title: Two New Angels  ........................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersTwo newly created Angels flew out of my Sewing Room over the festive season ... both Wendy Briggs of "Country Friends Designs" Angels (tho' Wendy is no longer designing patterns unfortunately)It all started when my dear friend Sandy & I were exchanging little snippets of our Christmas decorating with each other via private messaging.Â  Sandy sent me the photo above, of two of her Angels, both purchased from me when I was running my craft cottage & making & selling dolls.Â  I drooled over the image & when I saw Angel of Joy I thought to myself "Oh I doÂ want one!"Â  Â ğŸ’—So I hunted out my pattern book & began to make my own Joy Angel.Â  She is from Wendy's book Season of Joy ....As I have forgotten to take a photo I have borrowed this image from ebayI was lucky enough to have everything I used already in my stash but I had to buy a fat quarter of the red felt as mine was too "purple-ish" & this was a nice Christmas Red.Yes her hair actually IsÂ whole cloves!!! Hence she smells rather divine.Â  Â Painted shoes - I mixed together some red & black paints to get the right brown/reddish shade.The trickiest part (for me) was cutting out the hearts neatly in the bottom of her felt tunic.Â Â I have photographed her out on my deck table as our light is glary today & it's hard to get a decent photo inside the house.Â After I finished Angel of Joy, a couple of weeks prior to Christmas, I decided I would carry on & make another Wendy Briggs Angel ... this one is from the Homespun Magazine above which is dated July 2005 !!Â I have only had this pattern 18 & 1/2 yearsÂ ... waiting to be made!!Â  She is called "Berry Christmas Angel".Â  Â I even bought the white Linen back then, second hand from the thrift store - it has almost yellowed with age !!Â  ğŸ˜²I put the final stitch in her yesterday & I love her.Â  I have hung her from my old leadlight window frame & think she looks very happy there.Â  In the pattern Wendy has sprayed her entire Angel with a water/parisienne essence mixture to "tea-dye" her ... but I couldn't bear to do this to my pristine white girl.Â Instead of a felt star on her bodice, as the pattern suggests, I have sewn on this copper heart button - it was high time I used this as I purchased it a VeRy long time ago!Â  Her plum pudding is calico sewn, stuffed, painted white all over then the brown base painted on & embroidered with black french knots.Â  My "pudding" went missing for an entire day & I found it hidden under the spare room bed ... I am sure Little One had something to do with this tho' he denies it!I used the same felt as I used for Joy Angel to trim her skirt, same colour painted shoes also.Â Â You can see in the pattern above left, that Wendy's version has her eyes looking downwards.Â  I did this initially but felt she looked too stern, too severe ... so I painted over the whites & then made her look heavenward.Â  Â  Wendy's dolls are often inclined to have quite serious looking faces & I don't usually mind this, but I like her much more looking upwards.I am in love with my two new Angels & can't quite bear to pack them away just yet so I have told them they can remain out for the rest of the month so long as they behaveÂ  ğŸ˜‰Beautiful sweet peas, picked this morning.Â  I am having to move any scented flowers outside when The Mr is home as he has Long CovidÂ & anything fragrant makes him cough terribly.Â Â I thought I would share the Christmas Card Sid made me ... dear boy, he is growing up so very fast & will be 7 soon!Alec & his lovely Mum Sarah are on a 3 day tramp onÂ Mount Taranaki & sent this photo to my phone this morning.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Look at that stunning mountain in the background - they are having wonderful weather.Â Earlier this week I made Banana BreadÂ as our banana's ripen fast this hot weather.Â  I made two loaves & gifted one to my daughter in law.Â  They tasted delicious - this is such a nice, simple but moist recipe & keeps very well.Â Little One was most unwell an entire day last week.Â  I cried, fretted, prayed, & generally aged about 10 years in one day worrying over him.Â  The next day he'd bounced back right as rain & ran up a tree! He has taken up residence under myÂ Tilda Dolls Cot as he thinks no-one can see him under here.Â  Little does he know that Ginger furry girl can sniff out anyone !!!Â Â Wishing you a wonderful week ahead dear friends - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,Thank you as always, for your ever-welcome visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: Wishes for the New Year
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersÂ  ğŸ’•Just getting in a final post as the year draws to a close.Â  Â We are getting good rain here today ... December rain is always such a blessing & the garden is just drinking it up.Â Vases of sweetpeas & dahlia's picked this morning between showers.Christmas came & went again for another year.Â  Â We had two get-togethers ... firstly on the Saturday as eldest son & family were travelling down the Island for Christmas, & then another one on the 25th.I always enjoy watching my Grandsons open their stockings - it brings me great pleasureÂ  ğŸ„The week prior, I did some baking & packaged it up for friends ... just my usual Gingernut Bites & chocolate Fudge Slice ... a creature of habit I am!My dear friend Sandy posted me The Most DeliciousÂ chocolate Christmas cookies, all the way from the South Island.Â  And look Willie ... I madeÂ Scroggin Slice !!Â I always enjoy "the twixmas days"Â between Christmas & New Year.Â  Â  After all the hectic-ness that Christmas brings I love the slow, leisurely pace of these days.Â  Â I have been drinkingÂ Christmas Tea in my new-to-me Mug & eating delicious Christmas Cake.Eldest son & his family gifted me this wonderful book.Â  Â The Topp Twins are New Zealand icons ... my dear Mum would've loved this book as she so adored their music & requested their songs be played at her funeral.Â  Â I am enjoying reading it a great deal.We live on left-overs this week - so the only cooking I have been doing is harvesting & cooking up beetroot from my garden & blanching broccoli to freeze.Â  The Mr is growing cucumbers at the farm this year & is having a wonderful crop ... which is great because my plant produced One Single Cucumber before shrivelling up & dying !!I packed AllÂ the Christmas decor away!Â Â It took me two entire days but this was largely due to the fact that a certain Ginger Furry Being kept going to sleepÂ in my containers, thus stopping me from using them ... being the soft touch that I am, I waited for her to wake up! ğŸ˜‰GlassHouse Candle "Dancing Sugar Plums" gifted by my dear friend Sandy - such a gorgeous fragranceÂ -As the year draws to a close, I light a beautiful Candle & remember all those loved ones we have lost this year.Â  Â I include in this a special furry friend - sweet littleÂ Poppy Q who left us in July & who we all miss very much here in bloglandÂ  ğŸ’—From Donna Ashworth Words on InstagramThough this verse brings tears to my eyes I LoVe it & think it is very true indeed.Â  Grief has been a hard thing to navigate this past year.Wishing you a wonderful New Year dear friends.Â  Hand-on-heart I want to thank you all most sincerely for following along on my little journey here.Â  Your presence warms my soul more than words can ever express.Â  For those that comment or email, or even just take a moment to read my ramblings ... thank you all from the bottom of my heart.Sending much love & friendship out to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0 â¤â¤â¤

title: A Mini Christmas Home Tour
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWarningÂ ...very photo heavy post - apologies in advanceÂ  (I have made collages of photos to try & condense them up a bit)As promised, here is a mini-home-tour-of-sorts to show you my festive decorating.Â  Our home is a humble 3-bedroom house & this year I've decorated the deck, kitchen, dining area & lounge.Â The decking table is one of my favourite areas ... walk up the steps & onto our large covered outdoor deck.Â  Â Yesterday Sid & I hung some beaded garland from the wrought iron candlelabra.Â Mum's potted red geranium is flowering away merrily.Â  My entry is through glass French doors but I still manage to hang a wreath on them.And into the kitchen we go .....................I have a small galley style kitchen that leads directly into the dining room in an L-shape.Â  On the end of my bench, a small festive display on my egg crate.Â  Lean into your screen & take a big sniff of my citrus potpourri - it sure smells good ğŸ’›Â On the other corner of my bench I have just tucked some festive bits into things ... after all this is a well used area, not just for display.I like to hang little christmassy bits from my cupboard door handles - just tuck them in here & there - a bit of cheer ğŸ’—And directly into the dining area we go ... my vintage sewing table down the end has a large christmas display on it using my tiered trayLots of handmade creations here ..........Remember to click on any of the photos to enlarge themAlong the wall to the right .................I have wound fairy lights all through my plants on the fireplace hearth but they have decided today they are not going to work unless I stand there manually holding the switch wire ğŸ˜This fire gets used nearly 6 months of the year - the reason it is in the dining room is because once-upon-a-time, this room used to be the Lounge.The top of the dining room mantleÂ My Advent angel madeÂ in * this post * & my Country Friends Christmas angel madeÂ in * this post *A small round table in the corner with my knitted ornaments tree on it - I have not added to this as yet but I had grand intentions to this year (that somehow flew out the window) ğŸ˜‰Â My vintage kauri dresser that often features on my blog. Mostly op-shopped china with some festive berries added.A small display of bottle brush trees on top, thrifted transferware & Yes - I did sew tiny Santa hats for my miniature bears last Christmas ğŸ˜¯And then through in to the Lounge we go ............Â Â Vintage typewriter on my antique Oak tea wagon & a prim display on my spindle-leg American Oak table.Of all my displays, this top right one is one of my favourites - vintage feather tree with rustic & prim Santas & felt stockings - LoVe itMy fireplace - one of my absolute favourite areas to decorate.Â  This fire surround is faux - you can read all about it * here *.Â  Love, love decorating this area for the seasons.Keeping it traditional in my colour scheme.Â  These ornaments are all gathered/purchased when I spent 20 years working in a Gift Shop.Â Beside the fire surround is my Gothic Mirror - stockings all gifted from friends.Â  The Tilda Father ChristmasÂ was made * here *Little displays of toy vignettes that I tell myself are for the grandchildren but really they are for the grown up childÂ GrannyÂ that lives here - Yours truly ğŸ˜‰Under the tree I put my vintage wagon filled with mine & The Mr's oldÂ teddies ... the parcels are just empty boxes wrapped up.Â Â You can read about myÂ red car table in *this post*Â  - this area looks beautiful at night all lit up.Beside the red car table is another round occasional table where I display my pomanders - I have tucked festive bits into here.Opposite this is my Oak secretary desk - a small display on the top of this - again, just bits tucked into chinaÂ My "Mum corner" ... Mums oak table, canteen of cutlery, verses, glass trinket box & her reading glasses.Â  ğŸ’•A comfy chair display (mainy for Madam Pip) ğŸ˜‰ & a small primitive table beside this.Â  You can read about creatingÂ Prim Mousie * here *.Phew - well done friends, if you've made it this far.Â  To be honest I didn't even show quite a bit of it - too many photos as it was.Â  Yesterday I had Sid for the day & he had so much fun adding his dinosaurs to my "deer table" ... you can read about creating thisÂ in * this post *As this is my last post before Christmas day I want to wish you all a most wonderful festive season & to thank you allÂ with all my heart, for your support & encouragement throughout the year - it really does warm my soul & I have made some wonderful friendships through my blog.Remember during the coming days ... be kind to yourselves & to one another,Â  ğŸ„Sending you much love & friendship across the miles,Julie, Blackie, Pippi, Little One x0x0x0Â  â¤â¤â¤

title: A Green & Gold Christmas Coffee-Table Vignette
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersFirstly thank you all SoÂ very much for your sweet kind comments on my last post.Â  Â The general consensus seems to be "Leave the stand silver & paint the star" - which I am more than happy with.Â  Â Â The problem here is that the star is currently missing - I blame the youngest four-legged member of the family & live in hope that I can find it again (!!!)Â  ğŸ˜¸Last week I decided to do a Christmas coffee table display in a GreenÂ & Gold colourwayÂ  ğŸ’šğŸ’›This largely came about because I had these 3 cherished items, bought home when I cleared out Mum's homeÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â back in early March.Â  Mum always kept the Cherub candle holder & flower frog in her china cabinet & I found the gold Angel wrapped in tissue in a drawer.Â  I very much wanted to use these items as I especially loved the bronzy gold tonings of the cherub.Â Â I needed a tray for my display but had none apart, from silver ones.Â  I had bought this mirror home from Mums, actually lifted it off the wall at the last minute & thought I'd bring it home to donate.Â  It's frame was plain dark brown.Â  I unscrewed the hooks from the back so it sat flat & then went over the frame with my rub-n-buff ... it came up wonderful & just the right muted gold colour I was after.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Lights Turned OffÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Lights Turned OnÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â My only purchase was this gold glass "tree" which I bought online from Spotlight in their sale.Â  It has fairy lights inside & stands 36 cms tall.I knew I had some thrifted candles that would fit in the cherub & found the perfect Christmas green.Â  All the other items on my tray are from past Christmas's or items I use daily around my home.Â  I sprinkled some gold stars over the glass when I was happy with everything.The little wire heart tree in a pot also lights up & was purchasedÂ * here * back in 2020.The gold baubles were a previous op shop purchase - you can buy bags of these very cheaply.Â  The bottom ones are actually broken but you just place them in the bottom & no-one knowsÂ  ğŸ˜‰Â The tureens that the baubles are in are from the SPCA Op-shop purchased backÂ * here *Â in 2021.The wreath has been used for many years - I placed my glass tree inside it & wound some gold strings of beads around it.Â  Mums gold Angel sits just on the edge of it. The cream brocade tablecloth was a gift from my friend Joyce,Â  thrifted by her from the Church Op Shop where she works.I LoVedÂ my Green & Gold Vignette & when I sit on the couch at nights it makes me very happy to look at the treasures that were my Mums.Â Unfortunately I came in last night to close the curtains & what do you think greeted me dear friends .................... ??.................................................................................................................................................................................Go on .....Â  take a guess .....................................................................................Raise your hand if you guessed right !!!!!!!Â Â ğŸ˜Â And just look at the way her tail is curled so neatly around the flower frog making sure she doesn't stab her precious self !!!!!!!Â  Â She is honestly enough to make me give upÂ  ....... & then yesterday I came home from town to this belowÂ  .................................................................................Blackie parked up on my new outdoor table runner - Lord give me strength ! ğŸ™I decided to paint the wooden fruit board that I showed in my last postÂ as I wanted to use this special Christmas transfer.Â  Unfortunately it turned out too dark - I have photographed it outside today as it's such a dull overcast day - but indoors, in my house, the transfer barely shows up.Â  I should have used a light coloured background.Â  But it's okay - its all learning & not everything I paint turns out just magical & wonderful.I have acquired a small selection of Christmas books & wanted something to display them in.Â  This box (top left)Â was in my sleepout - it had gotten damp at some stage & had watermarks all through it.Â  I painted it Vintage White & mod-podged this lovely piece of decoupage paper to the front.Â  The paint covered over the watermarks really well.I'm really pleased with how this project turned out & Sid sat on the floor yesterday & read through some of the Christmas Children's books (all thrifted of course)The felt elf boots (top left) have been on my Pinterest board for a couple of years.Â  Last night I decided I wanted to make some so I drew up a pattern, scaled it down somewhat & then sat & stitched a pair of elf boots.Â  Mine are in pale green felt with pink pom poms because Why Ever Not ? ğŸ’šğŸ’—Before I close a mention regarding my last post .... the last photo of the $12 thrifted picture is actually Our beloved Late Queen as a young Princess Elizabeth.Â  Some of you realised this & some did not.Â  My dear friend Willie very kindly did some research on this & sent meÂ * this link * if any of you are interested in reading about the prints.Thank you so very muchÂ dear friends, for your visits here today,I hope to be back in a few days with a Christmas-Home-Tour-of-sorts to share with you,Wishing you a wonderful rest-of-the-week,With much love & friendship,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: A Thrifted/Upcycled Kind of Christmas   -  (Part 2)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersThank you all so much for the kind & encouraging comments you left me on my Part 1 post.Â I saw this on Instagram on marcandangels post - very true indeed!Â A couple of months ago, whilst browsing my local St John's Op Shop, I saw this cone below.Â  This was the same day I purchased the $1.50 wooden angel in my previous post.The cone was plastic & covered tightly in a thick brocade fabric - it measured 17 inches in height so was quite tall.Â  Â It has been $8.90, marked down to $3.90, & when I took it to the counter the lady took another dollar off as the tip was slightly broken.Â  Â I knew immediately I wanted to make it into a Yo Yo tree, the same as the one I madeÂ last year in * this post *I painted it 2 coats of Linen chalk paint - it adhered really well. I also glued cardboard in the base to give it some stability, although the paint did stabilise it rather well.Each evening sitting on my couch, I would make fabric yo yo flowers using fabrics in the French General range - it was quite therapeutic & as I made them I tossed them in a small basket by my chair.Â  I made larger ones (12cm) for the first 2 rows & then decreased in size to a 9 cm circumference.Finally - just yesterday - I had enough yo yo's to cover my cone.Â  I used fabric glue to attach them as I could not stitch through the painted surface.Â Â This silver candle holder has been in my stash forÂ yearsÂ a very long time & I thought it would make a good stand for my cone tree.Â  I currently have the tree just sitting atop the candle holder as I am unsure whether or not to paint this & I need your help & opinions please.Lots & lots of yo yo flowers ...... 62 in total !! ğŸ’—I had thought about painting the base in a dull Christmas red - the same colour I have usedÂ * here * on the wooden reindeer.Â  But I also rather like it left as it is ... sort of a bit vintage looking.Â Â What would You do dear readers?Â  Please leave me a comment below & let me know ... paint or leave as is ??Also the rusty star is just attached with double sided cellotape currently ... paint this ?? or leave as is ??Â  Your opinions would be very much appreciated.Â  Â  If you are unable to comment then just email me & I can copy/paste your comment.Â  Thanking you in anticipation.(My email address is stitchedbyjulie@hotmail.com)This pair of wooden chopping boards was $4 in Stratford Hospice shop earlier in the year. I decided to paint the round one at the back ... this turned out to be simply a wood round & Not a chopping board & the paint went on so well ... I am using the Forrest Green that I have become rather addicted to this Christmas.Two coats later & I applied a wonderful Iron Orchid Designs transfer that I purchased last Christmas.Â  I had planned to screw an eye hook into it to hang, but I rather like it just tucked into my display as is.When I bought the red hessian online in Spotlights Black Friday sale (last post) I also bought 2 metres of Minecraft fabric.Â  I made my Grandsons a pillowcase each using * this * simple tutorial..Â  As the fabric was extra wide I had enough on the sides to make them each up a drawstring bag as well.Â They are both right into everything Minecraft at present & I am sure they will love these items which I plan to put in their Christmas stockings.This morning I finished up some wooden tags that I had painted - some I used transfers on & others I mod podged serviettes onto.Â  These will be tied onto gifts for some special folk.We had a lovely craft group break-up outing last Monday when we visited Cambridge & went to viewÂ the Town Hall Â all decorated for Christmas.Â  We also visited a couple of Op Shops & had a nice cafe lunch.Â Click on the picture to enlarge it should you wish.Â  While I was waiting for the ladies to be served in the SPCA Op-shop, I happened to look down on the floor & this picture was leaning against a stand, kind of tucked into the corner.Â  I could not resist buying it & I absolutely love it! Â  Â  Â  So dear friends ... look around but also look upÂ  & look down when you are thrifting - you never know what bargains you may miss.Â  $12.00 an absolute bargain!Â  ğŸ’™Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you a wonderful rest of the week - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0x

title: A Thrifted/Upcycled Kind of Christmas  -   (Part 1)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have lots of Christmas Creations to share with you so I plan to be posting quite often throughout December.Today I wanted to share some thrifted & upcycled Christmas makes to hopefully inspire you that you don't need to spend alot of money - just a bit of imagination & time.Â Although I have forgotten to take aÂ Before Photo,Â the wooden Angel above left was picked up in the Stratford Hospice Op-shop for $1.50. She was a pale denim blue in colour. I painted her in 2 coats Antique White chalk paint & then decoupaged a Christmas serviette on to her dress. She makes a sweet display on my table along with a vase of Seafoam rosesÂ  ğŸ’—Remember backÂ in * this post * when I won the breadboard at a Pink Ribbon Breakfast fundraiser.Â  It had sat in the back of my craft cupboard so I added a pretty poinsettia transfer & gave it 2 coats spray acrylic varnish so that food can still be placed on it.The Reindeer above was white - he was on clearance (50 % off) in a local Variety Store last Christmas.Â  I painted him in red to fit in with where I planned to display him. The cherubs above right were purchased from my local SPCA store in mid winter.Â  Although they look plaster they are not & were only $4 each.Â The poor Angel above was a sorry sight in my local St Johns Oppy.Â  She was $1.50 & looked most unloved.Â  I pulled her to bits by holding my hair dryer over the star & wings to loosen the glue - this did not come away as successfully as I hoped.Â  But a sand, some chalk paint & decoupaged tissue, new hair,Â  then wire added to hang her with & some pip berries wound around the wire ... a huge improvement don't you think ??!!Â  ğŸ’•Frequently in thrift stores they have bins of kitchenware for very cheap as they seem to get so much of it donated.Â  I found the sifter & the vintage grater in Mums Hospice a couple of years ago.Â  Looking back through my photos I first attempted this in August 2022!!Â I filled ziplock bags with cheap toilet cleaner purchased from the $2 shop & left each item in it for a couple of days, turning frequently.Â  I wanted them to rust really well!!Â  Once they'd reached my desired rusty-ness, I ran cold water over them to stop the process & there they sat, in my cupboard ...... until last week ...... when I dragged out the Sifter.Â  I'd seen an idea on Pinterest & wanted to try it.You can see how rusted it got by the photo of the back view.I filled the inside with some wadding to about 3/4's the way up.Â  Then I hot glued in a variety of different bits & bobs ... rusty birdhouse, a pinecone, some greenery & pip berries.Â  I wanted some long cinnamon sticks but had none so I hot glued shorter ones together & then tied them up with torn fabric strips.I made a small calico gingerbread man as well as some candy canes which I tea dyed & then painted stripes onto. I packed it really tightly & secured everything, as well as poking some dried moss into the gaps.I also made a tag by tea dying a luggage tag ... I am so thrilled with how this project turned out & look forward to doing something with the grater now.Â The big messÂ creative space top left, was how my work table looked last week as I had various wooden bits in the process of being painted.Â Â I decoupaged tissue onto the oval tags & tied up 6 different soaps in cellophane & ribbon - I plan to gift these to the ladies tomorrow at our Christmas Craft Group break-up.Yesterday I did a Christmas display on my outdoor deck table.Â  I'd purchased 2 metres of red hessian in Spotlight's black friday sale & made this into a runner.Â  I placed my pots of white & red petunias on this but felt it stillÂ "needed something more"Â Â ............I had the chalkboard signs in my drawer so I painted them with Forrest Green & then added a transfer & Jute twine to make into a Christmassy sign.The teapot above left was a thrift store find months ago so I also painted this with the green while I had it out.Â  Once again, a transfer, some greenery & berries & it just finished off my table setting.Incidentally this is what you do when your teapot has a wet bottomÂ as well asÂ wet sides & lid ... you have to be a bit ingenious to dry it all at onceÂ  ğŸ˜‰The blackboard advent calendars were purchased last year at the same time as the wooden deer (previously mentioned) in a 50% off sale ... I bought 3 so gave one each to my Grandsons.Â Â I'm really delighted with my Christmas Outdoor table & No dear friends .... as I type this .... there is notÂ a cat on it as yet !!! ğŸ˜²My daughter-in-law Sarah makes me a beautiful calendar each year with photos of Alec in it.Â  Â I must admit to a bit of a ğŸ˜¥when I turned it over for December ... missing my dear Mum so very much!Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,I shall be back soon with Part 2 ... I just have to actually finishÂ the item before I can share it with you.Wishing you a wonderful week ahead - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: " A Jingle In A Pringle   " ğŸŒ²
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersYesterday I needed to wrap a fragile ornament for posting, so I found a cardboard tray in my recycling bin to cut up & use around the ornament.I went to find my packaging tape & upon my return, this is what I found ğŸ± ... a certain ginger furry friend curled up in the cardboard tray!Â  Â  Â This is especially for you Willie as you commented last week "no furry friends??"Â I might add - she slept for over 2 hours there before I was able to cut up the cardboard box.Â  You surely cannotÂ tell me that is comfy ??!!Back in early September when I returned from Mum's funeral & crafting was the very last thing on my mindÂ - my dear friend Claire messaged me to ask if I'd like to doÂ "a christmas challenge"?Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â She'd just had this bright idea for us to do "A Jingle in a Pringle".Â  What might that be I enquired? ğŸ˜‰Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  You takeÂ a Pringles tin & make somethingÂ christmassyÂ that will fit inside it !Â Hmmmm .... it certainly got my creative mind whirring ...Â I hadn't bought Pringles in years but Yes the local supermarket still sold them.Â  I purchased a can & Sid happily munched his way through them for me.Â  Then I painted my can 2 coats Forrest Green chalk paint.I had a lovely Christmas transfer that I thought would look just right against the Forrest Green colour ... I also glued some ribbon to the top & lower edges.Although I went back & forth with a few ideas, I came back to my original thought - making Claire the tiny Country Friends Christmas dolls in Wendy Briggs book.Â Â Wendy is no longer designing but I have lots of her older patterns & books.Â  It was tricky sewing & turning those teeny tiny doll legs & then painting the boots black ... its been awhile since I've done anything like this.The Mr would be in the dining-room working on his laptop in the evenings, & I would be in the Lounge.Â  He would send me phone photos of Little One who would sneak into my sewing room, take the dolls (or doll body parts)Â off my desk & then play with them ... this went on for several nights despite how well I hid themÂ  ğŸ˜I was absolutely delighted how the dolls turned out.Â  Their names are Joy & Kris Kringle & I managed to make them entirely from fabrics & trims already in my stash.Â  Â Â You can see from the photo above that they are only the size of a pencil - just under 6 & 1/2 inches in height ... so rather tiny & fiddly.A closer view of their handpainted boots & Joy has some stitchery on her skirt.Once they were finished I was looking at them & wondered if perhaps Claire might like to make them into a swag.Â  So I made a little stuffed heart from homespun fabric ... I didn't stitch them into a swag as they would not have fitted into the Pringles tin but I wrote Claire a note suggesting this when I sent the package down.You can see how they might look stitched into a swag.I also had room (onlyÂ just!)Â to add in one of the stockings that I showedÂ in last week's post.Â  I filled it with some choccies, a candy cane & a small ceramic Christmas tree ornament.Let me tell you dear friends - it was a tight fitÂ getting all those items in that Pringles tin without squashing them up too much!!I bought a Christmas box at the Variety Store, packaged it all up in red tissue,Â  then added one of the wooden tags that I madeÂ in *this post* last year.Â  I also added in some Choccies, some Relax tea & a bag of my homemade Citrus Potpourri.Â  The package only took 2 days to arrive at Claires & she was so thrilled upon opening it.Â Â The reason I sent it before December is because Claire is taking part in a Christmas Home Tour this weekend ... opening her home all decorated for Christmas, & I thought she might perhaps like to include the swag in her decorating.I shall be sure & show you my Jingle in a Pringle from Claire when it arrives.This morning was a baking morning whereby I madeÂ Caramel Anzac SliceÂ for my eldest son,Â Â a Weetbix SliceÂ for The Mr, & another loaf ofÂ Banana BreadÂ as I had banana's turning brown.Â Image courtesy of @LadySnowAngel on PinterestTomorrow we wave Goodbye to November & welcome in December & the festive season.Â  It feels like I blinked & November disappeared by.Thank you dear friends, as always, for your welcome visits here today,As we approach a busy time of year, please remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,Â With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the 3 furry ones x0x0x0

title: All Stocking-ed Out (!!!)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersIt has been a stocking-making kind of week (or fortnight) & I am currently all stocking-ed out !Â Our beautiful Cherry Blossom treeÂ (Shimidsu-sakura) in full bloom a couple of weeks ago, before the strong winds came.At the beginning of October my local Patchwork Store Stitchin-stuffÂ put a notice in their online newsletter requesting small christmas stockings to be made to donate to the local Foodbank. I collected the free pattern & instructions & cut out several from my Christmas fabrics.Â  I managed to sew up 10 before Covid struck me & my sewing abilities disappeared out the window ğŸ˜Â They are fully lined & padded with wadding, & each one measures just under 8 inches.Â  This one above was one of my favourites fabrics.Â Â The store were hoping to reach a target of 300 stockings & when I dropped mine in they were up to 279.Â Â (Click on the picture to enlarge & read clearly)So I was delighted to read in my local newspaper this week that they actually reached 350 in the end.Â  The store fills them with chocolate treats & they go in the Foodbank boxes for families that have younger children.Â  Next year I will aim to sew up more as I am sure I have 10 already cut out.These sweet little stockings above are a free pattern from theÂ Twig and TaleÂ website.I buy offcuts of linen when I see it in the thrift stores & I hand embroidered these before sewing.Â  I plan to fill them with some ceramic christmas ornaments for a couple of special people.Last year, after Christmas, I made myself the swag of primitive stockings above.Â  My dear friend Sandy had shown me a photo on her phone & I made them from memory ... in the softest green & grey striped linen fabrics above.Â Â My friend Sandy has moved away down to the South Island & I miss her immensely. I decided to make her a set in reds & taupes as I knew she loved these colours.Â  I posted them away & Sandy was delighted when they arrived as she had just begun her Christmas decorating.While hunting for some threads I came across this stitchery that I had stitched last Christmas & never ever made up.Â  It is a very old design from Mogs Designs whom I am sure no longer designs. It is called "tis' the season stocking"Although I'd done the stitchery I still needed to tea-dye my calico & then make up the stocking, stuff it & fill the top with berries & greenery as well as make the 3 candy canes. I also sewed 7 rusty bells down the length of the stocking.Â Â I used to make lots of these & sell in my Craft Cottage & they were always VeRy popular.Â  Â ğŸ„I love this little area of hand-mades hanging on my wall.Â  The Calico Reindeer I madeÂ in * this post * back in 2020.And Yes -Â it was time again to sit & wrap 48 little parcels, & fill my Grandsons advent stockings.Â  This was a good activity to do while resting from Covid & took me 3 days to complete (!!!) I will be delivering these this coming Thursday.Â Just prior to going on the Cruise I cleaned out our fireplace, scrubbed the brick surround & then bought all my houseplants back from the "hospital corner"Â down the end of my lounge.Â  I noticed my ladder fernÂ (2nd from left)Â had roots coming out the bottom so it needed a re-pot.I found this pot under my house, bought home from Mum's when I cleared out No 44 way back in February.Â  I thought it was a good size for the fern but needed a paint.Â  I painted it in Old Linen, the same colour as the other pots, then gave it 2 coats of spray varnish to protect/seal it.Â  I found an offcut of transfer that I also applied to it.I am sureÂ that my ladder fern breathed a sigh of relief when I repotted it & it's looking much healthier already.Â  And Yes dear readers - you can see definate signs of Christmas decorating going on here at Threadbear HQ.Thank you - as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful week ahead - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0xÂ ( a new Header to take us into the festive season)

title: Cruise-ing,  Covid ........  &  Orders
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersOctober of last year, while I was lying in a hospital bed recovering from a not-especially-nice surgery, my friend Gail sent me a text ... Would I like to go on a 5-day cruise next year in November??Â Why ever not ?! I thought.Â  Of course it was ages awayÂ & anything could happen in between times (& in fact, quite alot did happen in between times)There were a group of 8 ladies going, mostly our craft group ladies plus 2 extra.Â  Because we shared rooms it kept the cost to a minimum.Â The first rose blooms of the season - Dublin Bay - picked last weekEventually November rolled around & the day arrived for us to board our ship.Â  It was a P & O Cruise for those that are familiar with them.Â  This one was a "Tribute to the King Cruise" so lots of Elvis music & rock-n-roll. I must add here, that the tribute acts were just wonderful & of a really high quality.Here is everyone getting ready for the Sail Away Party.Â  I loved being up high on this deck & looking down on the pools, also there was a flying fox going overhead!Â  After pouring rain all the way up to Auckland the weather came out beautiful.The was the Atrium where some of the entertainment took place ... I especially loved the Glass Lifts (right).Â  Â This was on Level 5 & we were lucky enough to have our rooms on the same level.Here are all 8 of us together ...Â  left going around table .. Jan, Sharlaine, myself, Joyce, Maureen, Liz 1, Liz 2 & Gail front right.This was the route the ship took, leaving Auckland sailing down the Coast to Picton, a full day in Picton, & then returning again.Â  5 days - quite long enough for me - who couldn't wait to get home to her furry friends again ğŸ˜‰Where I have put the yellow +Â is where I live in rural Waikato.Here is the oldest of the group Maureen, with myself, the youngest.Â  On the right I had just had my hair done & we were getting ready to go to a Neil Diamond Tribute show (which turned out to be so amazing!!)On docking in Picton we had already prepaid for a tour up the Queen Charlotte Sounds (see map above).Â  We were going on the boat below left with a Company calledÂ CougarLine ToursWe sailed all the way up the Queen Charlotte Sounds stopping at all the little bays along the way, dropping off boxes of groceries, trampers, sometimes picking up tourists - it was fascinating & the Captain gave a running commentary along the way.Â  We saw lots of dolphins, some even followed the boat for awhile.Â Â The stunning crystal clear waters of the Queen Charlotte Sounds.The furthest point was Furneaux LodgeÂ 2 hours out ... & then we headed back to Picton again.Once back in Picton we treated ourselves to a delicious Pub Lunch of the freshest Gurnard, straight out of the sea.Â  There was a market opposite the wharf which we wandered through for awhile & then it was time to catch the shuttle back to the ship.Â  Another full day at sea & then early on the Tuesday morning we berthed again in Auckland.Waiting our turn to disembark - you had to vacate your rooms by 8 am so we were up & about early.Â  It was a wonderful experience & I would certainly cruise again but I would do several things differently next time around.Â My dear friend Sandy summed it up perfectly when she messaged & said "Congratulate yourself Julie on having the Cruise experience - especially since you are such a Home body at heart"Â  And I unashamedly Am a Homebody. ğŸ’—Unfortunately dear friends, I appear to have come home with a rather unwanted souvenirÂ & I am the only one in the group that has so far succumbed to the virus.Â  Today is day 8 & although I'm not coughing quite so much, I still feel constantly dreadful.Â  But I know Covid is a process & I just have to be patient, rest & let it run its course.Â  It has taken me 3 days to write this post as my concentration skills are rather lacking ğŸ˜A couple of months ago my dear friend Shirley asked me to make her two items she had some photos of.Â  The first was a HOME wallhanging, quite primitive in style but Shirley didn't want primitive for her home so we adapted it & I painted a wooden coathanger to tie Shirley's hanger on to (the one in her photo was tied to a twiggy treeÂ branch) Shirley's home is muted pinks & greys so these colours were perfect.The second item Shirley had photographed was a rather dilapidated looking Angel.Â  As soon as I saw it I knew I had that pattern - thankfully it was an old design from Mums Moment, whom I don't think are designing anymore. The pattern is called Pocket Angel as she has a sweet elasticated pocket on her dress, where the yo-yo flowers are.Â  I made her up in Tilda fabrics, provided by Shirley & think she turned out delightful.Â  I used some hand-dyed mohair yarn for her hair.Â  Her base is weighted with pellets so she sits nice & sturdily.Her wings are embroidered with the words Love is the stitching that holds hearts together ğŸ’• Shirley was thrilled with both her Orders.Thank you dear friends for staying with me through this lengthy post,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Love Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: Craft Group Challenges,   Book Characters   &  A Little One Update
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersYesterday I picked a beautiful bunch of lilacs from my tree - this is only the 2nd year it has flowered but last year was not enough to actually pick any.Their fragrance is gentle & soft ... I have sat a framed photo of Mum underneath as she would be smiling I am sure.Throughout the year my friend Gail & I like to think up random "challenges" for the ladies in our craft group.Â  When I hosted the ladiesÂ back in July I had saved & washed up a load of cat food tins.Â Â  We go through 2 or 3 of these a day so it doesn't take long to get a good supply.Â  I'd removed their labels & any stickiness left behind & I held the bag out & told the ladies it was a Lucky DipÂ - they could take 1,2 or 3 ... or however many they wanted ... & they had to create something with them!(I should add that these challenges are entirely optional to take part in)I chose 3 tins for myself & then found this old broken table leg in my stash that I knew would-come-in-handy-one-day.Â  I cut it down to size & then painted the tins & the spindle. Then I hot glued the tins to my spindle as I wanted to make AÂ Sewing Caddy.Click on the picture to enlarge for a closer lookI mod-podged some paper serviettes to my tins & spindle to embellish them - I'd originally planned to use transfers but paper serviettes are a lot more cost effective.Â  Then I mod-podged the whole thing to seal it.(I've forgotten to photograph it step by step hence I am explaining what I did)Tin 1 : I drew a cardboard circle, padded it, covered it with fabric & glued in - this was to hold my quilting clips.Tin 2 : I cut some floral foam to fit & then cut a slit in the middle & covered the entire thing with fabric - this was to be a scissor holder.Tin 3 : I made into a pincushion using a gathered circle of fabric & some wadding, all glued in.I made a little stitched tag to attach to the handle along with a scissor charm & then I filled my tins with their various bits & bobs.Such a sweet, fun project & would make a gorgeous gift for a crafty person ğŸ’—I loved what Sharlaine had done ... she had taken a thrifted wooden goblet, turned it upside down, glued her catfood tin onto it & then painted the whole thing & added some transfers.Â  It was so lovely & would be wonderful with a small candle or tealight in it ğŸ’œMaureen had cut hers into the shape of a sunflower, painted it & attached it to a thin dowel, then sprinkled glue + glitter to the centre.Â  This would look great poking into a potted plant ğŸ’›Liz had been thinking of her grandchildren when she created hers & had knitted tiny peas with black eyesÂ as well as worms with tiny felt hats on, then made the cans into houses for them, including using the lids off the tins.These had been such a hit that Liz asked me for some more cans as other family members had ordered some from her - I was happy to oblige.Â - Before -Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  - During -Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  - After -Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â A tiny bud vase picked up from the Op-Shop for $1.50 - given the tomato sauce treatmentÂ last week.Â  I originally thought it was brass but I think under all the grime & discolouration it was more silver.Â Sids school recently held a Book Week.Â  To celebrate the children got to choose a Book Character & then dress up as that character.Â  Sid chose Marmaduke Duck from the book above.Posing at HomeÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â At school with the telescope his Dad made himHis Mum did an amazing job of creating his costume using alot of what Sid already had (orange shorts, socks etc). My contribution was the hot glue gun, some white feathers & the wooden spoon tucked into his belt.Â  Sid was delighted to win the competition for his classroom & won a book voucher.Many of you have asked after Little One & I have not updated you for awhile.Â  He is doing well & is living his best lifeÂ ğŸ˜‰ No Pippi & Blackie have still not accepted that he is here to stay - Pippi is the worst & still hisses & chases him at every opportunity - Blackie not so much.Â  It is certainly easier now he can go outside during the day & we only have to keep them apart in the evenings when they all come in for the night.He is still kitten-ish in that he wants everything you touch & frequently runs off with my crafty bits.Â  He must be happy enough though because I have never known a cat to purr so much !!Â  In my naive way, I still live in hope that they will one day get along but who knows?!Â  When I do my big monthly grocery shop & buy cat food, the girl on the check-out always asks me ...Â How many cats do you have??? I usually say 4 as I include Fluffy at the farm ğŸ˜‰Thankyou as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x

title: A Trike-Trailer,   A Drawer,   & Dishcloth Knitting
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersThose that know me well, know my absolute LoVe of old vintage trikes ... I have four of them in varying states of disrepair.Â This one above is still looking pretty with the last of the pansies blooming, but these will sucumb to mildew soon as it's getting warmer here.This trike above left is probably my "best one" as far as condition goes.Â  It has always stayed up on my covered deck so doesn't get the weather & the Grandkids have ridden it frequently so I keep it oiled & running smoothly.Â Â The trike trailer was purchased from the SPCA Op Shop ($12) late last year.Â  I had been asking The Mr to weld a loop to my trike so I could hook the trailer through itÂ  .................... but I was still waiting ....................During my deck clean-upÂ in my last post I found an old wire hook & managed to find a gap under the trike tray that I could screw this into quite securely.Â  I was delighted ğŸ˜Š - I gave the trike & the trailer a good scrub as they were both looking green after the winter.As I knew I wanted to sit potted flowers in them, I lined each tray with an offcut of oilcloth to help prevent the wet pots sitting against the surfaces & rusting.Â Â I planted some mixed colour petunias into six terracotta pots I already had - 3 for each tray.How happy this little set makes me every time I look at it.Â  Â And if the Grandsons want to ride around on it still, then it's simple to lift the pots out & away pedalling they can goÂ  ............This old drawer was found at Mum'sÂ Hospice Shop at the same time I bought the Pansy Planter Box.Â Â  I thought it might make a handy addition to my craft room.Â  It had originally been bolted to a desk so I removed the old hardware from the back.Â  It was actually formica but I thought it should chalk paint up okay.You can see I removed the handle & painted right over it the same colour.I gave it 2 coats of chalk paint in the colour Vintage White.Â  It went on really grainy - to be honest I think this was more the paint than anything wrong with the surface of the formica.Â  I tried thinning my paint out but it still went on like this.Â  I very lightly sanded the roughness out afterwards but still wasn't happy with it.The drawer had a chunk out of one corner but I was able to fill this with some polyfiller.Â  I came across a large sheet of decoupage tissue that I'd been gifted last Christmas & decided to use this over my paint.Â  This was my first time using this tissue & it went on really well using mod-podge.Â  Once dry I coated it again with mod-podge as I find this seals everything & makes it wipeable.The sheet was large enough that I did the top, the drawer front & also managed to line the drawer base.Â I tied a Tilda swing tag to the handle & soon filled it with crafty bits & bobs.Â Â I was really pleased with the finished result after being not so happyÂ with it originally.And it fits in just perfectly on my sewing bench ğŸ’™The last time I delivered an Order of Potpourri toÂ Brandy's Botanicals Deb asked me if she could try some of my knitted cotton dishcloths to sell.Â  I was more than happy to oblige as I just love knitting these up -Â here isÂ the free pattern I use.I decided I needed to come up with a nice packaging method that was not too overly fancy but presented them nicely. I tied a brown paper belly band around them & then made up some swing tags that I printed off onto brown paper & cut out.Â Â I was pleased with the simple but effective way they looked.Â  I had enough cotton in my yarn stash that I was able to knit 10 different ones to send down to Deb.Â  This way people can pick them up & feel the softness of them but also Deb can package them up with a soap easily enough if she so wishes.Last month Alec had his first ever Grandparents Day at his country school - they have been cancelled in recent years due to various Lockdowns.Â  He dressed up as a Wizard & I dressed up as a Granny ğŸ˜‰ (!!!)(I promise to have a proper cat update in my next post - Little One is fine & dandy & No - they are still not getting along)Thank you so much as always dear friends, for your visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: Three Things I do each Springtime
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersLongtime readers of my blog will know there are three things I like to do each Spring to help to refresh my home & outdoor area.Â The last of the spring freesia's picked this morning & displayed in Mum's crystal vaseÂ Thing One :Each Spring I like to treat myself to a fresh new length of Oilcloth for my dining table.Â  This table is a workhorse & gets a great deal of use so I really enjoy refreshing it each year.Â  This gorgeous 1.5 metre length was purchased online from this wonderful store.Â  I've always been partial to paisley designs & this really caught my eye.I especially loved the Lineny look & feel of it, even though it is fully wipeable.A gorgeousÂ new variety of Gerbera gifted to me from my friend Sharlaine ... sitting on a thrifted silver tray.Thing Two :Every spring I give my old wrought iron table & chair set another coat of paint.Â  The colour is Hot Chilli & I just use the Resene testpots for this - I had some left over from last spring. This set is so old now that The Mr tells me the only thing holding it all together is the paint I keep applying to it.Â They are sitting up on my deck at present as everything on the lawn is covered in a fine confetti of blossom flowers that are floating everywhere with the winds we are getting.Thing Three :I always give my large wooden outdoor table a good scrub with sugar soap.Â  During the winter months I keep an eye on Spotlight & when their Hessian comes on sale I buy a 2 metre length of it to refresh my table.Â  This year it was $3 a metre on sale so the length only cost me $6.Â Â I like to overlock the ends to stop fraying & I also gave it an iron as it was creased.Â  No sooner had I gone to get my plants to display on it, than a certain ginger furry being decided it looked rather nice & comfy & plonked her derrier down on it ğŸ˜Â  Usually she sashays down it like a runway - being the Princess that she is !!!I have some potted red petunias in my vintage scales & in the old cooking pot I have planted white petunias.Â  I didn't plan on a Ginger Cat featuring in my display but it appears that this may be non-negotiable !! ğŸ±Â The pansies in myÂ black planter box had gone mildewy so I replaced them with some red & white Impatiens ... every single thing got a good scrub & a clean & a de-cobweb.I don't particularly enjoy this job but things get really manky during winter & if you want to have all theseÂ derelictÂ vintage treasures around then I feel you need to actually care for them.Â Â Otherwise it all ends up resembling Steptoe's Yard.Â My friend Jane had given me this sweet daisy wall pot so I drilled some holes in the base & planted it with some miniature viola's.Â  So simple & lovely ğŸ’œThe 5 red tulip bulbs I planted in Mum's old pedestal pot are flowering & looking so vibrant.This lily bulb has come up & although the flower looks brown in my photo it is actually quite black & reminds me of velvet.Â  I have no idea who gave me this or when I planted it here.It has been school holidays here in New Zealand & I have had the Grandsons on various days.Â  Sid's Mum asked me to drop him home a bit earlier last week as he was going for a haircut.Â  This is the photo I got sent later that day.Â  This is very "out there" for Sid who is usually such a reserved little boy.Â  It did make me smile.I want to thank you all from the bottom of my heart for your comments on my Eulogy Post last week for my Mum.Â  I did hesitate when I went to hit Publish but I write this blog as a record for myself & my Grandchildren who may read it all one day & I felt it was important to include it.Â  Your comments just warmed my sad heart so very much - you are all so kind & thoughtful. ğŸ–¤Wishing you all a wonderful weekend dear friends - we are due some rain here in rural Waikato so it might be a sewing weekend.With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: My Mum's Circle of Life  ğŸ–¤
text: Greetings dearest friends & readers ğŸ–¤On the 31st of August, the official last day of Winter here at the bottom of the world, my beloved Mum's Circle of Life came to a close.Â  As she took her final breath,Â I was there by her side holding her hand, patting her head & playingÂ her favourite song.Â  I told Mum that it was okay to go & be with Dad now, to be well & happy & healthy again.Â  That's how I like to think of them now ... together after 22 years apart.When Mum met Dad he was fresh out of the Armed Forces & not ready to settle down.Â  She loved him & waited patiently ... eventually they got engaged, married & moved up to Taranaki to begin their new life together.They became parents to my brother & I - & built a house at Number 44 where Mum was to live for the next 61 years of her life.Mum loved being a wife, a mother & a homemaker - even during the difficult years, of which there were many. Money was tight & Mum learned to be frugal, to make-do-and-mendÂ  ....Â qualities that never ever left her.(Mum is on the left in both photos)Born & raised in the Manawatu area, Mum was the 3rd eldest of 11 siblings!Â  Her favourite always, was her older sister Margaret, gone 6 years now.Â  They remained close all of their lives.Mum was always neat & immaculate - both in her appearance AndÂ especially in her Home.After Dad passed away, 22 years ago now Mum decided she'd like to try travelling, having never ever been out of New Zealand.Â Â Together we were lucky enough to do 4 trips to Australia over the ensuing years - we both thoroughly enjoyed these trips immensely, visiting two of Mum's brothers.Youngest Son Kayne & wife Nicole on left & eldest son Aaron & wife Sarah with Mum on right - taken April 2022 - Mums 93rd birthday !Mum loved being Nan to my 2 sons & was delighted when she was able to attend both their weddings, 8 & 9 years ago now.Â Â Mum would often say to me "I hope I live long enough to be a Great Grandmother but I don't think that I will".Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  It was to her utter delight that she got to become special "Great Nan" to Alec & Sid, 6 & 8 years ago now.I absolutely LoVe this photo above & we used this on Mum's service sheet for her funeral ğŸ’—Taken at a re-union lunch in the Bay of Plenty almost 7 years ago now - the last remaining siblings of the 11, both Mum & Aunty Marg (seated centre)Â now passed away.Mum (reluctantly)Â entered Resthome Care last June (aged 93) & these photos were taken then.Â  Altogether Mum was in the Resthome for 15 months.Â When IÂ cleared out No. 44 for sale last February,Â  I came across this plastic Shampoo Product bag & put it in my brother's Safe.Â  After Mum's passing we opened it & along with Birth Certificates & Mum's Will, it contained all her requests for her Funeral arrangements ... the Undertaker she wished to use, the Venue, the type of Casket she wanted, the Flowers, the Music/songs played & the Poem to be read out - it was incredible!Tucked into the bag was this envelope with strict instructions to be placed in her casket with her.Â  The letters were written by my brother & I in 1968 (I was 8!) ... & posted to Mum who was in hospital at the time.Â  Mum's great Grandsons also made her a card each & these went in with our letters.Â Mum chose this Poem to be read at her Service & wanted pink & mauve flowers on her casket.Â  It made everything very simple to just follow out her instructions.Â Â I think Mum would've been very pleased with her Farewell ... I think she may NotÂ have been so pleased at all the cousins that came out of the woodwork, some she had not seen for well over 22 years!Â  I will never understand why people do this - yet they can't even pick up a phone & say Hello - how are you?!Â  I had to use my not-so-nice-voice a number of times to bring it all back to the small private service that Mum wanted.Even though I had mentally prepared myself for Mum's passing for quite some time, I still cannot get my head around that she is no longer here.Â  I jump when my phone rings, thinking it may be the Resthome.Â  I hear some news & I think Oh I must tell Mum that.Â  Plus I have been hit by a wave of exhaustion (or maybe grief) since my return home again.Â The views from my brother's house where I stayed - the sea out the dining room window & out the other side, Mount Taranaki wearing his winter cloak!Anyway dearest friends ... although I have a head full of fluff, I will endeavour to return to blogland again & catch up on all your posts.Thank you sincerely, if you have stayed through this lengthy post - I wanted to write this Eulogy for myself more than anything but in all honesty, how do you cover 94 years - it would take 10 blog posts!Â  A dear friend sent me this little Verse last week & I thought how perfect.Â  ğŸ’™Wishing you a wonderful week ahead dear friends - remember to be kind to yourself & to each other ... & I hope you find those Glimmers in your week,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the Furry Three x0x0x0 ğŸ±ğŸ˜¸ğŸ˜º

title: A Bird-House Creating Workshop
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersEvery few days I pick some fresh stems of Daphne - I like to keep a small vaseful on my kitchen bench & each time I'm working there I lean in & have a big sniff ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’— ... as far as I'm concerned the daphne season is over wayÂ too fast.My dearest friend Sandy moved away down the South Island earlier this year & I miss her dreadfully.Before she left she gave me a big bucketful of bulbs, mainly daffodils. I picked out some large sized ones & planted them in my wheelbarrow as the begonias I had in there were not doing well.Â  I am so delighted with my daffy display & think of Sandy every time I walk past it, & smile ğŸ’›A couple of Saturday's ago I attended a workshop out atÂ The Floral Shed.Â Â Very longtime readers of my blog will remember Nita when she first opened the Hummingbird - I wrote a blog post on it *here*.Â  Nita has now established a large garden at her rural property, opened a Shop there, as well as supplying Florists & running Workshops.Â  When I saw a space available in the Birdhouse making one, I put my name down without thinking too hard about it.Driving out there I felt a little anxious as I did not know any of the other ladies doing the workshop.Â Seeing it all set up around the work table, I felt immediately inspired.Â  My first attempt came together quite quickly but then I realised I'd put my sides on wrongly ... Nita easily recitified this & gave me a new kit.Â  It was so much fun banging in nails - you actually had to hit them really hard to go into the wood.The photo above was taken by Ayla who does photography & social media for Nita via her own businessÂ fablefolknzÂ I was so totally engrossed in drilling that I did not know it was being taken but I did ask Ayla for permission to use her photo in my post, which she very kindly gave me.Â  Â After our birdhouses were assembled we all stopped for a delicious morning tea.Â  Look at that food - I can attest that it was amazing!After morning tea the fun part (for me) began when we got to decorate & embellish our birdhouses.Â  Nita had a great array of rustic bits & bobs for us to choose from.Â  Some ladies kept theirs quite plain, others went over the top - they all looked wonderful.(That is me second from the right for those that don't know me ğŸ˜‰)Although I knew none of the other ladies I think I hit the jackpot because they were all just soÂ lovely & friendly, inspiring & fun to be with.Â  Here we all are, so proud of our birdhouses - we all agreed that it was indeed a wonderful way to spend a morning & that we don't do this sort of thing for ourselves, often enough.Â Here is my finished birdhouse - I wanted to add the No 91 to it because - well that is my address! I found some silver numbers that you put on birthday cakes & painted them matt black.Â  I just adore my birdhouse in all its "rustic-ness".Â  I would do another workshop with Nita in a heartbeat.Â Currently I have it sitting on my deck area under my vintage Mangle.Â Â My lovely friend Shirley was visiting so I made some banana & white chocolate muffins as I had banana's turning brown.Â  A few days later I was hunting for a caramel slice recipe online & came across a new-to-me recipeÂ Â Caramel Anzac Slice. It sounded divine & as I had all the ingredients, I made it up.Â  By the amount of pieces that have passed my lips I can certainly attest that it was delicious ğŸ˜I would like to be able to say that we have harmonious relations in our furry family but I would not be telling the truth.Â  Thankfully Little One can go outside now & it's made my life a little easier.Â  I bring him in about 5 o'clock & he has a rest by the fire before causing havoc for the rest of the evening, then bedtime.Â  You can see by the blue arrow he hides under this unit, thinking he is invisible. We don't as yet allow him in the lounge as it gives Pippi & Blackie a room to get away from him.Â  He of course, has other ideas!Pippi is "milking it for all it's worth" & knows I will allow her on the things she is not usually allowed on, for example my Mums good mohair throw blanket.Â  I still live in hope but I must admit - it's wearing thin some daysÂ  ğŸ˜–My chocolate addictionÂ consumption continues & this arrived in my inbox yesterday sent from The Mr. I think it was supposed to make me feel better .... it did notÂ  ğŸ˜‰Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Enjoy the rest of the week & remember to be kind to yourselves & each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry three x0x0x0

title: Hosting The Craft Group Ladies
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWell it would seem that I blinked & July ended ğŸ˜• - the year is slipping by so very fast.It was my turn to host the craft group ladies in July & I just managed this on the very last day.Â  When I look back at the busloads of Garden Groups that I used to host it is hard to believe how much work it felt like just to get ready for 7 ladies!!!Â  It felt like a marathon effort.Â In my attempts to tidyÂ upÂ prettify thingsÂ a bit round here I went off to the Garden Centre with a birthday gift voucher from my friend Gail.Â  I could not resist the super healthy looking maidenhair fern above, as my last one was looking rather deadÂ sad.I also used the voucher to buy these lovely cyclamen above - just the pop of colour my outdoor space needed at the moment ğŸ’—Mine is the one on the right - an old frame of Mums that I repurposedWe had previously decided to make this craft meeting a Mid-winter Christmas theme so I chose the "Joy" frames as our project.Â  Everyone had to bring along their own painted frame.Â  We had a lovely time glueing vintage music papers to our frames, stamping the word "Joy" & then making the tiny wreaths to go on them.Â  I love how everyone's turned out slightly different as each of the ladies put their own spin on it.Â Â Our challenge issued last month was from Gail.Â  She handed everyone a Daphne's Diary magazine & we all had to make a project out of it.Â  Gail works at the Op Shop & a large pile of almost-new Daphne's Diary magazines had been donated.Â  This is my copy above.Wanting to try something a bit different, I chose the leaf art above.Â  I found a tree down the far end of my section with these large green leaves on it so I pressed & dried them for a week.Â  I was really pleased with how the painting turned out but unfortunately I put them too close to our fire to dry the paint & they burnt & crinkled up quite a bit.Â  You can see the brown markings above where they burnt.Â  So I decided to try another project.The patchwork coasters caught my eye so I found my scrap bag of Tilda fabrics - Yes I save everyÂ scrap!Â  These were a fun & simple project to whip up - I used wadding in the middle & a pretty floral backing.Â  These would look lovely tied up with a scrap of lace & gifted together with a pretty coffee mug.Â I had originally planned to give the ladies another project after lunch so I trialled the snowflakes made from wooden clothes pegs.Â  You can find the instructions * Here *.Â  I found that the wooden pegs were very rough & required lots of sanding once I'd glued them, then when I painted them I wasn't that happy with the end result so I ended up mod-podging a paper serviette over it to hide the faults.Though I was able to show the finished project we did not end up creating it - perhaps another month we may make it as our group project.Â Â This is our lunch tableI know I have said this before, but one thing we alwaysÂ get right at our meetings is the food!Â  We all bring a shared plate & everyone bought something christmas-themed along.Â  It was wonderful to have the hot food as it was a cold bleak day here.Â Â Our morning tea table above - Yes Willie, I made Scroggin Slice !Â I reached my hand into my christmas decorations box & pulled out a few little bits to decorate our table & make it feel a bit more mid-winter christmassy.I picked Sid up at lunchtime on Tuesday as they had parent-teacher interviews.Â  He wanted to craft so we made this "penguin" above from toilet roll tubes.Â  Sid has named him "Frank" ğŸ˜‰I captured this photo of Pippi last week ... she had been creeping up on Little One on the deck & thought that she was hidden behind The Mr's farm gumboots.Â  She was Not impressed when he ran away inside & she couldn't stalk him any longer.Â Wishing you a wonderful week ahead dear friends - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Love Julie & the furry ones (all 3 of them!) x0x0x

title: Arts And Crafts
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWhenever I ask Sid what he would like to do today he alwaysÂ replies "Arts & Crafts".Â  I save a myriad of boxes, tubes & other containers that I think he might enjoy creating with.The other day he made a "marble run" ... a contraption made of tubes etc for his marbles to go down - even including a sharks mouth for the marble to run through. I am always amazed at his imagination & he never needs any prompting.Â Every Tuesday after school we go to Lego Club which is held in a part of our local Library.Â  Afterwards we go into the Library & he chooses books to get out.Â  The Christmas craft book above left caught his eye as he wanted to make the Snow Globe Terrarium in it.Â  Off to the Op-shop we go to buy a large glass jar for $2.Â  Thankfully Granny had everything else required to make it.Sid wanted to "re-enact" the scene shown in the book so I found my other bottle brush trees & we did a matching display.Â  The snow globe has fairy lights in it but ours aren't showing up well in my photo.Â  We had to thread white pompoms onto clear fishing twine to make the effect of the snow falling.Â  Sid was delighted when Granny found a remnant of green ric-rac for his lid. ğŸ˜‰Also in the book were these Christmas Pinecone Owls.Â  Luckily I had some pinecones in my woodshed so we made one of these as well but chose not to spray paint our pinecone.Â Â I've covered Connor's face as I don't have his Mums permission to put his photo on the internetSid had been asking for a friend to come so we invited Connor, a boy from his class & such a sweet delightful boy.Â  Together they made a range of characters using cardboard loo roll tubes.Â  I googled & foundÂ * this * wonderful site for ideas.Â  When I collected Sid from school this past week Connor came up to me in the playground & said "Granny - I've been saving my toilet roll tubes for the next time I come to your house".Â  What a perfect compliment ğŸ’™My lovely friendÂ Kiwikid SueÂ & her husband have been on a trip over to New Zealand & we arranged to meet up in Tirau for lunch.Â  I had wanted to give Sue a wee gift for her new (6 month old!!!) Grandson Finn - just a little handmade Kiwiana gift, so I sewed some bibs & a matching teething ring, then made a cat from a wool blanket in my stash.Â I pulled apart an old toy of Sid's & removed the rattle from inside it - then I stuffed the cat with the rattle inside & it sounded great.My friend Carolyn has been up for 2 weeks dog-sitting for her son while he was overseas.Â  Carolyn wanted a chalk painting & decoupage lesson so we organised a painting day together last Saturday.Â  She painted the thrifted tray & bowl above & then I showed her how to decoupage them using paper serviettes.Â  She plans to gift these two items filled with baking.Â I had been working on this old saw that had belonged to my Dad - I bought it home in March when I emptied out the family home.Â  The Saw was rusty so I sanded this off & then coated it with Fishoilene which I found in The Mr's shed.Â Unfortunately the Fishoilene was still sticky after 5 days of sitting the saw by the fire.Â  I googled "fishoilene still tacky" & it suggested sprinkling talcum powder over it to remove the stickiness.Â  I figured I had nothing to lose so I sprinkled it liberally with talc & then shook the rest off onto the grass.Â  This certainly did the trick & took away any sticky residue.Â  While Carolyn was painting her woodware I painted Dad's Saw - 2 coats of black chalkpaint.I wanted to gift the Saw to my Brother for his birthday - he is right into growing veggies but although I looked hard I could find no transfers or serviettes relating to this theme.Â  In the end I used offcuts of the Botanical transfer that I used onÂ * this box * & was really pleased with the end result.Â Â  I have sprayed the saw with two coats of clear matt finish varnish as I think this will protect it well.Â  I especially love the detail on the wooden handle & will give this a couple of coats of wax before I gift it to him next month.Â Â Little One is fine & dandy & living his life to the fullest ......He enjoys watching the birds out the dining room window as they eat the bread I toss to them.Â  We leave the door open for him to venture outside but he is still a little timid as yet & has only gone a handful of steps out.Â  Mind you, if you could see the face on the Ginger girl who guards the door, hissing, spitting & banging on the glass, you would think twice about venturing out too (!!!)Little One is fixated with the front-loading washing machine & spends a great deal of time watching it agitate round & round.Â  He is also absolutelyÂ obsessedÂ with the toilet ... the above funny appeared in my inbox this morning from The Mr. ğŸ˜A funny thing I've noticed that he does ... when I use my grumpy voice to him, shake my finger & say NoÂ - he squints his blind eye at me several times as if to say "Well I am incapacitated you know!"Â Dear Pippi & Blackie have not become friends with him as yet.Â  I live in hope but I think that the website I read that stated "it can often take 8 to 12 months" was probably referring to Our Household!Â  He has been in the household for 9 1/2 weeks now & for those that were wondering - Yes I am counting!!Â Â The photo of Blackie is especially for you Willie my friend ... notice noÂ leg-in-the-air today ğŸ˜‰Â Â Alec picked these few straggly daffodills yesterday when I had him here - we had really strong winds on Friday & these were almost flattened.Â  They make me feel that hopefully, spring is around the corner.Thank you, as always, for your ever-welcome visits here today dear friends,Wishing you all a Happy SundayÂ (I started this blog post 3 days ago now!!)With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: A June Recap
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersÂ Even though we are now well into July,Â  it's time for a bit of a June recap. (warning - rather photo heavy)We had a family day out to "the big smoke" of Auckland, New Zealand's largest city, about 2 hours north of us.Â  First we visitedÂ Kelly Tarlton's Underwater World.Â Â I last visited here when my 2 sons were aged 4 & 8 years old & my brother took us all as a treat.Â  I had been wanting to take my 2 Grandsons for awhile now as I felt they were really good ages to enjoy it.Â The boys both loved it so much & all agreed their favourite of all was the Penguin enclosure.Sid found a new friend ğŸ˜‰Eldest son taking photo is not in picNext we drove into Mission Bay & had an early lunch at the Bald Eagle Diner.Â  This was fun & then a walk along the beach front back to our vehicles.After lunch we visited the Auckland Museum & saw the Dinosaur Exhibition amongst other wonderful displays.Â  I took 98 photos of our day out so I have just tried to pick out a few special ones to share with you.I loaned my dear friend Claire a Simply Vintage Magazine - the same copy I used to make this primitive pumpkin..Â  When she posted it back she included "extras"The sweetest fabric pear & a matching miniature quilt in autumnal colours - she had sewn both items for me as a thank you for lending her the magazine.Â  Needless to say I have offered her several other copies Any Time She Likes!Â  ğŸ˜‰I completed an Order for my lovely friend Shirley for 4 lavender/lace coathangers along with some more Mothball sachets.Â  When I posted my Mothball sachet recipe on Instagram I received orders for 24 of them.I celebrated another birthday in June - 63 years around the sun! Happy Birthday to Meee!Â  We had a family tea celebration planned but had to postpone due to Alec developing Whooping Cough, so youngest son Kayne came to visit me after work with Sid.Â Â We managed to have our postponed pizza dinner last night & my daughter-in-law made me the most delicious carrot cake ğŸ’With some birthday money I treated myself to this expensive-but-gorgeous book above.Â  You can buy it in New Zealand from * Here *.Â  I drool over the pages & want to make EverythingÂ in it!When I cleared out Mum's house in early March I bought this old silver tray home with me - Mum used it to sit her toaster on for as long as I can remember.Â  I sanded the rust off,Â  chalk painted it & applied a sweet lavender transfer.Â Â It is school holidays here in New Zealand so I have been on Granny duties. I took both boys toÂ Extreme Edge Rock Climbing last Thursday & they had a wonderful time until it got super busy with other kids.They very much enjoyed the coin operated air hockey game.Â I let them choose where to go for lunch & of course they choose that old favourite McDonalds.Â  I didn't mind as I rather enjoy their fillet of fish burgers & fries.Â A Little One Update:Well I would love to tell you its all going tickety-boo but unfortunately it is Not.Â  Little One is fine & living his best life but Blackie & Pippi are most unhappy & they have not learnt to get along yet - it's over 6 weeks now.Â  Â I tried tough love the other day whereby I shut Little One in the cage above right, & shut Pippi in the same room so that they could get to know each other through the cage but it was traumatic & the most traumatised of all was Me!Â  Having said all that I didÂ read this onlineÂ (read the highlighted part)Â & realise it is still very early days. So I shall persevere & in the meantime, continue to eat chocolate (!!!) ğŸ˜Thankyou as always dear friends for stopping by today,Wishing you a wonderful week ahead - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the (3) furry ones x0x0x

title: L.B.L.O.  (Life Before Little One) ğŸ˜‰ ......  & an Update
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersLife is still very chaotic here at CatÂ CentralÂ Threadbear HQÂ but I realised I had not shared some projects that I'd finished before Little One came into our lives & tipped everything on its head !!Â The Mr sent this through to my inbox yesterday morning ... I did not laugh like once I would have ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜Before Little One I found an old wooden frame in my stash & chalk painted it off white.Â  I then framed the wonderful Certificate that Sid gave meÂ in * this Post *. It hangs on my sewing room wall ğŸ’—Before Little OneÂ I called to visit my friend Jane whom I hadn't seen in many months.Â  Jane was just about to list this gorgeousÂ vintage needlework picture on Trademe, an auction site here in New Zealand.Â  As luck would have it I was able to purchase it off her & I absolutely adore it!Â My photo is not really doing justice to the beautiful colours in this handwork piece.Â Before Little OneÂ I hauled this old wooden stool out of my sleepout. It was a $2 purchase from the Paws Animal Care op-shop.Â  I was originally going to just paint over the old vinyl top but in the end I removed all the staples & took it off.Â This was fortunate because the original foam padding had completely disintegrated & turned to dust.Â  I cleaned all this off with a scraper & gave the stool a good scrub with sugar soap.Â I gave the legs 3 coats of chalk paint in the colour Sage - the same colour I usedÂ on this small table.
