Â I gave the top 3 coats chalk paint - Vintage White which is really more of a cream.Â  Then I applied this White Cloud transfer.Â  Â I lightly sanded the whole thing as I wanted it to have a time worn appearance.Â  I will use this either as a plant stand or just a stool to put a cuppa on - these are always handy as little side tables.Â Â While still on the "$2 theme" I saw this wooden box on my last trip down to Mum's, in the Hospice Shop, sitting forlornly in the corner.Â  The first thing that popped into my head was "pansies" ...Â  I could visualise it planted with pansies.Once again, a good scrub & then two coats of a matt black testpot that I had in my stash. You can see I painted the inside well too.Â  Miss Pip used it in the interim as a sleeping box - then I added some of the leftover Botanical Transfers from * this * chest of drawers..Â  I waxed it really well both inside & out before lining it with a folded up black rubbish sack.Â  Â I forgot to add that I drilled 6 holes in the base for drainage.As originally planned, I planted it with a selection of 6 gorgeous flowering pansies - they are so pretty here in New Zealand this time of year.Â Â The reason I used the Botanical transfer was because I wanted to sit in on the chest of drawers that I'd previously upcycled out on my deck.Â  Many things that I sit on here blow off & I knew this was solid & weighty enough to withstand some wind.Â Â I am so pleased with how this turned out. I've put a piece of oilcloth underneath so that when I water it, it doesn't run over onto the wooden drawers.Â An Update on RascalÂ Little One ........Physically he is doing very well. On a trip to the Vet last Friday he was pronounced well enough to have his surgery (neutering). I don't know what they gave him but he came home bouncing off the walls & has not really stopped since.Â  He has finished all his antibiotics & even his blind eye is looking alot better.Â  He is livingÂ The Life of RileyHe is most fascinated with the fire & cannot understand it - our fire makes a noise as it has a fan fitted in it to blow the heat aroundNow that he has some confidence he is venturing further than the spare room ... there is much to explore in this house & different smells.Â  This is not always a good thing as I have to be vigilant with my other two cats.Â  Blackie takes not alot of notice but then he is gone most of the day to his favourite sleeping spots outdoors.Â  Miss Pip, being an indoor cat, has her nose most out of joint & I can't leave them alone as yet at all!Â This means not alot gets done.Â She is currently allowed to do things she would normally NOT be allowed to do ... such as sleeping in my underwear drawer (!!) ğŸ˜ŸÂ  (You may notice I managed to quickly tuck a cuddly rug down to save on cat hairs)Oh dearie me .... & on it goes . . . . . . . . . .My friend Elaine popped by for a visit last week & gifted me this beautiful bowl of Viola's - perfect colours for my deck table, & such a lovely surprise.Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - its mid winter here in New Zealand now & a bit gloomy,Sending much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones (3) x0x0x

title: The Tale of "Little One"
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI captured this stunning sunset last night from our deck area.Well my dear friends ... it would seem that - without even trying ... we appear to have become a three-cat-family ğŸ˜‰Let me tell you the tale of "Little One"(Yes named by The Mr - can't you tell !!)You can clearly see the glassy eye in this photo above - this is the one he is blind inHis pregnant Mum was dumped at the metal pit beside the farm that The Mr runs ... this is a frequent occurrence (cats being dumped) as the farm is at the end of a dead-end road, not very far from town - so they don't have to use much petrol to abandon their animals. ğŸ˜ Â  This infuriates me but that's not why we're here today.Â Â Pregnant Mum (black & white) made her way to the cowshed where The Mr feeds a motley crew of assorted previously-dumped cats.Â  The Mr always maintains "you either shoot them ... or you feed them but you never starve them".Â  I am inclined to agree with him.Â  Our small rural town no longer has an SPCA so there is nowhere to take these dumped cats & nobody wants them.Â Â Pregnant Mum gave birth to Little One & a black/white female kitten around Christmas time if my memory serves me correctly.Â  The Mr would sometimes send me photos of Little One & I remember saying I thought he had Siamese in him.Â  Always one eye was runny.Â  As time went on & he became very friendly The Mr decided he needed to get him neutered so off to the Vet they go.Â  The Vet checked him out thoroughly & informed The Mr they would not be doing the surgery as he had a nasty lung infection & an eye infection, as well as being born blind in one eye.Â  She also said he needed to be kept inside & given antibiotics & eye drops in order to recover properly or the lungs would never clear up.The first I knew of this was when The Mr arrived home & plonked the cat cage on my table ... what should we do??!! What a dilema ... we both shook our heads.Â  So The Mr said we'll try it for one night & see how it goes.Â It's a very stressful life here at Threadbear & sometimes we get tired from playing with the toys!!!Now let me be 100% honest here dear friends.Â  Â Do I want a 3rd cat? No I most certainly do not!!Â Somedays - I don't even want the two I've got !!!! (sorry Pip, sorry Blackie)Â But can I bear the thought of him living in the tractor shed in the cold & the damp with a lung infection?? No I cannot.Â Â And so we do the best that we can.He has certainly made himself right at Home in the spare bedroom & Yours Truly (myself)Â even found herself in a weak moment at the Variety Store last week - purchasing cat toys (!!!!) ğŸ˜–Back again to the Vets last Thursday for another check up (we're up to $397 currently) ... & although he is much better, he's still not well enough for an anaesthetic, so another weeks antibiotics.Â Â Oh my goodness ... how on earth did this happen I ask myself?!Â Unfortunately along the journey of caring for him - he has well & truly crept into my heart & I just adore him.Â Â The Mr informed me that several people had been to the farm to look at taking him but they all either wanted a female so they could breed from her ... or the weepy eye put them off.Â  Our new milkers took him home & he lasted one night before he escaped through a window & back up to the hay barn to his family.Â Â The minute I walk into the spare bedroom he gives a tiny squeak & starts to purr ğŸ’™And so - for now - Little One appears to be living here at Threadbear HQ - & what the future holds I am not too sure. I always said introducing another cat would upset the balance but we shall see what unfolds.Â  And while I am being honest here my friends ... No it is Not all cuteness & playing with toys - it is VeRy stressful & I find I feel anxious alot of the time & get very little achieved with endeavouring to keep everyone (3 cats)Â happy !!Â And what's a girl to do when her Mother does this despicable thing ... bringing in a strange-looking creature to the house?Â  Why take to her bed of course & while she's at it - sleep on one of the Good Cushions that she's usually Not allowed on ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜–I found some time over the weekend for a couple of creative pursuits ... my friend Sally had given me this gorgeous vintage fine lawn nightie in a toile pattern & asked me to make her some lavender bags from it.Â  I had enough of it to make a lavender sleep pillow too.Â  The sewing room smelt heavenly with the lavender fragranceÂ  ğŸ’œI made up another batch of Laundry Liquid over the weekend. I find a batch usually lasts me about a year ... I used the recipe in Rhonda's book below, which I refer back to all the time.Â  The vintage decanters have been thrifted over the years & I love filling them with the liquid but I keep a plastic milk bottle under my laundry sink to use daily so I can give it a really good shake first as the liquid can tend to gel.Â Â Thank you so very much for staying to the end dear friends,I am off to fill the wood basket again - a heavy frost here this morning & its taking some work to get the house warmed up.Wishing you all a wonderful rest-of-the-week,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones (all 3 of them !!!)

title: Welcome to June ğŸ’—
text: Greetings lovely friends & readers & Welcome to June ğŸ’—Officially the first month of Winter here in the Southern hemisphere.May it be a wonderful month for us all !Â I bought Mum this "Welcome Trough" many years ago from a delightful home-based business just south of me - Tomo Pots.Â  I bought it home with me when I cleared out her house & yesterday I filled it with water & floated some Camellia flowers in it - just like Mum used to do.I have been looking for a new rug to go in front of my fire for many months now.Â  The previous one came out of the Farm Owners house & was in tatty condition when I received it several years ago.Â  Â All the ones I looked at cost many hundreds of $$ but I was able to find one online that I liked (for only $85) & it arrived on Tuesday.Â Â I absolutely LoVe it & when my eldest son saw it he commented "it looks like it's a hundred years old".Â  How perfect!!!Â  Even Miss Pip gave it her seal of approval & she almost blended right in with the new rug!Â As I had two Orders for mothball sachets I made up another batch earlier this week.Â  These are wonderful to put in your yarn or your woolen clothing & keep the moths away without leaving that nasty lingering camphor smell.Â  I'll put the recipe at the end of my post today in case you would like to make some yourself.I had a baking day on Monday.Â  I made fruity cereal slice & a new-to-me banana bread recipe as I had a large bunch of bananas turning black.Â Â This is the new recipeÂ I used.Â  You can see from the photo above that my eldest son & Alec quickly demolished half of it, still warm from the oven.Dear Alec won Player of the Day for Soccer last Saturday & he was Oh so proud of his Cup & Certificate.My dear friend Sandy gave me some plants she no longer wanted & when I had planted them all I discovered this wooden cat under the layers of newspaper in the bottom of the banana box that the plants came in.I've forgotten to take a "before photo" but it was faded & chipped in a couple of places on the paw.Â  I had the matt black chalk paint out so I gave it a generous coat of paint & it came up beautifully.Â  Well what else could I write on it ... it IS their house & they very generously allow us to reside here too ğŸ˜‰I used to have a subscription to the Simply Vintage Magazine (4 issues per year) until I could no longer fit them in my bookcase & I cancelled it.Â  I still enjoy pulling them out to re-read from time to time.Â  This Issue No 8 is from 2013 & when I spotted this primitive pumpkin in it, I thought perhaps I could use up some of my autumn toned wool fabrics.It was simple & fun to make ... I used 8 different fabrics for the wedges in muted autumn tones.Â Â I stamped a tea-dyed tag & made some "curls" from a length of rusty wire.Â  Just wind the wire around a thick knitting needle & slip off.Â I had a pair of these silver plated candleholders ($1.50 for the pair) in my stash so I painted one with matt black chalk paint & it was just perfect for the base.Â  You are supposed to use the pumpkin as a scissor holder but I like mine just fine without scissors poked in the top.Â  âœ‚I have been continuing on with my dishcloth knitting - at nights when my eyes are tired. I am using up all my small oddments of cotton yarn & making scrappy ones.Â  This free patternÂ is still my preferenceÂ as I like a small sized dishcloth that I can squeeze out in one hand.Â Every now & again something happens that tugs right at your heartstrings.Â  This was the case yesterday when I attended my Grandson Sid's school Grandparents Day.Â  He very proudly presented me with this below & it bought big tears to my eyes.How fortuitous dear friends, that I just happened to be wearing my pink shirt & black pants that very day!Â  Please take note of my curly hair, my eye make-up & my slim body (!!!)Â  I shall be putting this in a frame in a special place.Â Thank you so very much dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you a wonderful (long) weekend - its King's Birthday Weekend here in New Zealand & the sun is actually out!Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0xHerbal Moth Ball Sachets:Â  50 grams dried Rosemary, 50 grams dried Mint, 50 grams dried Thyme, 25 grams Ginseng (tea), 200 grams whole Cloves.Â  Combine mixture & add to muslin bags.Â  I also add a large handful of dried lavender to mine.

title: Sewing, A Birthday, Painting & Slow Stitching ...........................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersIt has been another busy week with lots happening each & every day.A friend gifted me this gorgeous Cyclamen for pet feeding duties so I planted it in my vintage wrought iron chair ğŸ’— ... a splash of colour for the colder months hopefully.Last week I drove toÂ Tirau to meet up with a dear friend who was travelling North.Â  No trip to Tirau is complete without a visit to my favourite storeÂ My Style Â I knew I wanted to purchase some of their Cath Kidston fabric to make a new ironing board cover.Â Â I simply remove my old cover, pull the elastic out, lay it on my new fabric (60 cms) & cut around it, allowing enough to sew a casing.Â  The "helper" was unfortunately non-negotiable but she made a good weight to stop the fabric moving around ğŸ˜‰If I could give you one little hint then it would be to NOTÂ have a "helper" if possible, as they get tired, lie down on the job & sometimes even GO TO SLEEP!!! This makes removing your new piece of fabric from underneathÂ VeRy TricKy!WhenÂ yourÂ helperÂ wakesÂ upÂ againÂ you have sewn your casing, simply thread your elastic through & pop it on your ironing board.Â Â It is amazing how much pleasure that 60 cms of fabric brings & makes me want to actually DO the ironing!!Â That very same evening we had a Birthday Party to attend as Alec was turning 8!!The far right photo is just Alec pretending he has fallen to the groundThis year (for a change) his parents decided to hold his party at this venue in HamiltonÂ Extreme Edge Rockclimbing GymÂ & it was the most perfect place for 10 rowdy, energetic boys to run around & use up energy!Even Sid enjoyed it after his initial hesitation.Â  There are just so many wonderful themed climbing boards for children & they are harnessed in so it is very safe.Â Â If you have more than 8 children they give you a room to hold your party in ... which worked out so well.Â  We had pizzas followed by Chocolate Mud Birthday Cake ... then back to the climbing.Â Â Some readers may remember back in early March when I won this Anthurium PlantÂ in a Competition.Â  I loved it & it seemed to really thrive sitting on my table.Â  However I read online that the flowers are very toxic to cats & as mine are frequently on the table ğŸ˜• I thought I should move it & not risk anything.Â  I didn't think they'd eat the flowers but simply brushing against them could cause a nasty reaction.Â Â This pink stool above was in my woodshed (!!) - an old thrifted find. I sanded the marks on the top, washed it down well & then painted it with two coats of chalk paint "antique white".Â  I kept the wood showing on the legs & gave these a generous coat of wax ... I was delighted with how it turned out & now its well out of any furry friends reach.When I was down packing up Mum's house in early March, my dear friend Claire invited me to her home for a Stitching Evening.Â  There were 6 of us there - just a nice number.Â Â One of the girls, Joy, had bought along a box full of these vintage fabric packs.Â  Joy had purchased these fromÂ French Pear Vintage & as she had so many we were each able to buy a bundle if we wished.Â  They are called "lucky dip bundles" - you don't know what you are getting but they are antique french fabrics & linens that the lady imports.Â  The girls issued a challenge that we had "toÂ do something with our packs of fabrics".Mine came home with me & when I looked at them all I decided I wanted to make a project using ALL of them in one hit.I laid them out in a pleasing design, changing my mind over a couple of days regarding placement.Â  I decided to attach them to a piece of pre-washed calico which I cut to shape.Â  I machine stitched around some to fasten them & also dabbed a fabric glue pen under some.Â  Then I began to hand stitch across them, changing my direction as I worked my way across the rectangle - some horizontal, some vertical.I drew some of my lines with a Frixion Pen as I am inclined to be wonkyI think it would be fair to say I enjoyed this mindless slow stitching so very much that I found myself driving to pick Sid up from school half an hour earlier so I could sit & stitch some lines in the car while waiting.Â Â I just used a roll of thickish embroidery thread that I had thrifted once-upon-a-time & really liked the effect of this thread.Â  I had 3 pieces left over from my bundle, 2 green & one white ... so I stitched these to a square of calico that I planned to use as my backing.My original plan had been to make this piece into a table runner but somewhere along the way it became a cushion.Â  A sort of French Country looking cushion.Â  I finished putting it together at the weekend & made a large inner for it from an old pillow I had bought home from Mum's.Â  I like my cushions stuffed nice & tightly.Â Â I am really thrilled with my new cushion & I think I might be rather addicted to this slow stitching as I'd now like to make a table runner.Â  I wasn't sure about leaving my raw edges but now I really like this effect on my cushion.Thank you all so very much for your visits here today dear friends,It feels like its going to be a cold night here at Threadbear HQ so I am off to fill the wood basket,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Before,  During & After ........................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWelcome to another shiny new month ... May !!Image from "scraps of us" blogI have been away down to see my Mum again & returned just in time last week as the road was closed due to another big slip.- Before -Â Thank you all for your sweet kind commentsÂ in my last post about my new seating area with Mum's mohair blanket/new cushions.Â  I had hardly hit PublishÂ on my post when I walked into the room to discover a certain 4-legged Princess had tossed the cushions on the floor & decided the mohair rug was quite cosy for Her Royal Highness thank you very much!!I usually try not to light our fire until the month of May.Â  This year however (in late April) I came inside from gardening one afternoon & decided it was jolly well freezing in my house ... so I pulled my pinecones out & lit it promptly.Â  It never takes the ginger one long to find the heat.Â  It will burn now until October as our seasons have changed so much & our springs can be very cold & wet.Before I headed down to see Mum I had some birthday gifts to make.Â  I wanted to make candles for my friend Carolyn & also my sister in law.Â  The crystal glassware was out of Mum's china cabinet so I thought it would be special to make candles to gift to my sister in law in these.Â  The fragrances are Orange, cinnamon & clove, & smelt wonderful.In our first Lockdown of 2020 I purchased a punnet of Zinnia Dahlia plants that were not much bigger than my smallest fingernail.Â  I lovingly nurtured them along until they grew large enough to plant out in my garden.Â  They grew into the most stunning flowers & each year I remember to collect the heads so I can save the seeds for the following year.Â  I had pressed some of the flower heads under heavy books so I made up some fancy seed packets to gift to my friend Carolyn, whom I visited on the way down to see Mum.Â Â Prior to my trip away The Mr came home with this wooden mirror he had picked up in his travels for $20.Â  It had obviously come off a stand as it had brackets on each side.Â  Before painting I glued on some efex rubber mouldings to try & tizzy it up a bit.As you can see I originally started off painting it my usual Vintage White colour but then changed my mind & decided to try a new-to-me colour ... "Linen".Â Â I loved the finished colour but decided the scrolls needed something to make them "pop".Â  After the numerous YouTube videos I watch I thought some white wax might be the answer ... problem was I had No white wax.I decided to make my own version simply by mixing a tablespoon of clear wax with some white chalk paint & stirring well.Â  It did the trick wonderfully for the small area I wanted it for.Â  I find if you clear wax the scrolls first, then whatever you apply afterwards will always wipe off easily if you don't like it.Â Â Love, love my new (old) mirror & the colour is a gorgeous mix of brown & grey undertones, just like the raw linen I am stitching on at present.Â Â - During -My brother & sister in law decided to go away for a few days to celebrate her 65th birthday.Â  I offered to house sit for them & look after their animals as it gave me a chance to visit Mum & also free accomodation now Mum's house has sold.Â  I had planned to take lots of photos but my time away was just so busy that I barely picked up my phone.Â Each evening I lit the fire & their elderly (deaf) dog Bella comes in at night & sleeps by it.Â  I had hoped to stitch but the cat in my lap was originallyÂ Mum's cat Bubby & she rather liked my lap.Â Â View from the bottom of the driveway ... & then from the top - out to an oil rig at sea.My brother owns 40 acres & their house sits way up on the top of a hill with amazing views in every direction (but also lots of wind).Â Longtime readers of my blog will remember the fence my brother built by hand inÂ this postÂ & also inÂ this postÂ - my brother only has one arm after a motorbike accident when he was young.Â He has now built himself a Hothouse - it had to be built really strongÂ to withstand the winds that they get up on the hill.Â  It was incredible & filled with a large variety of plants already even though he is just getting it underway.Â  Â Â While I was away my lovely friend Claire invited me to a Pink Ribbon morning tea - this is a fundraiser for Breast Cancer that they hold each May.Â  We had the most delicious cooked breakfast ... & while at the Venue I took some raffle tickets & managed to win a prize.This lovely wooden bread board & a set of 4 wooden coasters.Â Â - After -Â Once home again I got Sid to decorate 2 of the coasters - one each for his parents.Â  He did a lovely job of them & I sprayed each one with 3 coats of clear matt varnish to make them wipeable.Â  I'll get Alec to decorate the other 2 for his parents.Â Â While Sid was in hospital I took him an Easter colouring competition that I'd cut out of our local newspaper.Â  He coloured this in & upon his return home I dropped it in to the venue running the competition - a local Real Estate Agency.Â  Sid was delighted when they rang to say he had won his age group so I was able to take him in to collect his prize - a $50 gift voucher from a local bookstore/toy shop!!Â Â The fragrance is Baked Pear - just divine !I called into Brandy's Botanicals while away as I needed to drop in some dried lavender ... I purchased this beautiful set of fragrant tealite candles & am burning one today in my crystal candle jar.Phew - well done if you've made it all the way to the end!!Thank you so very much dear friends, for visiting here today,I hope the coming week is good & kind to all of you,With much love & friendship to you all,Love Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Mr P. Cottontail Rabbit  . . . . . .  & Displaying Some of Mum's Treasures
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAlthough I have packed all my Easter decor away now, I did manage to finish off this rabbit which I started onlyÂ 12 short months ago!!!Â Â His name is P. Cottontail Esquire & he is designed by Lyn Hosford.For his tailored Jacket I used the wool fabric from a man's blazer that was purchased from the Op Shop quite sometime ago.Â  I often pick these up when I see them going cheaply as the wool fabric is wonderful to use in projects.His personalised wooden key is purchased fromÂ * here *Though the pattern states to dunk his body in a "dye bath mix" to stain it, I could not bear to do this ... I much preferred my Gentleman rabbit in pristine condition.Â Here he is besides Miss Maggie Rabbit which I madeÂ way back in 2019!The pattern is from the book Meadow Threads byÂ The Need'l Love CompanyI hauled a comfy lounge chair over closer to my French doors for the winter time.Â  It gets lovely afternoon sun here & is a nice spot to sit & look outside in the wintery months.Â  Amongst Mum's treasures I had bought back this soft pink mohair throw & I draped this over the chair.Â  My friend Jane had gifted me a beautiful Cath Kidston tea-towel last birthday, commemorating our late Queen's Platinum Jubilee.Â  I decided to make it up into a rectangular cushion for my chair.Â  Jane had also gifted me the beautiful piece of Sanderson Linen & this became a cushion also.Â  Â I thought they looked so pretty on the pink throw & they only took a couple of hours to sew up.Â  Often I pick up cushion inners when I am thrifting & tuck them away for projects like this.Â Â An inviting spot to sit with a cuppa ... I just need to make sure I actually do this!There is a round occasional table next to my chair & I displayed Mum's glass cake stand on it along with some pretty floral china my friend Sandy had gifted me.Â  When I do new little vignettes like this, it encourages me to pull everything out & it all gets a good clean & a vaccum & I like to oil/polish my wooden furniture.Â  Â Â A small ribbon-rose embroidered cushion that I gifted to Mum many years ago now ğŸ’I was with Mum when she purchased this sweet little Oak tableÂ way back in 2014.Â  She needed something to display photographs on & this was perfect.Â  I've always loved the heart shaped legs on it so home it came with me.Â  Mum's Crown Lynn Swan displayed on the lower shelf. (would you believe dear readers - Mum used the Swan to hold her toilet cleaner & loo brush !!!)This Oak Canteen holds Mum's silver cutlery set.Â  She had always said she wanted me to have this so I have sat it on top of the Oak table & popped a small display on top.Â  Looking at the brass tray in this photo - I really must tryÂ the tomato-sauce method on this!!!The sweet lace cloth cames from Mum's alsoJust a little corner of my home ... & makes me think of Mum when I look at her treasures around me.Â  There are still lots more to sort through yet dear friends, but I am trying to deal with a few things each week.Â Â Sid came twice last week & wanted to do "arts & crafts".Â  I save loo roll tubes for him but he also goes through my Recycling bin & pulls out any cardboard boxes etc that he wants.Â  He happily crafts & builds junkÂ contraptions for hours! He LoVeS cellotape & goes through rather-a-lot !!! ğŸ˜‰I got up early this morning & cleaned out my Fridge.Â  I then tossed all the left over veggies into a Fridge Drawer stew.Â  This will hopefully feed us for 3 nights & smells very comforting cooking away in the Crock Pot.Â Â There is a cold Southerly wind blowing here today & Madam Pip has her banana box inside the houseÂ with a fresh wool blanket.Â  Blackie is tucked up in the hallway cupboard sitting on the ironing pile (!!!) ğŸ˜.Â  The Mr informs me we are in for cold temps tonight.I hope you are warm & cosy where-ever you are dear friends,Thank you as always, for your welcome visits here today,With much love & friendship to you All,Love Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Easter Decorating Threadbear Style   .............................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAs I began packing away my Easter decorations this morning I realised I had not yet shared them on here.I really LoVe Easter decorating - I love all the soft pastels & I really enjoy that it can all be bought out in a day & then packed away again in a couple of hours, unlike Christmas decor that seems to take me days & days.Â I have a vintage Singer Sewing table in the corner of my dining room that I like to decorate for the seasons.Â  This is my display on here - nothing new this year, just re-using the same decor from previous Easters.Â  Â Raggedy Rabbit madeÂ * here *Â Same table - different endThis is the small nest of tables that I decoratedÂ * here *Â . New items are the Girl Statue that I paintedÂ * here * & a pink Easter sign gifted from my friend Sally last year.Â I bought this little shelf in from my Cottage - I have a new piece here ... the china rabbit plate purchased on saleÂ from * here * about a month ago.Â Raggedy Heirloom Rabbit made by meÂ * here * & knitted rabbit from Mum'sMy mantlepiece is decorated pretty much the same as last Easter with no new items.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  A small occasional table with some Easter items from last yearThe rabbit trinket box is new - again purchased on saleÂ from * here * but turned out much larger than I imagined - one of the downfalls of online buying I guess.Â  Â The moss rabbits are both op-shop finds.A small primitive display on another table - nothing new here ... wool rabbit madeÂ * here *Â ... cross stitch cushion madeÂ * here *This wooden egg was a 50 cents op-shop purchase sometime last year. I found it when I unpacked my Easter decor & decided to give it a coat of white chalk paint.Â  It had some tatty lace glued around the middle which I pulled off first & sanded lightly.Â Â I had purchased the decoupaged wooden rabbit from my friendÂ Joy when I was last down at Mum's.Â  I found the very same serviette Joy had used in my stash, so I decoupaged the egg with it.Â  I just love how this turned out & would never have thought to use browns & greys in my Easter decor had I not seen Joy's rabbit.Â  ğŸ¤ğŸ–¤This one is especially for you dearÂ Willie ...... when Blackie got wind of the idea that I was Easter decorating he decided to bring me my very OwnÂ Easter Bunny!!!Â Â  He was not at all impressed when I shooed him away with it.Â I sewed a baby gift over Easter - 2 bibs & a wool blanket rabbit.Â  My dear friend Sandy is flying to Canada to visit her new grandaughter so I wanted to send a little Kiwiana gift as Sandy's son & my youngest son were very good friends during their schooling years.Â Â I spent a couple of days with Alec this past week.Â  The first day we went to the Variety Store (Pokemon cards!!), Cafe for morning tea, the Space Centre & then the Movies in the afternoon.Â  On day 2, I decided we should drive over toÂ Raglan & we had a delicious fresh fish lunch at the Wharf Cafe.Â After lunch we went to the beach & Alec found a trowel so he dug for crabs.Â  He found 8 which he played with for awhile before Granny made him put them back in the water & we had an icecream before heading home.Â  It was a wonderful couple of days but I was rather shattered at the end.Â  Next week I'll be having Sid as it's school holidays here in New Zealand.Thank you dear friends, as always, for your welcome visits here today,Wishing you a wonderful week ahead - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Sid's Sixth Birthday (!!) ğŸ’—
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersSid's 6th birthday is one we will all remember for a very long time ... & for all the wrong kinds of reasons.After I made the Pokemon Mew toys for Sid & Alec in * this post *, Sid requested aÂ Gengar character to be made.Â  I managed to finish it just in time to wrap up for his 6th birthday.Â  These toys are a free download available fromÂ * this * amazing site!Â Sid's birthday gifts were all wrapped up ready & waiting for his party of which he was So excited about!Â Â  Unfortunately the very day before his birthday he became most unwell & ended up being admitted to hospital & having to undergo many tests & scans to determine why he had so much pain in his neck & body.Â The photo above left is poor Sid on his 6th birthday - in alot of pain & not happy at all.Â  The following day the Dr's decided that the antibiotics they were giving him intravenously were not working & they needed to do surgery to drain the large cyst that was appearing inside his neck.Â  The photo above right is dear Sid, trying to manage a smile right after a very long surgery.Â  He was such a trooper - the Dr's said it was a large cyst to drain but they were confident they got it all cleaned & flushed out.The following week passed by in a blur of travelling to the hospital each day to visit Sid, keep him entertained & also try to offer some support to his parents who were having a very difficult time of it all.Â  I did colouring in with him & read him stories - just whatever it took to pass the hours away & distract him from all the IV lines in him.Â Â Several days after surgery when he was showing some improvement we were allowed to go upstairs to the craft room!Â  This Granny thought that was just wonderful & Sid created the "tower" above right.Â  Look at all those dollies on the windowsill (left hand pic) - I badly wanted us to dress/decorate one but Sid was not interested.Â Finally - the day of Sid's Mum's birthday - he was allowed home again.Â  The day we thought would never come!!!Â  It was so good to see him happy to be back in his familiar surroundings again.Â Though I had grand plans for some Easter creations, this was all I managed this year.Â  The felt bunnies are a free pattern from * here *.Â  I made the chocolate & banana muffins to use up bananas that were turning brown & added some frosting to them with a smallÂ Lindor Egg in the top - these were a big hitÂ  ğŸ°As my Grandsons mainly wanted Pokemon cards this Easter, I packaged up a bag of small treats for them each including the felt bunnies & some other fun bits & bobs.Â Â Does my Bum look big in this ???Â I decided to make up a gift basket for my daughter in law's birthday. I knew I had a nice wooden crate in my cottage so I bought it inside & popped some tissue paper in the bottom while I sorted out my gifts to go in it.Â  No sooner had I gone to do this than a certain ginger furry being decided to try to fit her rather ampleÂ proportions in the crate!!!Â Â Finally I removed both cat & ginger hairs & made up my gift basket.I also made Nicole a chocolate cake & decorated it with candles as I remembered Sid had not gotten to blow out any candles for his birthday.Â  I managed to rescue the last of my pom-pom dahlias to go with the cake.And then this very morning I got to spend some time here with Sid while his parents caught up on some things. The first thing he wanted to do was "arts & crafts" so we had a wonderful morning making things at my table .................... until a certain black T-Rex decided to plonk himself down in the middle of all our craft supplies !!Speaking of contrary cats ... I bought out the banana boxes a couple of weeks ago as it's turned chilly here now. I lined each one with an old flannelette sheet.Â  Blackie wasted no time in curling up in one & then I noticed Madam Pip had joined him, so I dragged out the 2nd box.Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â This was the scenario that followed .........Â Â For two days they both slept in the back box & since then they've both been in the front box together.Â  I am not even going to try to figure them out !!!! ğŸ˜Wishing you all a wonderful Easter break dear friends,Â  ğŸ’•Thank you so much for your ever-welcome visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Catching up Post (Part 3) .... Clearing out No 44
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersThis post is written mainly as a record for myself, my sons & grandsons ... & I acknowledge it may be of no interest to anyone else.Â  But I wanted to keep a record of clearing out my family home,Â  as I have a tendency to forget ğŸ˜‰Winter Pansies planted in my old trike just yesterdayÂ  ğŸ–¤I was down at Mum's house for 2 weeks emptying it out & cleaning it ready for settlement on March 10th.Â  The new Owner was purchasing it as a rental property & I wanted it presented as "move in ready".Â  Â Â Â I first came to live at No 44 when I was aged 1 so I had 61 years of memories tied up in the house & large section.Â  I expected to feel all sorts of emotions the day I drove away for the final time but I did not feel one iota of sadness whatsoever.Â  Which surprised me to be honest.Â  Â I felt incredible sadness for my Mum who was lying in bed in a Resthome, just 6 doors away from the house she had lived in for the bulk of her 93 years of life.Â  The morning of settlement I had walked up to visit Mum as I did twice daily, & she had been very frail & incoherant.Â  So I felt a deep sadness over my Mum but certainly not over leaving the property.Â My brother had sold quite a bit of Mum's furniture on Facebook Marketplace prior to my arrival so this was my little set-up in Mum's lounge, where I sat for my meals & to do a bit of knitting or reading in the evenings.Â  A cane chair borrowed from my sister in law & a banana box for a side-table. There was nothing else left in the lounge room but this worked just fine.My brother & I had to be ruthless when it came to Mum's furniture & possessions.Â  We both have small homes & each have houses full of furniture already.Â  So many, many loads went to the 2 Charity Shops that Mum liked - SPCA & Hospice.Â  I kept some things that had sentimental value but even then I was ruthless.Â  Some things I bought home were simply because I could not bear the thought of them going to an Op-shop.Â  Like Mums wedding dress for example - like I would ever fit into it in a zillion years !!! But I kept it.I certainly do Not need more sewing supplies but I kept Mum's sewing basket (which she made herself) & needlecase, which my Dad sewed himself when he went into the armed services & they all had to make one.Â Â Â This mohair bear was made by myself a year after Dad died - the pattern is "Old Boy" & that's what Mum used to call Dad.Â  The Granny bear I made for Mum after she fell in love with the pattern - I did not knit the cabled twinset - this was knitted by Mum in very fine wool.Â  Before her eyesight deteriorated Mum was an exquisite knitter.I have been working on a few revamps of some things I bought home & you can expect to see more over the coming months as I slowly sort my way through things.Â  This table above was "donated to a mate" by my brother, & I promptly undonated itÂ & hid it in my car.Â  It was made from an offcut of formica many years ago & used as a bedside table in Mum's spare bedroom.I chalk-painted it with cream & then used a lovely green on the top called "Pale Sage".Â  Just to take the plain-ness off a bit, I added a stencil in the same colour as the legs.Â  I gave it a light distress & a wax & it is just THE perfect size.Â This concrete statue had sat in Mum's laundry for many years.Â  She had a broken neck as you can see above (cracked right through).Â  Â She was also a dirty pale lemon in colour.Â Â I filled the cracked neck with some strong adhesive, left it to harden & then chalk painted her in cream.Â  I love how she has come out & you would never know she'd had a broken neck!The two silver trays above had Australian maps etched into them.Â  Mum used to feed her neighbors cat whenever she went to Australia & these were bought back as thank-you gifts.Â  The larger one had rust spots on it which I sanded off.Â  I cleaned them well & then chalk painted them in cream - I really loved the floral edging on them both.Â Then I applied a couple of the left-over transfers from Juno's rabbit suitcase in my last post.Â  I added hangers to the backs & these are now part of my Easter displays.Â Â This cutting board had seen alot of use but I loved the shape of it.Â  Once again painted in cream & then transfers applied.Â  I really like how this turned out too.I hope to share some of my Easter decorating in my next post. ğŸ°ğŸ‡Last week I dug an entire tray of worm castings into my raised veggie gardens along with lawn clippings & some compost.Â  I dug them over well & then planted 6 punnets of winter veggies - silverbeet, spinach, broccoli x 2, cauliflower & baby cabbage. I saw cauli's in my supermarket last week for nearly $10 each !!!While I was outdoors working I picked my gourd harvest.Â  These are one of my most favourite things to grow as it's always a lucky dip what shapes & colours you get.Â  I decided to do some autumn decorating on my deck table as I'd given it a good clean out there.I washed my gourds & displayed them in my vintage scales .. I am not usually an orange-&-yellow-fan but I just loved these rich warm colours for autumn.Â  ğŸ’›ğŸ§¡While at the Garden Centre buying my veggie punnets I noticed these celosia plants in autumnal colours so a punnet of those went in my trolley & the Kalanchloe plants were on special so I grabbed one of those too.Love, love my new display .... & not a cat in sight (Yet!!) ğŸ˜‰ğŸ±Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,I am all caught-up now & hope to continue blogging more regularly.Wishing you a wonderful rest of the week - be kind to yourselves & to each other,Sending much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Catching Up Post  (Part 2)   -  a Rabbit Suitcase for Juno & a Pattern Request
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersSometime last year my lovely friendÂ Leeanne gifted me 2 of these suitcases covered in cat paper.Â  She said I might like to "Julie-afy" them at some stage.Thinking about my step-grandaughter Juno & her rabbit obsession I decided to re-vamp one into a rabbit suitcase for her.Â  Her birthday is just after Easter so I thought it could be an Easter/birthday gift combined.Â Firstly I painted it using my left-over chalk paint in the colour Soft Duck Egg.Â  I love this particular shade. I embellished it with some rabbit transfers purchased fromÂ * here *These are the same range of transfers that I used on Juno's table & chair setÂ way back here & then the chair I did for her new baby sisterÂ in * this post *I added some to the inside of the lid also.Â  Then I sprayed it all in clear laquer to make it wipeable.Â Originally I had planned to just re-vamp the suitcase for her but then I thought "why not make a rabbit to go inside ?"So this little girl came to life using a free Tilda pattern from * here *.Â  I even dressed her in some vintage Tilda rabbit print fabric from my stash.Â Then I thought to myself "all good rabbits need some food" ... so I made a couple of felt carrots that made The Mr laugh rather too loudly when I showed him ğŸ˜‰ ...Â  & a bag to carry her carrots in.Â Just right ! ğŸ’™ ğŸ¥•ğŸ¥•When I sat my rabbit in her suitcase, she kind of rattled around a bit ... so I thought perhaps she needs a little bed?Â  I found some sweet rabbit-print flannel fabric in my stash & fashioned her a mattress & a pillow to fit in her suitcase - nice & comfy & squishy, just how good rabbits like it!Â  ğŸ°ğŸ‡I sewed a simple sheet for her & tucked her in all snug ğŸ’•Then I thought "every good rabbit needs a quilt for her bed"... so I made her a quilt using this gorgeous Peter Rabbit fabric.Â  I made it reversible so the print is on both sides.Â  Juno's rabbit looked so cute tucked up in her bed ........ but perhaps a teeny bit lonely ???Â  She needs a wee friend I thought ........I knew exactly what pattern I would use! I receive an online newsletter fromÂ Swoodson Says & she has a free felt rabbit download if you subscribe to her newsletter.Â  This is only 2.5 cms tall & Soo sweet.Finally I was happy with my suitcase, my rabbit ... & her friend.Then just last week this cute wooden swing tag arrivedÂ from * here *Â - just the perfect finishing touch.Â  I need to gift this to Juno asap as I cannot stop myself from playing with it & every time I show it to a friend the first thing they say isÂ Â Oh I want one too !!I have a pattern request please dear readers ... if anyone has this book could they please contact me at stitchedbyjulie@hotmail.comÂ  I am actually only after the cushion pattern & will happily pay postage & photocopying costs.Â Â Thank you so much & thanks, as always - for stopping by here today.I think I have one more catch-up post & then I am all caught up!!! ğŸ˜ŠWishing you a wonderful rest-of-the-week & sending love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Catching Up Post (Part 1) - Back From Mum's
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have returned from packing up my Mum's home for sale, & settlement went through last Friday.Â  To say it felt like a marathon would Not be exaggerating.Â  I think I ran on adrenalin the whole time & now that I am home again I have somewhat folded in a heap.Â  But time to catch up on some blogging as I have lots I have not shared over the past couple of months & I want to visit you all & catch up on your posts.Â Somewhere along the way, summer disappeared & Autumn crept on the scene ... here in the Waikato we have been having the most stunning autumn days & I just LoVe them.Â Â I subscribe to a free online gardening newsletter & every week they run a competition.Â  I mostly always enter as the prizes are all garden-related items.Â  I completely forgot I'd entered one for Valentines Day to win a stunningÂ Anthurium PlantÂ ... often called the Flamingo Flower with its heart shaped leaves. I got such a surprise when my post lady delivered this tall box to my door.Â  Just delightful ğŸ’—Â Prior to my trip south I managed to complete a large Order which I hand-delivered toÂ Brandys BotanicalsÂ ... 6 embroidered Lavender-&-Linen hearts, 12 bags Cottage Garden Potpourri, Citrus potpourri filled teapots & wire hearts, & 8 Vintage Teacup Birdfeeders.Â  My car smelt rather lovely on the long drive down.Â On one of my past trips down I came across the sweetest little tray in a Gift Shop in Stratford.Â  It was glass with the daintiest rose gold feet & I adored it but I did not adore the price tag of $90.00!!Try as I might I could not justify spending that amount on something just to sit things upon.Â This vintage brass tray above was $3 in the SPCA Op-shop - I originally thought it was a frame.Â  I decided to get a piece of glass cut to fit & the Glass framers were able to straighten the wonkiness of it a teeny bit for me which was wonderful.Â Â When I tried to polish it with Brasso nothing happened.Â  I googled how to clean brassÂ & it said to use Tomato Sauce!Â  Surely they were dreaming?? But it was worth a try so away I went with my sauce bottle ... believe me dear friends - It Works!!Â I took the above photo because I thought you would surely Not believe me!Â  Apparently the acid in the tomatoes reacts with the metal & cleans it.Â Â I am so in love with the dainty brass bows on each end of the trayI was delighted how shiny it came out & hardly any elbow grease required.Â  I told The Mr if all else failed we can always dip our hot chips in it !!! ğŸ˜‰I have used it to display some vintage crystal on my bedroom chest of drawers - some of these items came from Mum's & I just love this little display so much.Â Â Very pretty & I am now eyeing up other brassware around my house with my tomato sauce bottle in my hand ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜Šthese are the items you start with above - a flattened tin, & a paper servietteÂ Early last year I won a draw on Instagram for a chalk-painting class with my friend Joy fromÂ The Joy Within.Â  I had booked in for a class 4 timesÂ but had to keep cancelling due to Mum-related issues that kept popping up.Â  Finally 2 Saturday's ago, I was able to actually attend.Â  I wanted to make one of Joy's famousÂ squished tins.I painted my tin a pale cream colour & then decoupaged on this delightful Easter Rabbit serviette using mod-podge.Â  Joy also gets you to decorate a tag to match your tin.Â Â Upon my return home, I styled my tin with some faux Easter eggs ... I scrunched up tissue in the bottom to prop them up a bit more.Â Â Joy encouraged me to try decorating the base that gets cut out of the tin ... I chose a different serviette for this piece.Â  Each class participant goes in the draw to win a decoupaged heart & my name was drawn out.Â  I won the beautiful blue heart above right. The "rules"Â  are that you must gift the heart to someone so it was perfect to gift to my dear friend Carolyn who drove an hour to help me clean Mum's house & worked like a Trojan.Â Oh how I missed these two during the fortnight I was gone.Â  And Yes here they are asleep on the good quilt & the good cushions - I have made a pathetic attempt to cover the quilt with a cotton sheet but not succeeded especially well ğŸ˜•Thank you all so very much for your visits here today,I hope to get back to blogging a bit more regularly ... more than once a month hopefully ğŸ˜ŠI hope the week is treating you kindly dear friends,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Struggling to Blog  ..................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have been away down to my Mum's for quite sometime & upon my return I'veÂ been struggling to blog.Â  Â  I received a phone call from the Resthome to say Mum had deteriorated (again) so I drove immediately down there.Â  Mum has slightly improved but she will not get properly well again now & is very frail.Â  I knew I needed to sell the family home this year in order to continue paying for Mum's Care so when the neighbours approached me about their daughter buying it, I didn't hesitate.Thus began the looooong process of sorting & clearing out 60 plus years of stuff.Â  I have been home a couple of weeks now but will return next week to finish up & stay on for settlement.Â Â Every time I would sit at my computer to write a blog post - the words just wouldn't come - so I would walk away.Â  Since my return I have not been idle & have found some creative moments in amongst catching up on everything around here.Â  While at Mum's I took 5 bootloads to the Hospice Op-Shop.Â  I have a large vehicle so they were certainly NOT small loads.Â  Even so, I still bought some treasures home with me ... my Dad's old paintbrush was one of them.Â  It was hanging on the hook in his shed where he always hung it.Â  I can still see myself, probably aged about 5 or 6 looking up at it & asking him why he hung that one there?Â  "Because it's my favourite brush" he said.Â  Â I'm sure I've mentioned before that my Dad was a Painter & Paperhanger for all the years that he was my Father.The "before" on the left ... I stripped it using the Oven Cleaner method that I have seen on YouTube.Â  It took a couple of applications but eventually got rid of the layers of old paint. I had to sand it a little bit & then I just wiped it with furniture oil.Â  I used a wire brush to clean the bristles out as much as I could.I love vintage tools hanging on the wall so I've hung it in my dining room where I can enjoy looking at it.Â Â Another couple of "before pics".Â  These wall sconces were in my sleepout ... they were Op-shop purchases from awhile ago, & I decided it was high time to do something with them!!I cleaned them both before giving each a couple of coats of chalk paint in the colour Pumice.Â  I also stripped all the wiring out as both of them no longer worked.I'veÂ hung the single one on my dining room wall where it matches some frames I'veÂ painted.Â  I purchased 3 plain candles from The Warehouse & glued lace around the bottoms to "tizzy them up a bit". These sit quite sturdily on the sconce bases although I'm not sure I will be lighting them.The double one is hanging in my lounge room.Â  I also rubbed each one with a tiny bit of silver gilding wax just to bring out the detailing in them.Â  So happy with my wall sconces ğŸ’•If you had told me that I would spend 2 solid days sitting at my work-table making Pokemon toys, I would've told you that you were quite insane!!!Â  However, that is what I did last week as Cyclone Gabrielle raged around us here.Â  Fortunately we didn't lose power although the Mr had no power at the farm to milk the cows.Â Â This is a free pattern from this amazing website.Â  I showed Sid these free patterns last year & he asked for a black Mew Plush.Â  When I showed Alec he asked for the same.Â Â I'd like to say they were enjoyable to make but they certainly did "test my sewing skills".Â  ğŸ˜‰I used plush fur for the bodies & felt for all the eye details.Â  Some hand embroidery in parts also.Â  The feet & hands were all needle sculpted.Â Â I think the trickiest part was probably the long curly tail ... wiring & stuffing that very nearly sent me over the edge.Â  But Mew is famous for his long curly tail so I persevered.Â Â Luckily I had Blackie to talk me through the trickiest bits.Â My two grandsons were absolutely thrilled with their Pokemon toys & Sid has now requestedÂ a Gengar PlushÂ ğŸ˜While I was down at Mum's I worried that my veggie garden would dry out but luckily we had plenty of rain.Â  I am picking courgettes & tomatoes each day & giving lots away.Â  This is yesterday's pick above.Â Â And the dishcloth knitting continues as I work my way through all my oddments of cotton yarn. I knowÂ * this dishcloth pattern * off by heart now so I can sit & knit it without thinking too much.Â  I find working on these quite therapeutic in the evenings at Mums when it is so quiet.Â Â Well there you go - I actually managed a blog post.And if you stopped by for a visit then Thank You SoÂ Much!I hope to get back to regular blogging soon dear friends, & also to visiting you all over at your blogs again too.Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry Ones x0x0x0

title: Some Post-Christmas Finishes  ..................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAlthough I had the bestÂ of intentions, December seemed to go by so very fast & I did not manage to complete all that I had hoped.Â  Â  Â  Â Â But that's okay - that's what these slow after-Christmas-early-New-Year-days are for.Â This cloth doll has sat, unclothed, on my Sewing Room floor for two years now - under a pile of fabric & other unfinished items.Â  It was high time I dressed the poor girl !!Â She is a VeryÂ Old PatternÂ by Wendy Briggs of Country Friends, who stopped designing several years ago now.Â Â She is called Christmas Angel & I adore her. ğŸ’—I had purchased a gorgeousÂ Lynette Anderson fabric a couple of years ago so finally I made her skirt. The wings are from a scrap of Sandcastle fabric that I had just enough of.Â I had left some greenery out when I packed away my Christmas decor so I made her a twig wreath & then a garland for her hair.Â  I embellished her with some wooden buttons fromÂ Theodora CleaveÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Painted shoes & torn strips for bows.Â Â Once finished I decided she needed a frame to hang in - like the one in the pattern.Â  I had the perfect size frame with chicken mesh on it but it was too olive-y green in colour so I painted it with my pale duck egg chalk paint.Â Yes - of courseÂ - I had the usual ginger assistant who is currently sporting several smudges of Pale Duck Egg on her ginger fur ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜(I have left my Angel out for awhile longer to enjoy, before I pack her away til next Christmas)I wanted to make some new cushion covers for the old cane chairs on my back deck area - this is a nice place to sit out in the afternoons with a cuppa & the old chairs are very comfy.Â  I removed the old covers & found the inners to be still in very good condition.Â  I wanted something Vintagey lookingÂ so I hunted in my stash & found an old table cloth with big blowsy roses on it - just perfect ğŸŒ¹I sewed an envelope closure for the back & tied it together with a big red bow, also found in my ribbon stash.Â  The cushions are wonderful to sit against - especially now the sun has decided to grace us with its presence at long last.Â Â On my last trip to Mums I took some stitchery work to do but completely forgot to include my embroidery threads.Â  Luckily I had tossed quite alot of fabric scraps into my bag so I was able to sit in the evenings & make yo yo flowers ... simply cutting a circle of fabric & drawing it up.Â  I find this quite therapeutic.Â  On my return home I decided I needed to actually doÂ somethingÂ with all these yo yo's!!Â Â I'd purchased a polystyrene cone from the $2 shop prior to Christmas - I painted it Pale duck egg.Â  Also the red candleholders were a 50 cent bargain from one of my Op Shop trips. I painted one of these too as I wanted to tone down the brightness of the red.I simply glued all my yo yo's over the cone, slightly overlapping the edges - you will notice the lower ones are a medium size & the top section I have made a bit smaller in size.Â  No two fabrics are the same & they are all made using Tilda & Liberty scraps.Â  I hadn't intended to have a red & blue theme but this is how it has turned out.Â Â I glued the cone to my candlestick base & then tied a snowflake charm to this, & tied a bell & heart to the top.Â  I love this & would rather like to make more in other colour-ways.Â  ğŸ’™ğŸ’—I thought you might enjoy this little Cat CollageÂ I put together & hopefully it will make you smile .... if I don't smile at these two's antics then dear friends, they will surely drive me bonkers!! ğŸ˜ŠMy 3 pots ofÂ  RhodohypoxisÂ were late to flower this year due to our wet spring so they were still looking pretty after Christmas. I found a certain Furry Ginger FairyÂ curled up asleep in the middle pot just last week.A glance out the window shortly after & this is what I spy .........Fat Blackie must've wandered by & thought Oh what a nice comfy spot that looks ...........Â I ran & grabbed my camera ...........Â  she is trying really hard to look innocent but is not fooling me !!!Shortly after ......... just like a couple of nesting hens.Â  I wonder if I look underneath, if there'll be any eggs laid there ??!! ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the naughtyÂ furry ones x0x0x

title: HaPPy NeW YeaR  !!!  ğŸ’—  ............... & The Tale Of The Little Red Car  ğŸš©
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWelcome to another bright shiny New YearÂ  ğŸ’—Lets hope 2023 is a happy & healthy one for All of Us.I saw this verse on Instagram & thought how VeRy true & how it certainly does sum things up!Â  Sometimes the AwfulÂ bits go on a bit longer than the AmazingÂ bits but I don't think any of us get to miss those bits out.Â  Personally I rather like the Ordinary & Mundane bits - the routine parts of life suit me just fine.Â We had a lovely Christmas with Mum in her room at the Resthome. My eldest son joined me, along with my Brother & his wife.Â  We were amazed the staff had gone to the effort of setting a proper Christmas table for us in Mum's room - just wonderful.Â  Mum is looking very frail & hardly ate anything but did enjoy the company.Â My eldest son's wife Sarah arrived late Christmas Day from visiting her family further down the Island.Â  Sarah & Alec were able to visit with Mum on Boxing Day & Alec read Mum a story.Â I took home an old Orange pot on my previous visit to Mum's.Â  Though I forgot to take a "before pic" I painted it black & then stenciled a Bee onto the side of it.Â  My sister in law just LoVes black & white pots on her deck area, so I planted a lovely white Impatien into it before gifting it to her.Â  She was delighted.Â  ğŸ–¤A couple of months back I purchased this wooden blue car from the St Johns Op-shop for $1.50.Â  When I went up to pay for it the lady said to me "Oh I guess you're buying this for your grandson".Â  Â  No I was not .. it was for Me!Â  Â  I hadÂ a plan for this little blue car.Â You can faintly see in the right hand pic, I've traced a black square in the back panel - I got my son Kayne to cut this square out for me as I wanted to make another "window".Â Â I painted the entire car with red chalk paint in the colour Raspberry Beret.Â  I had not used this colour before but it was the perfect Christmas Red that I was after.Â  Then I applied some Iron Orchid design transfers that I'd had for a couple of years.Â  I wanted to make it look Christmassy. ğŸ„I poked some greenery & berries in the rear window & then a small size bottlebrush tree in the "new window" in the back.Â  Originally I painted the wheels black but didn't like them so I painted over them in red.Â Â Having worked in a Gift Shop for almost 20 years, I do have a tendency to turn every thing into a display.Â  Â  I could not help myself with the little red car.Â  I found some miniature rusty tools & then decided to make a sign . . . .I glued a piece of dowel into an old wooden cotton reel & painted it red, then glued on a wooden disk which I'd painted black ... a couple of cut-up transfers added & then I could write on my sign with chalk.This little red car prompted an entire new Christmas display.Â  I used the table that I revampedÂ in * this post * & then added vintage books, bottle brush trees, greenery & berries.Â  The beautiful Christmas book was a gift from my dear friend Sandy & blended perfectly on my table.Â The tiny red car had lights that came on after I added batteriesEverything was already in my stash apart from the small red car with a tree on top, which I purchased from my local Variety Store.Â A strand of Christmas lights & it looked just like a winter village/ Christmas tree farm.You see, once upon a time there was a girl named Julie ğŸ˜‰ who drove a little red car for many, manyÂ years.Â  Â And many a December she actually drove HomeÂ with a real Christmas tree sticking out the rear window!! (& two sons in the back!!)Â Â Â  Even after she met The Mr & he eventually purchased an artificial Christmas tree - she still drove that little red car for many years to come. ğŸ˜ŠAfter fluffing for ages I was finally happy with my Christmas Coffee Table display.Â  I dragged out my op-shopped silver trays (polished them) & filled with freshly made citrus potpourri.During the year I collected old amber coloured glassware whenever I saw it in the Op-shops, & I made some of these up into soy candles & displayed on another vintage tray.Â  I have yet to burn these - I like to let my candles harden for at least a month as they burn much better.And YES dear friends ... I had the usual scenarioÂ  ... hadn't left enough space for a certain 4-legged fairy to plonk herself down on the table !!! How Dare I Indeed ???This is Her Not Impressed Christmas Face !!!Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: A Re-Purposed/Thrifted Kind of Christmas .....................................
text: ğŸ’—Â Â Greetings lovely friends & readersÂ  Â ğŸ„Â On my last trip down to Mum's when IÂ bought home the Chest of Drawers ... I also bought some other oddments that no doubt would have ended up in the bin.Â  I decided to use a few of them for some Christmas decorating projects.Â I bought Mums last 2 houseplants home with me & the silver tray (above left)Â was sitting under one of the plants.Â  It was "toss-able" as The Mr would say.Â  I sanded the rusty parts lightly & then gave it 2 coats of chalk paint in the colour Pumice.Â Â I mod-podged on a scrap of music paper, stamped the word JOY & then fashioned a wreath from a branch off a Christmas tree.Â  My friend Gail gave me the tree branch as the Op Shop were going to bin it.Â  I added some berries & a ribbon & lightly sanded the tray edges ... I really LoVe how this turned out ğŸ’—I've hung it on the wall above a small display using one of the Op-shopped plates from this post * Here *.Â  And YeS I really did make Santa hats for my miniature teddies !!!! ğŸ˜‰ (Click to enlarge for a closer view)Mum had a large stack of books in the spare room wardrobe - these had belonged to my Dad & he has now been gone for 22 years so I decided it was high time they got donated!!Â  I bought 6 home with me - glued 3 together, painted with Forest Green chalk paint & then glued on a small decal that I've had FORÂ ever.I painted over the entire thing again,Â  then tied it up with a scrap of ribbon, tucked in some greenery & berries & added a wee tag to the bow.Â  A book bundle for the princely sum of $0 !!I forgot to take a "before pic" but this tatty tray was in Mums wardrobe too.Â  I painted it with Linen chalk paint, then decided this was entirely the wrong colour for the transfer I wanted to apply.Â  So I painted it with black & then added red to the edges, lightly sanding for a more vintage look.Â I've had this transfer for 2 Christmas's nowÂ Â ...Â  I first used it on the mirrorÂ in * this post * & absolutely love it.Â  It is no longer in stock so I wanted to use it for something special. I applied some of it to the frame & am so pleased with how it looks.(The transfer is by Iron Orchid designs)This rusty saw was $5 at the SPCA Op-shop in Mum's town. I painted it black, oiled the handle & then added another section of the transfer to it.Â Â This old aluminum cooking pot was in Mum's shed.Â  I painted it with chalk paint - Country Clay - & then added yet more of the transfer to it.Â  It is just perfect to sit my wee artificial tree in with a block of wood inside to prop it up a bit higher.Â  ğŸ„My entire thrifted/upcycled/repurposed display arranged together on an old trunk.Â  The only purchased item was the Woodland Scene Teatowel which I have used as a table runner.Â Â I had really wanted a Reindeer to complete the scene but at $90 + in the stores it was way out of my budget.Â  Then I remembered this leather one I had gifted to The Mr many years ago. I found it in his shed, the leather had gone mildewy but I was able to clean it & give it a good oil.Â  This will be staying insideÂ once Christmas is all packed away.Â  I encourage you dear friends ... to think outside the square.Â  You do notÂ have to spend big money on Christmas decorating.Â  I have a couple more items that I would love to share but I feel this post is waayyy long enough so I will share those after Christmas.Â I am a creature of habit - I bake the same items each year,Â  those that I know & are simple.Â  Mars Bar Slice, Chocolate Fudge Cake & Gingernut bites.Â  These have been all packaged up & gifted to local friends, whom I share baking with.Â  The black/white striped boxes were again in Mum's wardrobe so I tizzied them up with paper doilies & a tag to present the baking in.Â I keep my eye out in Op Shops for little Christmas tins also - these are often 50 cents each & perfect for presenting baking in.Â This is my last post before I head to Mum's tomorrow dear friends,I am hoping to be back next week with a final post before the New Year.I would like to wish you All a most wonderful, safe & happy festive season & to thank you all with all my heartÂ for your visits to my little corner of cyberspace & the lovely comments you take the time to leave me ... it truly warms my heart more than you will ever know.Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: Christmas Prep  ........................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Well the 1st December came & went in the blink of an eye.Â  I got my Grandson's advent calendars filled for another year & delivered to them in time.Â  Â It is getting trickier as they get older, to find things small enough to fit in those tiny stockings.Â I have had to be a bit inventive & found I could tie the larger size packages to the peg with some string &Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  then clip the stocking over the top.Â Â  I keep a written sheet for myself, so I know each day what they will be opening.Â  It would seem - from checking in with his parents - that Alec has done a bit of a re-shuffle with some of his ğŸ˜‰A couple of weeks ago, Spotlight had huge reductions on all their Hessian so I treated myself to another length for my decking table.Â Â Every time I walk outside that $6 length of fabric just brings me so much pleasure.Â  I tizzied up the table a bit for Christmas & the red petunias just set everything off nicely.Â  ğŸ’—While I was placing my online Order I thought I would re-cover my outdoor cushions as well - they were looking quite a bit "worse for wear".Â  Â I decided to purchase the doiley print this time round & had great difficulty getting to actually SewÂ itÂ  ... due to a certain Ginger Miss who thought it made a lovely soft sleeping spot when I was down on the floor cutting it all out !!Finally I got them both done & am so pleased with the end result.Â  Yes of CourseÂ she had to test it out for comfort &Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  snugability !! Look at her there with her ampleÂ proportionsÂ lovely furry tummy!!I received another order for my potpourri fromÂ Brandy's Botanicals - it seems to be very popular this Christmas.Â  I have been experimenting with drying some Calendula flowers in my Dehydrator - they don't take long so you have to keep an eye on them or they shrivel too much.Â  They add such a nice pop of colour to my citrus potpourri.I've been re-doing my coffee table display for Christmas & filled a lovely silver plated dish with some of my fresh potpourri.Â  I will show my festive coffee table in my next post.Â Our craft group had our end of year Outing.Â  We went to Cambridge to view theÂ Christmas display in the town hall which was wonderful.Â  I wanted to gift the ladies a little treat each - last year I did theÂ Soaps wrapped in Dishcloths.Â Â Â I had some peat pots that I'd recently painted roughly with white chalk paint so I stood at my kitchen bench & decoupaged paper serviettes onto them using mod-podge.Â  It was a fun, simple craft & looked effective.I had planned to fill the pots with baked treats but simply ran out of time & energy.Â  The Warehouse had large boxes ofÂ Ferrero Rocher choccies on sale so I purchased one to fill my pots, then wrapped them in cellophane with a Christmassy tag.Â  The ladies were delighted.Â  Let me tell you dear friends .... quite a fewÂ of those choccy treats landed in my mouth while I was putting these together !!!! ğŸ˜Â  I've no idea how !!!Sid has 3 new family members of the 2-legged variety.Â  My son Kayne has built this wonderful hen-house & they have 3 baby hens.Â  Sid has named his one (pictured above) Frankfurter (!!!), Sid's Mum has named hers Gertrude, & my son has named his Wingy ğŸ˜‰ .. I shall try not to fill my future posts with too many chicken photos.Â Â I had started my Christmas preparations early this year (mid November) but it still feels like it's going to be a mad rush to the end.Â  We are having our family Christmas this weekend as I will be travelling down to spend Christmas Day with Mum at the Resthome.Â  I will be back before then with another post.Â  I hope the lead-up is going okay for you all.Â  Remember to pause, to breathe & to try & enjoy the festivities.Â  (Yes - hark at me talking ğŸ˜)Thank you, as always, for your visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Love Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: My Childhood Chest of Drawers
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersOn my last trip to Mum's, when I told my brother I would be taking home the old chest of drawers out in Mum's shed, he said some words I can't actually print on here ğŸ˜‰ ... but their interpretation went something like "was I barking mad?!"Â  No I was not !It took some effort on my part to load them into my vehicle as they are native timber & not exactly light ... but I was determined.This chest of drawers was used by my brother & I for the first 5 years of our life as we shared a bedroom together.Â  Eventually we got our own bedrooms & I think he used this for awhile longer before it got moved out to Dad's shed & became home to all his painting & wallpapering gear.Â  You see my Dad was a painter & paperhanger.Â  When I got the drawers home & loaded onto my deck I realised they were probably in much worse state than I had envisioned.Â  But that's okay - I still had a "plan". ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜¶Â The drawers & the sides of the unit were full of borer holes.Â  I sanded & stripped the wood - it took me a week but that wasn't continually working on it - that was walking away from it quite often !!I treated it by spraying with kerosene to kill any live borer lavae.Â  Then I set about filling all those borer holes with wood putty.Â  Believe me friends, there were about a gazillion of them !!Lastly I oiled the wood using a woodstain that I already had on hand.Â  It has actually turned out darker than I wanted but I am fairly sure where I have placed it - on my covered deck area - it will soon lighten a bit & fade.Â  The stain looks patchy here but it is not this bad in real life.Â  I also replaced the 5 handles with new ones as they were broken.Â  I wanted a simple handle - nothing too fancy.Â Â My "plan" for this chest of drawers & my "vision" was to use it to house all my garden supplies.Â  These were previously sitting on our old dog kennel & often looked messy/unsightly when you walked up our deck steps.Everything fitted in perfectly & I also ran an old candle along the base of the drawers as the wax helps them to glide open & closed easily.Â  I was really pleased with how it turned out but felt it needed "something more" ..............I ended up purchasingÂ this botanical transfer fromÂ * this * gorgeous shop & I think it just finished it all off nicely.Â  I am really pleased with how these drawers turned out & the fact that they are so useful is a double blessing.Â Â Safely under cover on my deck area & out of any weather.Attractive as well as useful at the same time ğŸ’šI also washed all my china plates & replaced a couple that had big chips/cracks in them using the plates I op-shoppedÂ in * this post *Â for $2 each.Â AÂ "Beautical Sunray Pink Petunia" in my wrought iron chair planter - a gift from my friend Julie ğŸ’—Lastly dear friends - I absolutely LoVe this photo above - look at the body language on Sid! Could he sit much further away? ğŸ˜Š He is not especially fond of Santa, but he thought there might be a toy involved so he persevered. Makes me smile everytime I look at it.Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Enjoy the weekend, remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Chasing My Tail   .........................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readers,Sometimes I watch Miss Pippi chasing her tail ... round & round she goes madly ... never actually catching it or achieving anything - well that is rather how this entire year has felt.Â Round & round I go - achieving very little at times.Â  And yet another month goes by since I last blogged.Â Â  I have been away down to Mum's again but prior to that, & just as I was recovering from my surgery, I caught Covid.Â  I know everyone has a different experience of Covid but I have to say - it absolutely flattened me.Â  I always had grand visions of being able to craft the recovery time away but friends, I could barely lift my head off the pillow - it just immobilised me & a month later, I am still trying to get some energy back.Â (I should probably add in here that I certainlyÂ did NotÂ travel to Mums until I was well over my Covid)(The stunning Mount Taranaki was peaked in white in the background)I delivered a large citrus potpourri order (10 bags & 10 boxes) out to the lovely Deb atÂ Brandy's Botanicals while I was down at Mums.Â  And she has just yesterday messaged me for another order please.Â  So my dehydrator is busy drying another load of oranges off my tree.It was theÂ Centuria Garden Festival time while I was down at Mums.Â  I usually miss this yearly event but this year I was hoping to get to see a couple of the gardens.Â  In the end I managed to visit 3 but the one I was mostÂ excited about wasÂ Jenny Oakley's Garden out at Manaia.Â Mum & I first visited Jenny's garden together, probably about 10 years ago now.Â  I well remember her stunning hanging baskets & they were just as magnificent this time round.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Here they are hanging in this beautiful old Native tree.Â Â Even Jenny's window boxes took my breath away.Such a riot of glorious colour everywhere ğŸ’—I loved how she had planted out these Moa's & Pink flamingo's that her husband had fashioned for her.Â  The Moa's are filled with Mondo grasses in green, & black for the baby.Â  The pink flamingo is planted with pink impatiens that will be stunning when they grow.Â  Such imagination ğŸ’•As luck would have it (& good timing on my part), Jenny was giving a hanging basket demonstration & talk at 11am on the morning I visited.Â  She gives a couple of these throughout the festival.Â Â As well as being just a genuinely nice person, Jenny was So happy to share her knowledge.Â  I honestly learnt so much & so many little tips & tricks.Â  I shall be giving this a go sometime over the summer months.Â Â The day after my return was the big Fireworks Spectacular at our local Speedway which we can see clearly from our outside deck area.Â  So my Grandsons & their families came for a Pizza dinner & then around 8.45 we sat out on the deck & watched the display.Â  The little ones loved it & it was all over by just after 9 pm.Â Â I have to say I don't especially enjoy fireworks, mainly because of the trauma they create for our animal friends.Â  Thankfully I had gotten my two furry ones inside early enough as in past years Miss Pip has gone missing for days at a time, so traumatised is she by the noise.Â Â Â En-route to Mum's I usually break for a coffee at the lovely Cafe Lure in Inglewood thatÂ I wrote about * here *.
