Â I like to browse their craft section & purchased this catnip mouse for Madam Pip (Yes inÂ floral colours, reminded me of Liberty fabric).Â  As soon as I gave it to her she just devoured it ... she can obviously smell the catnip inside.Â  Two weeks later & she is still obsessed with it.After my surgery my dear friend Sandy loaned me a wonderful selection of books to read, so I decided to make her a bookmark as a little Thank You.Â  I used one of my lovely friend JenniferÂ of Elefantz designs bookmark patterns - goÂ * here * for the free downloads.Â  Â I made Sandy's in Tilda fabrics in two of her favourite colours. ğŸ’™Â Lastly dear friends, my step-grandaughter Juno has become a "big sister" as they welcomed little Sadie Joy into the world a couple of weeks ago.Â  I just adore this photo above - they are all doing well & we look forward to meeting Sadie very soon.Â Â Thank you as always, for your welcome visits here today,I am off batten down the hatches as we are experiencing dreadful stormy weather here this week,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: A Catch-Up Post  (Part 2)  ..........  (A Waffle-y Post)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAfter hitting Publish on my last post, I was unable to get it to actually Publish.Â  Â I did not know how to resolve this as contacting Blogger seems to be a mission impossible, but finally I found a Community Help Forum & a lovely Polish man named Arek very kindly assisted me.Â  I was So immensely grateful as I had been wondering if I may have to give up blogging if I couldn't reach you all with my posts.Â  It made me realise how much I would miss this chatty, friendly place called blogland.Â Â Anyway - all that just to say ... I am very happy to be back here again ğŸ˜Š This is a bit of a waffle-y post filled with all sorts of things I wanted to share here.During our first Lockdown in 2020, my friend Gail dug out an entire garden of Clivias down one side of her house.Â  Unable to visit the Dump she filled 2 black rubbish bags & The Mr picked them up from her gateway to dispose of in the farm burning hole. When I saw them on the back of his Ute I grabbed them as I thought I might have somewhere to plant them.Â  The greenery was all cut off & it was mainly just the root system left.Â  We have a large area of native trees between our house section & our rented depot yard - nothing much grows here as the tree roots have sucked all the goodness out of the soil underneath.I carefully planted all the clivia's root systems & slowly they grew - I was delighted this spring that most of them are putting on such a lovely show of colour.Â  When I saw One Clivia PlantÂ in my local Garden Centre for $25 I realised what a treasure trove I had planted here.Â Â Some of you may remember this table & chairs that I revamped for Juno late last year in * this post *.Â  On my last trip to Mums I saw the little chair (below) in the local Hospice Shop for $6.Â  I walked back to my car without buying it .... but then I sat & had a think & I remembered that Juno is going to be a big sister any day now.Â Â I thought an extra chair might be handy once Juno's new little sister can use the table too ... so I went back & paid my $6.Â  I gave it 3 coats of chalk paint in the colour Rosie.Â  It was actually a horrid thing to paint - I am not sure why but I didn't enjoy it & it took 3 coats to get a decent coverage.I still had some of the rabbit themed transfers left over so I was able to keep the same look going.Â  Juno is rabbit-obsessed so I am sure she will love this pink chair & will no doubt be the bossy older sister who gets to decide who-sits-where !!I gave the chair 4 new rubber feet that I already had on hand - as well as 2 coats of matt finish spray varnish.Â  I find this makes the furniture wipeable which is handy when it gets used by children.Â I saw these wooden slabs last month when I visited the Daffodil farm & purchased 4 (they were $5 each).Â  I had always wanted to make some stepping stones from our driveway to the corner of the deck which is where I take a short-cut every time I go to check the mail box.Â  The Mr made me stain them well with several coats of Oil before I set them in the ground because he isÂ annoying, fussyÂ thorough like that.Â I love how they turned out & now I can even pop across in my slippers ğŸ˜‰I have had to make an elevation in the "hospital corner" of my lounge, where I grow all my cuttings & seedlings.Â  I needed somewhere to put some seedling trays so this old wooden pew made the perfect second storey addition.Sometimes my "hospital corner" even gets the odd visitorÂ  ............This dinosaur is one of Sid's most favourite toys, however it looked nothing like this when his little dog Darcy had finished with it.Â  She had bitten the back seam right open & much of the stuffing was missing as well as several holes in the arms & legs.Â  I was able to sit & stitch it all up & fill it with some new stuffing - Sid was delighted.To thank me he drew me this card ... it says "from Sid to Granny" but his G is back to front.Â  He also made the iceblock-stick/string toy for Pippi to play with ğŸ˜‰Â  These are the things I will treasure always.Â Â Alec has just returned from a 10 day holiday to Tasmania, Australia.Â  He flew with his Mum & stayed at his Aunt's rural property - off grid, way out in the Tasmanian wilderness - no power or running water!Â  He enjoyed every moment of it.Â  I love this photo above, he reminds me so much of his Dad in this photo.Â Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,(Hopefully I can get this post to actually Publish!)With much love & friendship to you all, ğŸ’—Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: A Catch-Up Post  (part 1)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersSome days/weeks it feels like I achieve very little but once I look back through my photos, I see this is not always the case.The last of the Freesias picked before the thunderstorm cameÂ I have been in hospital for some surgery & I came home with a long list of things I was not allowed to do .... fortunately crafting was Not one of them.My neighbor gifted me this set of vintage scales back in January for pet feeding duties.Â  She no longer wanted them but they were always missing their tray.Â  I kept an eye out on my Op-Shop travels & found this expandable cake tin for just 50 cents in the bargain bin.I painted it with 2 coats of matt black paint & then 2 coats of clear acrylic spray varnish.It could do to be a little larger but in the meantime it does the job wonderfully & I'm thrilled with my 50c purchase.My youngest son cut me out these house shapes from a piece of custom-wood that I had lying around.Â  This design is from an old pattern identical toÂ this one * Here *.Â Â  Yes I had "assistance"Â from BlackieÂ with this project ğŸ˜‰ - he very kindly helped me select which buttons to use.Â I spray painted 5 of the tags with some matt black & then added Christmas fabrics to the roof.Â  I glued on some wooden buttons fromÂ Theodora Cleave that I already had in my stash.Â  The tags can be written on with chalk, then rubbed off & re-used.Â  These were such a fun project. ğŸ„These are photographed beside my adorable new tin sign from my dear friends Jane & SallyOne of my favorite things to do is watch YouTube videos - I find them very inspiring.Â  At present it seems everyone else is decorating for autumn & there are pumpkins Everywhere!Â  I foundÂ this simple free pattern on the internet & decided to try knitting some myself - I just love how these turned out & am now knitting some in paler colours.Â  Though I don't consider myself a very good knitter, these were simple & fun to create.I had a packet of wooden coathangers in my stash likeÂ these ones * here *.Â  I had painted two of them ages ago but never done anything with them.Â  I wanted to make gifts for two friends so I decoupaged them with a gorgeous Rice Paper & then stitched my friends initials onto some linen offcuts.Â  These initials are a pattern fromÂ Jenny of elefantz designsÂ - I stitched them using Cottage Garden thread Pink Lavender & tied them onto the hooks. Just before gifting I'll add a generous drop of lavender oil to them. ğŸ’œLast year I purchased two Tilda Mystery Boxes from Craft with Fee.Â  I have been slowly finishing off all the projects in them & this needlecase was the last one.Â  Everything is included in the kitset - you just have to sit & make it all up, which is lovely & relaxing.Â  This particular Tilda fabric was one of my favourites from an older range.Â Â Just prior to my hospital admission it was my eldest sons birthday.Â  Nobody could visit as they all had colds & I could not afford to catch anything, so there was no celebration.Â Â As soon as I was home & able to, I baked him his favourites - Lasagne, & a Raspberry & White Chocolate Shortcake presented with a bowl of whipped cream! He was delighted.(Just some of the woolly mammoths that I managed to get a pic of)I have had Sid a couple of days last week as its school holidays here in New Zealand.Â  We went along to our local Library as their school holiday programme was Dinosaur Themed.Â  We made woolly mammoths.Â  Now let me tell you dear friends ... this was by far theÂ mostÂ exciting thing that I've done for ages!!Â Which probably tells you something about my life of late.Â  (in fact I am pretty sure I enjoyed it way more than Sid did - I am writing this small as if I am whispering to you)Thank you so very much for your visits here today dear friends,I shall be back in a few days with Part 2 as I have lots to catch up on here,Wishing you a wonderful weekend, be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: A Snippet Roll ......  ğŸ–¤  " Things I Love "
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersA fresh new length of oilcloth arrived to start the week off - ordered onlineÂ from * Here *.Â  I also picked the first vase of freesia's from my garden - I just adore their fragrance ğŸ’›When I placed the Oilcloth on my dining table I just loved it ... I asked The Mr what he thought of it & his reply wasÂ "it just looks like something you dragged out of Grandma's attic".Little does he realise that to me ...... this is TheÂ PerfectÂ compliment!It was my dear friend Shirley who first introduced me toÂ " Snippet Rolls " - I had never heard of them before.Â  Then I saw them on the lovelyÂ Michelle's blogÂ & drooled all over my computer screen when I saw her exquisite work.Â  I emailed & asked Michelle about them & she very kindly shared some tips to get me started.Â  Out of the blue a package arrived from her filled with some bits & bobs from her own collection - how special & wonderful.Â Though I had very little idea of what I was doing, I cut a metre length of linen & began embellishing.Â  I decided my Roll would be themed on "Things I Love"Â  ğŸ’—It must be well over a year ago that I first started this - I got as far as Friends & FamilyÂ ... then kind of ran out of puff with it, tossed it all in a basket & shoved it under the spare bed.Â There were two things that happened to re-inspire me, & help me to complete it.The first thing was (in July) when my friend Sally gifted me this beautifulÂ book above for my birthday.Â  I drooled over the pages, took it to Mums with me & read it from cover to cover. Upon my return home I pulled the Snippet Roll basket out again.Â I decided I needed to set up a special table to work on, & not have to clear everything away all the time which was hindering my progress.Â  I dragged in the drop leaf table that I revampedÂ in * this post * along with a sturdy chair & set up a small corner of my lounge where I had good lighting & it didn't matter if I made a mess (which I did!!) ğŸ˜‰This was a great decision & this messÂ table stayed like this until I finished my Snippet roll.And YesÂ ... in case you were wondering ... I had the usual "help & assistance of the furry variety" ğŸ˜A couple of weeks ago, I put the final stitch in my Snippet Roll ... would you like to see inside it??Â I started the first section with "Friends & Family" ...Â you can just see the word familyÂ embroidered in pale blue, where the arrow is pointing (bottom right)My next section in Things I LoveÂ was crafting & creativity.Â  I've forgotten to move my charms to the side before taking a pic, but the heart reads "Love to Sew"Â  ğŸ’•You can click on the photos to enlarge them if you wishThe next section was my Garden ... once again I've forgotten to arrange the charms nicely.Â  These are off a broken pair of earings that I had years ago ... a tiny trowel & fork.Â The next section is Home.Â  I really love my Home & being at Home - it is one of the places I feel safest.Â  I could hardly do Home without adding CatsÂ now could I??Â  Remember these are all the things I love.I happened to find a wooden black cat button in my stash & on further investigation, a pottery ginger cat button.Â  Miss Pippi is NotÂ impressed with this - she feels she should be Fine Bone China & not just old pottery !!!My final section was Christmas.Â  I was going to do Tilda but I think that might take an entire Snippet Roll all on its own.Â  So I found some lovely Christmas buttons fromÂ Theodora Cleave - remember when I won the giveawayÂ in * this post *.Â I ended it with a piece of treasured Liberty Christmas fabric.Â  It's all looking like it needs a good iron in my pics, but that is just from rolling it up tightly.Â Â I backed the entire piece using this lovely cotton print that I had in my stash - I wanted something subtle & pretty.Â  I hand stitched this on ... like Michelle does in her work, I didn't want any raw edges that might fray.And how did I display my Snippet Roll ?Â  I just unwound a section of it & sat it on my mantle piece so I can look at it & enjoy it as I walk past.Â Â This gorgeous tag was included in Michelle's parcel & I have this leaning against the wound-up bobbin.I'm really pleased with my Snippet Roll & would love to make another one sometime. I should add here that apart from Michelle's gifted trims, I just used items entirely from my stash & purchased nothing.Â  I should also add that my embroidery & applique skills are entirely self taught & probably NotÂ that wonderful to be honest ğŸ˜‰As I type this rain is setting in again ... the furry two are on my sweatshirt, on my bed, curled up together. I can hear Blackie snoring rather loudly.Â Thank you dear friends, for staying with me through this marathon post,I hope the week is treating you well - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Love Julie & the furry two x0x0x

title: Hydrangea Love  ğŸ’™ğŸ’™
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersMy friend Gail gifted me this beautiful Hydrangea transfer for my birthday in June ... I absolutely LoVed it & wanted to use it on something special.Â  Â I especially love Hydrangeas & just adored the pastel colours in this.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Seeing the black decorated lampshade on the packet gave me an idea . . . . . .I have this large plain table lamp in a corner of my Lounge.Â  The Lady that owns the Farm gifted it to me many years ago & I use it as I really love lamplight, but always wanted to give it a bit of a lift or an injection of colour.Â I carefully dismantled the lamp & then painted the base with 2 coats of chalk paint in the colour Old Linen.Â I dried it by the fire ... Miss Pippi takes her "watching-paint-dry duties"Â veryÂ seriously but after all - a girl does get tired !! ğŸ˜‰I also painted the lamp shade in chalk paint "Antique White" as it was showing some age spots & discoloration - it came up great!Â  Next it was time to affix the transfers to the shade. This was tricky (to put it mildly) as I had to pack thick bath towels insideÂ the frame of the shade, to stop it cracking while I applied the transfers. I carefully worked my way around managing to cover nearly all the circumference of the shade. I was really happy with how the lamp turned out & found some old faded hydrangea heads that I spray painted with some colours I had on hand - just a quick whiff across the flower head to bring them to life.The frame had a price sticker on it from when I thrifted it ... $8.00I still had some transfers left over so I found this oval frame in my sleep-out.Â  It was actually pressed flowers inside glass - very old & faded so I decided to just paint right over the glass as it was secure inside the frame.Â  Once again - two coats of Old Linen chalk paint & a light sanding/distressing of the frame.While I was working out the placement for my hydrangeas I felt I needed some wording in the background.Â  Like my fabric scraps, I keep every single offcutÂ of my transfers & I was able to find some vintage French wording in my offcuts envelope.Â  I love how this turned out ğŸ’™I hung it over the Gothic Mirror that I have in my lounge & just love my new Hydrangea cornerÂ so much. ğŸ’™Incidentally the cabinet that I dragged in had a brightly coloured transfer on the door which looked so gaudy.Â  I was able to wet this & scrape it off, & then give it a quick coat of the same chalk paint (Old Linen).Â  I love it much more with the door left blank.A string of fairy lights & it all looks complete. ğŸ’™ Each evening when I turn the lamp on it just makes me feel so happy with my little refreshed corner.After a couple of really nice spring days it has turned wet & icy cold here today - typical Waikato Spring weather.Â  I baked this morning ... aÂ Weetbix Slice for The Mr, & aÂ Raspberry & White Chocolate Shortcake as I have eldest son & family coming tomorrow.Â Â I have some freshly dehydrated orange slices by the fire as I have more potpourri orders to fill.A certain ginger Miss has curled up on my sewing chair dreaming happily with her little tongue poking out.Â YesterdayÂ * this special book * arrived in the post ... a treat (to me from me)Â using the last of my birthday money.Â  I have many jobs awaiting but for now I am going to sit down with a cuppa & maybeÂ probably a slice of that Raspberry Shortcake & drool my way through my new book.Â  Wishing you a wonderful weekend dearest friends.Thank you as always for your welcome visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: Painting, Planting & The Daffodil Farm
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWelcome to the first day ofÂ  Spring - my absolute favorite Season ğŸ’—Â We have had a week of blue skies, sunshine & chilly-but-glorious days where you can just about see the garden waking up from it's winter sleep.Down the end of my lounge by the French Doors, I have what I call My Hospital Corner.Â  It's where I put plants that need reviving or some extra care. It's warm, filtered light with no draughts & plants seem to really come back to life here.Â  I often wish I could just lie down there awhile & rejuvenate myself !! It's also where I start my cuttings off & so I decided it was time to pot up some of the plants that I had grown from cuttings over winter.A rustle around under my house & I came across some old pots that had been tossed under there.Â  I painted them with left over chalk paint & applied oddments of transfers to cheery them up a bit.Â After I've applied the transfers I like to spray them with two coats of clear matt varnish just to seal & protect them & I find this works really well & also makes them scrubable if need be.This plant was grown from a leaf off my friend Joyce's plantI forgot to take a "before" of this one but it was a dark almost black colour.Â  I loved the fluted edge of it.This pink paint I have used is actually a Resene Testpot in the Colour Pale Rose - it's the perfect shade of pink ğŸ’—This was a tin bucket with rope handles that I found in my sleep out. It was the perfect size for my poor pot-bound ladder fern.(I can cut 3 plants labels from one length of Dowel)Pretty plant labels are expensive to buy but I enjoy making my own from these round wooden discs that you can buy from the Variety Stores ($2.99 for a packet of 4).Â  I buy a length of dowel from Mitre 10, hot glue it to the back & then paint the entire piece before adding the transfers.Â  These are great if you need to stake a plant too.I decided to use this old tin trunk as a plant display area as the large picture window provides good light for my plants.Â  These ones are all newly repotted in larger (upcycled) containers.Just beside the tin trunk is a selection of thrifted plant stands that I have painted over the years. I seem to have a bit of A Pink ThemeÂ going on down here.While I was outside re-potting I gave my deck table a good scrub & potted up these sweet little viola's.Â  The purple in them almost reminds me of velvet.Â  The potted white hyacinth was pulled out from under a garden shrub - its fragrance is divine.The other week I had to deliver some fresh bags of my citrus pot-pourri toÂ The Farm Shop at Gordonton.Â  I had not supplied them for over a year due to Lockdowns etc & I wanted to deliver it & remove any old stock I had there.Â  My car smelt beautiful on the drive over!I had arranged to meet up with my lovely friend Sue out there & have lunch together.Â  Sue took me to the cafe out atÂ Woodlands EstateÂ on the other side of Gordonton.Â  I had not been here before & it was just stunning.Â Â We had a lovely lunch & a wander around the gardens but could not go in the main house due to a private function being held there.Sue & I both wanted to go to Clandon Daffodil Farm.Â  It has been a couple of years since I was last here & it is one of my favourite places to visit.Â  Just seeing those rows & rows of happy yellow faces as you drive up is so uplifting.Â  Even though it was a wet rainy day it was still such a pleasant & enjoyable outing.Â Â The shop is self service & they have a huge selection of daffodils for you to choose from & very reasonably priced.Â  Sue & I both bought a big bunch of Seconds.Â Â They also sell a selection of bulbs here & have a display garden where you can see the different varieties of daffs available to grow now ... even a pink shade.When I got home I divided all my daffs up into different vases as I wanted to share them with my daughter in laws.Â  Sue has begun learning pottery & is doing such amazing work - I was delighted when she presented me with one of her bowls in a lovely dusky blue glaze.Â Â I put a large vase of Early Cheer Daffs in my lounge so I could enjoy them each night & Oh the fragrance was amazing.Â  They always make me feel happy because I know when they appear each year ... spring is not too far away.Interestingly I took a photo of this notice at the Daffodil Farm & decided to do exactly as they suggested.Â  I often find daffs don't last long in my home as it gets hot here due to our fire.Â  But I did what they suggested (putting them outside on the deck each night), changing the water every 2nd day ...& they did Not begin to wilt until day 6 or 7, so I was really pleased.Thank you so very much dear friends, for staying through this lengthy post,I am off to fill the wood basket as it feels like another frost tonight,Wishing you a wonderful weekend - be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI noticed I have a couple of new followers ...... title: A Tilda Swap  ........  Across " the ditch "
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAt the start of this yearÂ Christine emailed me to ask whether I would be interested in doing a Tilda Swap with her as we are both dedicated Tilda lovers. I thought this was a wonderful idea & we both agreed to make very "loose rules" in that it would be a winter swap using Tilda fabrics but not necessarily a Tilda pattern.Â We both began working on our swap gifts in early Autumn & decided we would mail them to each other on the same day.Â  Christine is in Victoria, Australia & I am in Waikato, New Zealand so theÂ Tasman SeaÂ that seperates our two countries is often referred to as "the ditch".Â  We were curious to see whose reached its destination first.Â  Interestingly mine reached Christine in just over a week yet hers took 3 (long) weeks to get to me.During our waiting time Christine suggested we do a facetime call to each other & open our parcels at the same time.Â  We have never met & only became "friends" through this wonderful medium called Blogging.I had mine all laid out on a tray to begin opening them at our designated calling time ... it was So exciting & I even remembered to brush my hair that day (!!!) ğŸ˜‰Â The first package I opened was these delectable treats from Australia ... Choccy Caramello Koala's, Rocky Road Cookie Bites & a box of Australian Afternoon Tea.Â  Christine had popped the Caramello Koala's in for the grandchildren but I must confess NotÂ every single one reached the littlies ğŸ˜¯ (!!!)What was inside the other packages quite took my breath awayÂ  ...Â I must've mentioned once how I just adoreÂ the Tilda "Old Rose range"Â & Christine had remembered this ... this stunning project bag made from Old Rose fabrics & filled with all manner of stitching delightsÂ  ğŸ’• including a gorgeous variegated Cottage Garden Thread.The sweetest needle-case & matching pincushion ğŸ’•(The pattern Christine has used is a Gail Pan design)This darling little thread catcher that winds up & down magically, & a pair of scissors with a strawberry scissor-keep attachedÂ  ğŸ’•You can read Christine's post about what she made meÂ * Here *Â ... her photo's are much clearer than mine.I was honestly just SO delighted with my swap gifts & at the end of our phone call I realised we had both chatted for an hour!! It was simply wonderful.When we initially agreed on the swap the first idea that popped into my head was to make a doll for Christine.Â  She had mentioned she has pinks, greens, reds in her home so I pulled some fabrics in these colours from my stash & decided to make her theÂ Rosalie Quinlan doll "Ruby"This doll has a tag hanging from it's hand that reads "Dear Mummy We love you" -Â so I decided to stitch "I ğŸ’— Tilda" on my tag.The dress fabric is a piece from the Sweetheart Tilda range which is now a Very vintage Tilda (2015)The doll is made to hang from a loop on her other hand but I feel she is equally as nice just sitting.Â I had some treasured vintage linens in my stash & I used this gorgeous crinoline lady one for my doll's pinny.Â  Instead of French knots for hair as the pattern states, I gave her some pretty hair using hand dyed mohair.I painted her shoes using some pale pink chalk paint as I didn't have any fabric paint in this colour.Christine has named her doll "Tilly" ğŸ’—The face scrubbies & soap pouch are purchased from a gorgeous Handcraft Shop in Mum's townI had gathered together some bits & pieces to include so I decided to stitch a little gathered pouch to hold them.Â  The soap is fromÂ this Lavender Farm which is 2 minutes up the road from where I live.Â  The pouch is also a Rosalie Quinlan design from her book Gift.When I saw this wee china jug in an Op Shop the flowers reminded me of Tilda so I made a soy candle in the jug & included this, along with a N.Z magazine & N.Z choccy.The hanging doiley Angels are from the bookÂ Tilda's Winter DelightsÂ .. you cut them out & then add a paper doiley skirt - just so sweet tied onto parcels.Â And for Christine's post about what I made for her ...Â go * Here *Â  Â  Â We both agreed this was just such an enjoyable swap & were both so VeRy happy with our packages.Quite by accident Sid & I have discovered that our local Library has Lego Club each Tuesday after school so we went along this week & had a wonderful hour building Lego with other children.Â  I think this might become a regular fixture in our Tuesday after-school activities.Â Â Thank you all so much for staying with me through this lengthy post dear friends,Â Â With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Hello (& Goodbye !!) to July .......... & Welcome to August
text: Greetings (at long last) lovely friends & readersI did not mean to be gone for so long (2 months in fact) !!Some early spring flowers - picked from my garden just this morning ğŸ’›Just after I hit Publish on my last post, my dear 93 year old Mum became most unwell ...Â  3 ambulance trips in 10 days from the Resthome - Mum had Influenza A,Â a U.T.I.Â as well sufferingÂ a T.I.A.Â  My eldest son & I drove down arriving just after midnight to the nearest City Hospital.Â  I ended up staying for nearly 3 weeks until Mum was transferred back to the Resthome & became stable.Â  It was a scary & anxious time & not one I would want to repeat.Â  Upon my return our computer crashed & although I could read blogs on my phone,Â  I couldn't comment.Â  So I feel I have missed out on so much here in blogland & am happy to be able to post again.About 10 minutes drive from Mums home is Ohawe Beach - I went out there frequently for walks along the wild west coast & loved it.Â  I am over an hour from here to a beach so it was wonderful to be able to be so close to the sea.Â I confess to being a bit obsessed with taking photos of stunningÂ Mount TaranakiÂ - he was proudly wearing his white winter coat while I was there.Â The top left hand photo is just up the road from Mums, on one of my walks & the top right one is actually taken from my bedroom window at Mums - you can just see it peeking between the rooftops. I grew up with this mountain out my bedroom window & took it SO much for granted.Â  It never fails to take my breath away when I return.While I was away I celebrated another birthday - 62 years around the sun!! My friend Lynley popped in with a Red Velvet cupcake & candle so I happily blew it out for her.Â  Unfortunately just after our little morning tea Mum was rushed off in the ambulance yet again so my birthday involved 7 hours at A & E ... not exactly how I would recommend celebrating your birthday.Luckily just before my son & I headed off late into the night I remembered to toss my bag of knitting cotton oddments into the car & I was able to knit lots of dishcloths to fill in the many hours spent sitting in hospitals or Resthomes.Â  I useÂ * this free pattern * & I have knitted so many I can now remember it off by heart.I miss these two so very much when I am away ... the ginger girl frets & doesn't eat properly until I return, then she sulks with me for a couple of days & then goes back to normal ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜¸ (well normal for her)While I've beenÂ away we have been getting a nice new wooden fence built.Â  This is very excitingÂ for me ... we have always just had a wire fence between our section & the farm & it was falling down, to put it mildly.Â  Every time I would peg out my washing I would be trying to straighten posts that the cows had knocked over.Â  This new post-&-rail fence goes right around the outer perimeter of our section (260 metres) including the depot yard at the end which we rent out.(Click on the photo to enlarge it for a better view)The Mr bought one of the farm tractors home to remove the old posts & the furry two found it so incredibly fascinating climbing all over it & checking out the different smells of all the barn cats that live at the farm.Â Â Inevitably there have been some Op Shop visits on my recent trips.Â  The St Vincent de Paul Op Shop in Mum's town had a large stack of plates for only $2 each.Â  Of course I need more china plates like I need a hole in the head, but however ............. these ones came home with me.Â  The two on the far right were only $1 each & the others were all $2 - how could I resist ???!!! ğŸ˜¯There were other op shop purchases but I think I will show these as I repurpose/upcycle them.Â Â My daughter-in-law Sarah would send me lovely photos of my Grandson while I was away to brighten my days - I absolutely adore this one of Alec, sound asleep with the cat on the bed.Long time readers of my blog may remember the post I wrote about herÂ finding this feral kitten that was so unwellÂ - you can see how dear Bruno has well & truly landed on his feetÂ paws !! ğŸ’™Â Wishing you all a wonderful weekend dear friends,I shall be back soon as I have much to share with you,Thank you for your ever-welcome visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Moving My Mum to Resthome Care
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have been away for over a week as I moved my dear Mum in to Resthome Care.Â  Â  I think some overseas Countries call it Assisted Living but here in New Zealand we call it Resthome Care.Â  Â  Â It feels like I went away in Autumn & returned in Winter as there are bare branches & leaves everywhere around my section & garden.Â The day before I went I had a VeRy important event to attend ... Grandparents Day at Sid's new school.Â  Though the weather was dreadful & the scheduled Cross Country Run cancelled, we still had a wonderful time & both enjoyed it very much.My 93 year old Mum has spent the past 10 years of her life saying she is NeverÂ EverÂ going in to Resthome Care ... so I knew it was going to be difficult to navigate.Â  Â We had been waiting all year for a room to become available & finally when one was, I didn't want to risk losing it.Â  I am hoping that as the days & weeks go by Mum comes to accept that she can no longer manage living on her own at Home anymore.Â  It is 21 years todayÂ since my Dad passed away from Cancer.Â  Â  Mum's new room is very pleasant & has a nice big picture window that looks out on to greenery & big trees.Â Â (You can just see Mums reflection in the window)The Resthome has 3 cats, two of them were rescue kittens & this one above (Boots) came to welcome Mum on her first day there.Â  Here she is sitting on Mum's windowsill.Â Â The next day Boot's brother (Marley) followed me up the hallway & into Mum's room, where he promptly took up residence on her bed for the rest of the day.Â  The third day I visited, Marley was on her lap enjoying her pats.Â  I do think they sense when the Residents are "cat lovers" or not, as they don't go in to everyone's rooms apparently.I had really hoped that Mum would find "a new friend" while in the Resthome but I kind of thought a two-legged one & not a four-legged, furry one !! ğŸ˜‰When my brother came to install a new TV set in Mum's room Marley was not fazed in the slightest & just carriedÂ on sleeping.(The wooden childs chair was $5 & I thought I may re-purpose it as a plant stand)During stressful times I try to relax by browsing the isles of Op Shops ... however it was slim pickingsÂ this trip.Â  The above items were found in the local SPCA Op Shop apart from the Cane frame which was in a shop opposite that was closing down & was $3.I thought the wee lavender porcelain jug & bowl would be sweet with candles poured into them & the ($2) terracotta wheelbarrow will get a coat of paint & some succulents planted in it sometime.BeforeÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  AfterI couldn't resist this little framed cutwork design for $3 ... but once home I gave the frame 3 coats of Pale Duck Egg chalk paint as I thought this complimented the soft pastel needlework more than the darker wood.It fits perfectly on my occasional table with other thrifted/upcycled items painted in the same colour ğŸ’™You can read about the Jug UpcycleÂ * Here *Â  Â  & the taller Frame UpcycleÂ * Here *This wee girl spends her Saturday mornings on the Counter at the SPCA shop & is quite a hit with the regular customers.Â  I asked if I could take a photo of her - she was very social & seemed to really enjoy all the pats & attention.Â Back in early May I entered a Mothers Day Giveaway run by Joy fromÂ "The Joy Within" .. & was delighted to be informed I had won it!!Â  Â The prize was a Gift Voucher & one of Joy's repurposed Squished Tin's.Â  Joy delivered my prize while I was down at Mums & I hope to use the Voucher to attend one of her classes at some stage.Thank You So much for stopping by today dear friends ğŸ’•I shall get round to visiting you all at your blogs as soon as I can,Right now I am off to make something sweet & sugary that satisfies my craving & no doubt, goes straight to my Hips ğŸ˜‰ !!!Wishing you a wonderful rest-of-the-week,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Bunting, Peat Pots & Gourds
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersJust trying to squeeze in one last post before we wave goodbye to May.My dear friend Jane asked if I could please make her a white doiley bunting using a mixture of crochet ones & vintage embroidered ones.Â  Luckily I had a fairly substantial stash ğŸ˜‰ as Jane wanted it 4 metres long.Bunting is really quite tricky to photograph unless you hang it somewhere.Â I did send Jane the above photo of Miss Pip very kindly "ironing" the doilies for me ... & promised to pick all the ginger hairs out before giving her the bunting.Jane was absolutely thrilled with her bunting & I have yet to go visit her & see it hanging up. ğŸ’•On my last visit to Mum's I very briefly caught up with my friend Joy fromÂ " the Joy Within ".Â  Joy presented me with this little kitsetÂ above in case I wanted to do some crafting while at Mum's.Â  The kit included some peat pots, chalk paint, mod-podge & a beautiful selection of serviettes.Â  Joy holds workshops in her "she shed" where she teaches chalk painting & I had seen the peat pots done but never had a go.Â  I thought this was so incredibly kind of her.Â Â Let me tell you dear friends ........ those peat pots are Sooooo addictive!!Â Â In fact they are so addictive that I found myself driving to Mitre 10 hardware store in the middle of a thunderstormÂ to purchase more !!!Â  You just dry brush the chalk paint on & then embellish with the serviettes to your hearts content.Â  SoÂ Much Fun!I decided to make up a little gift package using 3 of the peat pots for a dear friend.Â  Â I filled One with lovely choccies, One with a tiny baby tears plant & the other One I made up a small French Pear Soy Candle into a glass container that just fit perfectly in the pot.I cut up a cardboard cereal box & covered with scrapbooking paper (& a paper doiley) to sit my 3 peat pots on ..........Â .......... before wrapping the whole thing in cellophane & adding a tag.Â  I left it in my friends porch to surprise her ğŸ˜Šwhen she got home.Way back at the beginning of September inÂ * this post *Â - Sid & I planted some Dinosaur Gourd seeds.Â  We finally harvested them last week & below is what we grew from the one packet of seeds.I'm not too sure why they called them dinosaur gourdsÂ but Sid pointed out to me that the long one looked a bit like aÂ Brachiosaurus's neckÂ !Speaking of Sid ... he had his school disco last week & it was dress up.Â  He went as a Tiger & his Mum sent me this photo above just before he went out to the Disco.Â  ğŸ¯Yesterday I had a Baking day.Â  I made Banana Cake from some bananas that were turning, & then aÂ no-bake Apricot Slice with a delicious cream cheese icing.Â  I plan to give most of this away as otherwise I am tempted to eat it & those jeans didn't get tight all by themselves Julie !! ğŸ˜‰I saw the above Verse on Instagram & it really appealed to me.Â  Things are "very messy & difficult"Â with matters relating to my Mum of late & I just have to keep going & trust that it will be okay in the end.Â Thank You dear friends - as always - for your visits here today,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Catching Up ...............  Part (3)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersFinally - after this post - I should be all caught up again ğŸ˜‰Thank You for staying with me through these lengthy Catch Up posts.Finally today our permit came through so we could light our new fire - & we are currently having a thunderstorm so the timing was perfect !Last week my dear friend Sandy hosted a Pink Ribbon Morning tea for a small group of friends.Â  Sandy has hosted these in the past as we like to celebrate the journey back to wellness of our dear friend Pam, who has battled cancer twice.Â  I always enjoy going out to Sandy's as everything she does is just to exquisite taste & I knew the morning tea would be special.As expected it was just superb & the pink theme was so perfect & pretty.Â  Â ğŸ’—Â  Sandy had mixed up a pink drink with soda water & we had pink straws, pink plates, serviettes & even pink coasters.Â  Pink candles were burning & a large vase of pink flowers.We enjoyed pink cupcakes, pink macaroons, pink heart marshmallows,Â  club sandwiches & Sandy had even made shortbread in the pink ribbon logo & iced this with pink icing sprinkled with pink & white hearts ğŸ’•Â  The entire table setting just made you want to smile.Our get-together's always go by so fast & before we knew it, it was early afternoon.Â  Upon leaving Sandy presented us each with a beautiful potted Cyclamen.I am lucky indeed to enjoy such friendships & it's so nice to get together & celebrate as we all lead busy lives & the months go by very fast before we manage to catch up.I have not done a display on my coffee table sinceÂ my Valentine's attempt.Â  Â  I just got tired of the furry two always sitting amongst my treasures & then I'd clear it all off for Sid to do play dough on Tuesdays ....Â  I kind of gave up for awhile.Â Â However last week I decided to do another vignette with lots of candles as I love to burn them through our dark winter months.Â  I took a piece of advise from my dear friend Claire who said to decorate every spare inch & leave No room for any furry 4-legged beings to sit!Â  Â Lots of Op-shopped junkÂ treasures used for displays !!I used trays to cover nearlyÂ  all the table & then did some candle, plant & vintage book displays on the trays. I really enjoyed this, using up items from my ratherÂ largeÂ stash.Â  I was so proud of myself when I'd finished & even made The Mr come & have a look.Â  (he was not in slightest bit interested)Well dear friends .............................................Â you can see how well that worked out for me .......................................................In case you're wondering .... Yes he ISÂ crying at me because I haven't left him any room to sit !!!!!Â  ğŸ˜Last Sunday my eldest grandson Alec turned the big 7 !!Â He had a birthday party & his Mum made him a wonderful chocolate mud cake.Sarah, his Mum had gone to lots of trouble organising games to occupy all the children that came - a lovely mix of both boys & girls.I especially loved this game above ... seems only yesterday my own boys were playing Pin the tail on the Donkey!Â Â Now its "Pin the tail on the Dinosaur."Â  Â I loved seeing where all the tails ended up ... one even completely on the next window frame !!! ğŸ˜‰Saw this on Instagram & loved it !!Â Thanks again dear friends, for your ever-welcome visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend where-ever you are ... be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to You All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: Catching Up  ..........  Part (2)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersHere I am still playing "catch up" on my blog posts from my recent trip to Mum's & before that ........My sister-in-law told me about a new store that had opened about 10 minutes from Mums, out on the Coast road.Â  As I'm always looking for places to take Mum for a drive I thought it might be nice to drive out & visit it.Â Â The store is calledÂ Brandy's BotanicalsÂ  -Â  the Owner Debbie has had a wonderful barn built on her property in order for her to sell her plants, seeds & other Giftware.It was really lovely & a wonderful selection with lots to look at plus the Owner was just so lovely & friendly.Â Â My photos Do NotÂ do it justice - it really was packed to the brim with plants that she had mainly grown all herself - plus a wonderful selection of seeds & some very unusual varieties.Mum chose this glazed pot & I helped her find the sweet little trailing plant to go in it.I bought myself 3 small size houseplants as well as 3 packets of seeds & the Owner tossed in the other 2 packets for free ğŸ˜ŠOn the subject of houseplants ... I noticed my poor Peace Lily was looking rather root-bound & in need of a re-pot.Â  I fossicked around under my house & found this old terracotta pot which needed a good scrub with lots of "elbow grease".Â  It has the odd chip in it but this just adds to the overall effect I feel. ğŸ˜‰After scrubbing & drying it well I gave it 2 coats of Pumice Chalk Paint & then applied a new transfer that I had ordered fromÂ * Here *.Â  I then sprayed it with 2 coats of matt finish acrylic varnish, just to protect it well.I gave my Peace Lily a good root prune before repotting it in fresh potting mix.Â  It just looks so much happier now & will hopefully flower again when spring comes.Prior to my trip to Mums my dear friend Jane requested a doll order for her Aunts 70th birthday.Â  Jane knew exactly the pattern she wanted - a Rosalie Quinlan doll called Ruby from an old craft magazine (Homespun I think)Â Jane requested that I make the doll in her Aunt's favourite colours of blues & greens ... "vivid retro florals" was Jane's words.Â  I was able to find exactly this in my vintage sheet collection, & Jane chose the homespun check for the bloomers.Â Â In Rosalie's pattern the tag reads "dear Mummy, I love you" but Jane asked me to stitch "Happy 70th Aunty Colleen".Â Â The pattern has a loop sewn to the dolls hand so she can be hung but is equally as nice sitting on a bed or a chair.Â  Jane tells me her Aunt Loved the doll & plans to hang her in her sewing room.Â  ğŸ’™We had a stretch of frosts last week & it was Oh So Chilly.Â  These two spend most of the day tucked up on a blanket on my bed keeping warm together.I think I have one more Catch Up Post to put together friends,Thank You for your visits here today - I am off to collect Sid as we have a couple of hours together after school on Tuesdays.Wishing you all a wonderful rest-of-the-week,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: A Catching Up Post .......... Part (1)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have been away down to my Mum's (Yes again!!)Â & I have lots of blogging to catch up on hence I decided on a couple of "catch up posts".The Mr snapped this pic last night after he had gone down to shut the cows away ... such a stunning sunset followed by a very chilly night.I have a new Grandson of the furry variety ğŸ˜‰My daughter in law found this dear little kitten living wild in the long grass on their rural road.Â  She caught it & took him to the Vets - he had Cat Flu, Conjunctivitis & a myriad of other things wrong ... rather a sad state of affairs & barely 6 weeks old according to the Vet.Sarah, my daughter in law, asked me if I had any blankets that I could share with her for the kitten.Â  I set to & cut up some thrifted cuddlies & also some wool blankets that I had on hand.Â  I overlocked all the edges of them & then Pippi tried them out for me for "comfort & snug-ability" ğŸ˜‰Here is the kitten (originally named Felix) after just 10 days of good food, medication & LotsÂ of love & care.Â  He is trying out the new blanket above right.Â  My Grandson Alec has now named him Bruno which believe me is alot better than his first choice which was Sharky !!Such a dear wee thing & full of mischiefÂ  ... Bruno has landed on his feet with his new home & will be very much loved & adored.Â  ğŸ’™The week I was away at Mums my youngest Grandson Sid had his last day at Daycare & got to wear the "Leaving Cloak" above left.Â  Then he had his first week at school, which he loves & just adores his new teacher.Â  (If you look closely you will notice he has had a haircut before starting school & also you might notice he was wearing his school uniform to DaycareÂ  !!!)I took a slightly different route down to Mum's this time & went via the City & then around the Coast so I could catch up with two dear friends.Â  My sister in law Felicity has a Groovy newÂ Coffee CartÂ & I loved her blackboard verse.The reason I took the coast road was so I could visit my dear friend Carolyn who had just celebrated a special birthday.Â  I made her one ofÂ Jennifer "Books & Roses" bookmarks to go withÂ * this book * which I had bought for her.Â I knew she had recently had a vintage chair re-upholstered & I decided to make her a Roundie Cushion to sit on her new/old chair.Â  I had this piece of Vintage Barkcloth fabric in my stash & hoped the colours might be suitable.Carolyn was absolutely delighted with her gifts & the new cushion just fit perfectly on the chair.Â  I have given her a copy of the pattern as I thought she might like to make some more.Â  It is out ofÂ my "Granny Chic" BookÂ You will be surprised to learn that I only visited One Op Shop on the entire trip!!Â  Â I actually called in to Spotlight while in the city & when I came back out to my car I saw there was a Salvation Army Op-Shop right next door so I popped in.Â  I noticed this cane chair for $30 & remembered that Mum had asked me if I would take her to buy a chair for her small front porch.Â  I thought this might be ideal & it was in excellent condition.Â Â I walked back to my car, sat in it for 5 minutes & then went back in & bought it.Â  Mum was delighted with it & can get in & out of it easily - plus it fits well in the small space.Â  I have traced off a pattern to make her a squab for the seat part.Â  When she tires of it, I can soon find a space here for it. ğŸ˜‰Before my trip I found this old muffin tin in my cupboard - a 50 cent find in the Op Shop bargain bin (my favourite place ğŸ˜‰)I painted it with 2 coats of Pumice Chalk Paint & then lightly distressed it.Â  I applied these Re-design by Prima knob transfers that I bought ages ago - using a different one for each circle.Â Â I first saw this idea onÂ * this Youtube video *Â as I am a subscriber to "Julie's designs & signs" & love what she creates.Â  Julie used stamps on her muffin pan but I didn't have any stamps & felt the knob transfers fit perfectly. She also decorated the underside of her tin.I hung it in my kitchen on the old rake that I have hanging there & love how it turned out ğŸ’—You can read my post about the Rake upcycleÂ * Here *I saw this Verse on Instagram & thought how very true !Thank you So much for your visits today dear friends ... I will be back soon with Part (2)Wishing you a wonderful rest-of-the-week,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: My Thrifting Haul(s)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersLongtime readers of my blog will know that I love to frequent thrift stores & Op-shops.Â  I don't always find purchases but it gives me so much pleasure when I do come away with some new-to-meÂ junkÂ treasures.Â  My many trips down to Mum's this year (6 so far) have seen me stop at lots of Op-shops in my travels & I realised I had not shared my hauls from the last two trips.Half an hour from Mum's town I pass through the township of Stratford. I really like their Hospice Shop - clean, well laid out, good stock & reasonable prices.Â  These items above were all from there.Â  In case you might think that I buy these items & then don't especially do anythingÂ with them, I thought I'd share what I've done with some of the items in the above haul.Â Â Â The beautiful hard-cover book above was $5 & still like brand new.Â  I bought it for Juno & it made a nice Easter gift along with the Carrot Treat BagÂ I had made for her.The Miranda Hart book ($1) is to gift to my friend Gail who absolutely LovesÂ anything Miranda.Â I am half way through reading the Sophie Kinsella book ($1) & then I'll pass this on to a friend.The $1 piece of Linen has been washed, ironed & put away with my offcuts of Linen - I always pick up Linen when I see it at Op-shops as it is so pricey in the Sewing shops.The small wooden stool above was $8.Â  I painted this over Easter with 2 coats chalk paint in the colour Vintage White.It made a perfect riser for a small Easter display I had done & will be handy throughout the year for table displays.These two tall glass candle holders were $2.50 each. Although they don't match I knew I had a boxful of small candles at home that I was sure would fit in them perfectly.Â  They look wonderful tucked into another display on my round table & I will be lighting & enjoying them soon.This haul above is from the Hospice Shop in Mum's small town - again another very good shop to visit.Â  The needlework framed picture was $5 & this too got painted over Easter as the frame was chipped & tatty.I used the chalk-paint colour Old Linen which seemed to match the background fabric perfectly.Â  I Love how this turned out. ğŸ’—This heavy crystal vase was $3 & I made a soy candle up into it - these are handy to have on hand for gifts. The fragrance is French Pear & it smells divine.Â  The wee floral jug ($2) will also have a candle made into it once my new order of soy wax arrives.The round jar (you can only see the Lid of it in my haul photo) was 50c.Â  I needed a good sized jar to keep some vintage buttons in & this was ideal plus I loved the shape of it.Â  Any household items that I purchase are put through my dishwasher as soon as I get them home as I find this brings them up clean & shiny.The china cups & saucers above were bought from the SPCA shop - they were pricey at $10 a pair but I was sure they matched some china I already had - the jug & bowl above right.How pretty they look amongst my collection of green china ware.Â ğŸ’šAlmost all of the china on this dresser has been thrifted.Another thing I always pick up is wooden embroidery hoops as these too are expensive in the Sewing Shops.Â  This one above was 50c & it just fit this sweet little stitchery that I had completed while down at Mums.Â  It looked a bit bland so I painted around it with some leftover blue chalk-paint & this seemed to really bring it to life.Â  The pattern is available fromÂ Twig & Tale Designs.We have had beautiful autumn days this past week & I've worked outside pulling one of my raised veggie gardens to bits & giving the soil a good feed before I plant for winter.Â  I harvested many green peppers which I froze & the last of my tomatoes.Â  I also harvested some self-sown pumpkins.Â  While at Mitre 10 buying sheep pellets for my soil I noticed their Bulbs were all half price so I purchased 2 packs of daffy's which are now in the ground.Since my return home Fat Blackie has taken up residence in the craft cupboard at the end of the hallway.Â  The door doesn't latch properly so he is able to get his paw around & open it. He is currently sleeping on a stack of nicely ironed linen tablecloths that I had just done.Â  Yesterday when I tried to get some fabric out from under him he hissed at me, the little so & so ğŸ˜’Thank you so very much for your visits today dear friendsWishing you a wonderful week ahead - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Mum's 93rd Birthday  ........  & Some Easter Makes
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI hope you all had a wonderful Easter - it felt like it went by in the blink of an eye.Just before my last post I returned from a week down at my Mum's.Â  During this visit Mum celebrated her 93rd birthday.Â  She didn't wish to have a "celebration" as such, but my two sons & their families had arranged to all travel down & surprise herÂ I really love this photo of Mum with my eldest grandson Alec ... they look like they have been up to some sort of mischief together ğŸ˜‰Mum with her two great-grandsons, Sid & Alec.Mum with my eldest son Aaron & his wife Sarah - (Alec's parents)Mum with my youngest son Kayne & his wife Nicole - (Sid's parents)We had a delicious finger-food lunch (catered for by yours-truly)Â followed by a sweet course.Â  My brother & his wife came as well so there were 10 of us around Mums kitchen table & we only just fit.I made Mum a chocolate mud cake & she got to blow out 3 candles for "yesterday, today & tomorrow".Â  It was such a lovely day & nice to all get together again after so long.My lovely friend Jane & I did a labour swap last year.Â  Â I sewed a Tilda Cat for her & in exchange Jane cross stitched this sweet Rabbit design for me.Â  This is a free download fromÂ Whilst Iris Naps website.Â I left the colour choices up to Jane & I absolutely LoVe what she chose to stitch it up in.Just prior to Easter I decided to sew it up into a simple small size cushion which I filled with crushed walnut shells to make it sit up nicely on my table.Â  I finished it off by hand-stitching this fluffy yarn around the outer edge.Â Â This Bunnie pattern was purchased about 3 years ago now fromÂ The Makers StudioÂ .Â  Â Once again I came across it & decided to sew a couple up.Â  I found the lovely piece of pale green linen - an Opshop purchase which looked like someone had started a cut-work piece & never completed it.Â  Â (I alwaysÂ pick up linen when I see it in the Op-shops)I made both sizes, one in cream linen & the other in the pale green.Â  I used Tilda scraps for their ears & embellishments.I added fine florist wire inside their ears to make them stand up a bit moreSuch a sweet design & fun to stitch up.Â  It will be hard to pack them away after Easter I think.The silver tray above left, was a $3 Op-shop purchase on one of my recent trips to Mums. I needed something about this size & shape for a "carrot bundle" I was making.Â  Over Easter I gave it a couple of coats of pale grey chalk paint.I'd seen an image of this Carrot bundle on Pinterest & it had stayed in my head (!!!) ğŸ˜‰.Â  I sewed them up using scraps of fabrics - the carrot tops are just Jute String unraveled ... it gets this wavy curly effect.Â  Â My Primitive Carrot bundle just fits perfectly on the newly painted tray.Likewise for this frame - yes, another 50 cent Opshop find.Â  I took the backing off, painted it the same grey as the tray & then hot-glued this birdnest, bird & real branches off my Plum Tree to the frame.Â  Another idea from the myriad of ones that float around inside my head !!!My only purchase this Easter was the sweet little felted rabbit in the purple jumper - I adored him ğŸ’œInstead of decorating my Coffee Table for Easter this year, I decided to decorate my Lounge Mantle.Â  This is mainly because of the 4-legged furry friends that SitÂ amongst my decorations !!Â I thought (hoped) the mantle was too high for them to get up ğŸ˜‰I just used all Easter decorations from previous years & the Peter Rabbit bunting was purchased from Spotlight.Â Â The grouping of calico rabbits I sat in the chamber pot which I purchasedÂ in * this post * ... & sat this on the plant stand which I revampedÂ in * this post *Well done & Thank YouÂ if you've stayed to the end dear friends,Its been another looonnng post,Wishing you all a wonderful Wednesday,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: My Valentine's  " LOVE " Swap Gifts From Claire  ğŸ’—
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have been away down to my Mum's again but I will share that visit in another post.Â  Â Â Â Regular readers of my blog will remember the Valentine's Love Swap that my friend Claire & I didÂ in this Post * Here *Â  Â  Â It was time for me to receive my swap gifts from Claire & Oh My ... how VeryÂ spoilt was I !!??-Â  Flowers picked from my garden for my daughter in law's birthdayÂ  -Â I had planned to visit Claire on my last trip but the slip made me So much laterÂ as I took a different (longer)Â route.Â  Â  Â  Â  I texted her to say "it's probably too late now" only to be told "NO - I'm expecting you". Upon my arrival she sat me down with a hot cuppa & a plate of home-made pizza bread.Â  It was just the tonic I needed & next thing ... this BeautifulÂ pink hat box was placed in my lap.Â Claire had been going to donate it but then decided to revamp it to house my swap gifts in ... how stunning & perfect it was ğŸ’—This is what it looked like inside when I lifted the Lid ..........Four parcels each wrapped in a vintage linen tea-cloth & a Tilda envelope attached, tied up with a big pink bow !Oh Be Still My Rapidly Beating Heart ..........Â  ğŸ’—These are the wooden letters (above)Â which Claire painted & decorated.LÂ stands for Love-hearts ... a beautiful Love heart quilt made using Tilda fabrics ... & quilted with hearts ğŸ’•& a tube of Love Heart sweets.OÂ stands for "the shape" ... yet another gorgeous quilt made using O-shaped blocks, quilted in O's & even an "O" cross stitch label on the back.Â  Also a delightful handmade ceramic O-shaped bowl.(I think about this point in time - I may have cried !!!)V stands for Violet & for "V"Â Â ... a smaller size quilt made using V shaped blocks (gorgeous vintage Tilda),Â a Violet-coloured "Scissor wall-hanging" in a V-shape,Â  some tiny Embroidery scissors & 3 Velour hearts with Tilda Angels attached.If you look closely you may notice the M & M's packet is empty - I blame that ginger cat of mine !!E stands for Envelope & Easter Eggs !!!Â  A square shaped table quilt with Envelope blocks on it & two bagsÂ of Easter Eggs.Â Each package had one of these hand-sewn Tilda Envelopes with it & a handwritten notecard insideÂ Here are the 4 Vintage embroidered tablecloths once I have ironed them all ... just gorgeous.Â Yesterday was the first chance I have had to even think about how to display my beautiful new treasures & I am sure I will continue to change my mind & re-arrange things.Â  This is a small display on the edge of my TV cabinet using the Envelope table quilt.The Love hearts quilt fits perfectly over an armchair & the Tilda Summer pillow, a gift fromÂ my dear friend Leeanne,Â  just compliments it so well.Â  The V-shaped quilt tucked under a small display of china in similar colourings.,I stitched a quilt hanger to the Scissor quilt & hung it in my sewing room along with a velvet bow ... but Claire informs me I have it upside down (!!!)Â  I shall have to rectify this ğŸ˜‰As you can imagine dear friends - I am just so happy with all my swap gifts - in fact, happy doesn't really do it justice.Â  Just So Much Love sewn in to each & every piece ğŸ’• Claire's handwork is absolutely stunning!!Thank you dear readers, if you've stayed to the end of this photo-heavy post.Â Wishing each & every one of you a Blessed Easter ... I hope you get to spend it however you choose.Â  For me it will be a quiet one & believe me when I say - Quiet is perfectly fine with me !Thank you as always, for your visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: A Wedding, An Ambulance, & A Special Birthday
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersIt has been an eventful week & then yesterday ... we welcomed in another shiny new month ... April ğŸ’šExactly a week ago today my Stepson & his Fiance got married in a stunning part of theÂ Hamilton Gardens.Â  Â If you google Hamilton Gardens Medici Court Images,Â  you can see much better photos than I have taken.Â It was the most beautiful Autumnal day & the wedding was extra special because this was their 3rd attempt - having been forced to cancel twice last year due to Lockdowns.Â  Â Then my Stepson went down with Covid, only coming out of his isolation the day before the wedding.Â  To say we were all holding our breath is an understatement.Â Â My photos are not great - I am always conscious of professional wedding photographers & their protocol so I only clicked a couple of snaps.The beautiful Bride & Groom after the service.Their wee girl Juno (nearly 2 now) had been given a new rabbit to match her new dress.Â  She did so well at the service & just sat quietly with the bride's brother without making a peep.A rare photo of me with my youngest son & his wife.Â  Kayne & JaredÂ  (the groom) grew up together & have remained close.Â Â After the service we travelled toÂ Hayes CommonÂ for the reception. The florists had done a stunning job of framing the entrance with the same sorts of flowers used in the girls bouquets.Â After a delicious meal a pink Icecream Van pulled up outside the venue & we were all to order any sort of icecream we fancied.Â  We all wanted to loosen our belts after this evening !! ğŸ˜‰(Again - I forgot to snap pics & the ones I took of the couple dancing have come out blurry.)On the morning of the wedding as I was heading to a friends to get my hair done I got a phone call to say my 92 year old Mum had had another fall & been carted off in an ambulance.Â  This did tend to put a dampner on the days celebrations for me as I was so worried about Mum.The next morning when I learned Mum was still in hospital awaiting a CT scan I decided to head off down there. I was having a relatively uneventful drive until I encountered this huge landslide.Â  You can read about it * Here *.I was only the 3rd vehicle back & I was on the other side to this pic.Â  (this is the newspapers photo I have shown)I ended up taking a different route going back, then inland - a journey that normally takes me 4 hours ended up taking me nearly 7. It was a long day & I was pleased to arrive safely at Mums house.After 4 nights Mum was discharged from hospital (nothing broken) & I took her home to her place.Â  I then drove home again late Thursday afternoon but I will return to look after Mum next week & this will be ongoing until a bed comes up in the Resthome just up the road from where Mum lives.The reason I wanted to return home was because yesterday,Â  April 1st - was a special birthday in whichÂ Sid wasÂ turning 5 !!Â  Â Â ğŸˆI spent yesterday morning wrapping presents & baking & then we had his little birthday celebration in the afternoon.One of his requests was for a dinosaurÂ piniata which gave all the children lots of pleasure until they managed to get it to burst open & lollies pour out.And then this sweet little photo appeared in my inbox this morning of Sid with the Crocodile Lego set I gave him.Â I can hardly believe this boy is now 5 years old & will start school at the beginning of May.Â  Â Â I will miss my Tuesdays-with-Sid.Â I was able to briefly catch up with my dear friend Claire before Mum came home from hospital & she gifted me my swap gifts from our Valentines Love swap that IÂ wrote about in * this post *Oh My !!! What treasures !!Â  I shall share those in my next post as I feel this one is already long enough.Thank You all So Very MuchÂ for your visits today,My posts & my visits to your blogs may be a bit erratic for awhile,Take care of yourselves dear friends - sending love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: Carrots,  Fireplaces  &  Contrary Cats
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersIt has been another busy week but Oh I am loving these March Autumn days with the chilly mornings & evenings ... I just adore them ğŸ’–I came acrossÂ this Carrot Treat Bag tutorial free on the Internet & thought what a wonderful idea they would be to make for my Grandchildren & pop a few Easter goodies in.Â  I was able to get 3 made up using orange & green fabrics already in my stash & thought they looked wonderful with the Easter tags I madeÂ in my last post.Â The only thing I needed to buy - besides the choccy - was 1 metre each of green & orange ribbon.Â (The Bunnie tag is to pop away for a rabbit I hope to sew one day)Then yesterday an Order arrived in the post from Love from Seventeen.Â  I often buy their seasonal tags to attach to gifts so the wee rabbits will be perfect tied around my Carrot treat bags.Â We have had Tradesmen here most days this past week as we had our old fireplace removed & a new one fitted.Â Â This is what the cavity looked like once the old one was removed - I did paint around the edges before the newÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â one went in.While I was doing this I observed all the colours the fireplace had been.Â  When we first moved in 20 + years ago I had thought it was a muddy cream colour but looking at this now I see it was more a dirty pink.Â  I remember when everyone had gone to bed late one night I found a tin of British Racing Green paint in The Mr's shed & painted it green.Â  I could not get the pink colour clean no matter now much I scrubbed it.Â  Then it was a dark burgundy for awhile before I lightened itÂ in this Post * here *It is a process now to change a fireplace.Â  Once the old one is removed you cannot fit the new one until a Building Inspector has checked the cavity first.Â  Here is Blackie checking out the new firebox & telling me there is no need to send a Building Inspector out - he can do just as good a job at checking everything ğŸ˜‰!!Here is our lovely new firebox.Â  We have a fan fitted in the bottom grill so this had to be wired in by an Electrician. Tomorrow at 8 am the Slate man is coming as the Hearth needs to be an inch wider to get our building consent.Â  As you can imagine Miss Pip is beside herself with all these Tradies here every single day & not impressed at all !!I went to pick up a presciption last week & noticed a new Op Shop in the old Bank building - an SPCA one.Â  So I went for a look & a purchase as it would be incredibly rude of me not to support them ğŸ˜‰I came away with the plant stand for $10 - the lovely vintage fabric above left was $2 & $3, & the plaster cherubs were $4 each.Â Â While the men were fitting the fireplace & I was keeping out of their way, I painted the plant stand with 2 coats of chalk paint - Antique White.Â  I will show you in my next post what I have used it for.Some self seeded tomatoes have gone wild in my veggie garden & this is what I am picking every 2nd day.Â  The cherry ones are especially sweet & delicious.Â I took Sid to our little local Park last Tuesday & he wanted me to take a photo of the clouds - they were so fluffy & wonderful that day & the sky was Oh so blue ğŸ’™Whilst I was still keeping-out-of-tradies-wayÂ I made up another batch of miracle spray. You can find the recipeÂ * here * Â This is all I use for my cleaning - it is wonderful & a batch lasts me a very long time.Lastly dear friends -Â  I had left my (undies!!) drawer open while rushing out the door to an early appointment.Â  Upon arriving home I found a certain ginger being curled up sound asleep in it.Â  I posted this photo on Instagram & it got so many lovely comments.Â  The next day I was contacted by a PetModels Inc. Company telling me they were interested in pets like this & would I be willing to work with them??And Yes there were ginger hairs all through my "smalls" ğŸ˜Thank You Very much but NoÂ ThankÂ You!!Â  This little ginger friend is alreadyÂ HIGH MAINTENANCE ENOUGHÂ without the thought of modelling going to her tiny fluffy head!!Â  And she is so contrary I could imagine the whole thing being a complete nightmare!!Â  Â So not a word has been mentioned to her about it ğŸ˜‰Thank You So Very Much for your visits here today dear friends,I hope the coming week treats you well - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Craft Group Get-togethers, a Mirror, & a Potty (!!)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWhen a New Year rolls around our small Craft Group usually get together & have an informal meeting to work out a rough programme for the year ... things we would like to create/learn/try etc ...After my visit toÂ The Tree Church inÂ * this post * I thought the ladies might like to get together Here for our first meeting & to work out our programme.Â  Due to various other commitments this didn't happen until late February but it was a beautiful summery day when we went.Just look at that beautiful Blue Sky !!!I had made a slice & some gingernut balls & Gail had made sausage rolls - everyone bought their own thermos flask & we sat in the shade & had our morning tea & wrote down some ideas for various activities throughout the coming year.There are usually 7 of us but only 6 could make it that dayWe also went for a big long leisurely walk around the Tree Church & Gardens.I could quite easily fill my post with soÂ manyÂ photos - it is honestly such a stunning place to visit.Â  It closes soon for the winter months & then re-opens again in the spring time.Whenever I go down to Mum's I buy packets of these wooden cut-outs from a Variety Store in her small town.Â  I had put together some Easter themed tags by mod-podging paper serviettes on to them & thought the ladies might like to have a go at this at our next meeting.Â Â Also the ladies each had to bring a painted bottle or jar so we could decorate these with mod-podged serviettes.Â  We all met at my home last Monday - it was such a fun activity & everyone had some tags & a decorated bottle to take home with them.We had a delicious lunch together & as always, there was an abundance of good home-made food.Â  The finished bottles all decorated top right.Â  Â  Â I forgot to get a pic of everyone's tags at the end.Another Hospice store find on my last trip to Mum's was this $5 mirror.Â  The entire mirror panel from the centre was missing & it was all rather sad looking ... however I could see it definately "hadÂ potential"Â ğŸ˜‰It cost $17 to have a new mirror panel put in the centre which I thought was really reasonable considering they also had to put a piece of board in to attach the mirror to.Â  I noticed some gaps in the corner joins so I filled these with Polyfilla.Â  It was a simple job because I had "good help" on hand to assist me & ensure I didn't miss any bits ğŸ˜‰Then I set about painting the mirror with two coats of Soft Duck Egg Chalk Paint.Â  Once I was happy with the coverage I lightly distressed the whole piece & then Very lightlyÂ rubbed some silver embossing wax over the decorative edges of the frames.I had thought the hinges looked like brass so I was able to bring a bit of shine back to them with some Brasso ... also the tiny ball feet were brass.Â  I am So pleased I didn't paint over these but took the time to mask them out first.I just love my new/old mirror & it fits perfectly in the corner of my dining room with a set of fairy lights wound around it.Â  My dining room can be dark at times & I find the addition of mirrors helps to throw some light into darker corners.I follow Kim atÂ Rosebud Collectables over on Instagram & she posts some real treasures for sale but I always seem to miss out on them.Â  When I saw this vintage chamber pot I quickly messaged to ask if I may purchase it & was lucky enough to be the first.Â Â It arrived last week & when I opened the box it was bigger, heavier & more beautiful than I had imagined.Â Â I have displayed it with a maidenhair fern for now but I am thinking that some Easter bunnies in a small group inside it would be rather lovely for Easter ...............I just adore the flowers on it ... & the colours.Â  ğŸ’—Â Way, way too nice for it's original purpose !!Thank You all So Very Much for your visits here today dear friends,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship To You All,Julie & the furry ones title: A " L O V E "  Swap For Valentines Day  ğŸ’—
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersSome of you may remember the TILDAÂ swap my lovely friend Claire & I did early last year.Â  You can read about itÂ in * this post *Â & alsoÂ in * this post *We both got so much pleasure from the swap that Claire suggested we do another one this year ... a LOVE Swap aimed for Valentine's Day.Â  The objective is that you make things that begin with the letters L O V E.Â Our swaps are always very flexible with no rules as such, which is what I enjoy (no pressure) ğŸ˜‰" L is for Lovely Little Lavender hearts "Â I began working on this last year & for some reason, I cannot find any of my photos ... but I took a silver thrifted tray & painted it with Pumice Chalk Paint.Â  Then I delved into my treasured vintage Tilda fabrics & made 6 hearts which I filled with my homegrown lavender.The "Good Friends"Â stitchery panel was purchased fromÂ * Here *Â & is aÂ Natalie Bird Design.Â  After sewing into a tiny pillow I stuffed it tightly with crushed walnut shells.Â  The ceramic Home Sweet HomeÂ plaque was purchased from a local Gift Store." L is (also)Â for LovelyÂ Large Lace Heart with Pocket "ThisÂ  comes from an idea I saw on Pinterest.Â  I stitched a large heart & stuffed it tightly, then I added a doiley pocket & embellished my heart with vintage laces, braids, mother-of-pearl buttons & a broken earing from my oddments of old jewellery.Â I filled my pocket with a soap, some dried lavender sprigs, rolled up music paper & a tea-dyed tag." O is for Overalls "This is made using a free patternÂ * here * scroll half way down the page on the Tilda Website.Â  However the overalls are actually for the Tilda Cow but I decided to didn't want to make Claire a CowÂ  -Â  Â I much preferred the Cat which isÂ also free * here *Â Â I sewed the Overalls using fabrics from the Old Rose Tilda range.I stitched a tiny woodenÂ Theodora Cleave Cat Button button to the bodice of my OverallsÂ  .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â Â I also used matching Tilda buttons on the overalls straps.Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  & then stitched this sweet ceramic heart to its handsÂ Â pawsğŸ¾Â "Â VÂ is for Vintage Vase with Candle & (also) for Verse "I had this wonderful heavy Vintage Crystal Vase in my collection so I made up a soy candle in it,Â  in the fragrance French Pear.Â Â This Verse is a free stitchery download from the beautiful blogÂ Nana Company * here *Â ... this is the 2nd time I have stitched this up & framed using a thrifted embroidery hoop."Â EÂ is for English Paper Piecing "The Tools drawstring bag was part of my Tilda Lover's Club Mystery Box fromÂ Fee Fee & MeÂ ... it came as a kitset in the box.Â  I purchased some "sewing tools" to pop inside the bag.The hexagon placemat is a pattern fromÂ * Here *Â which I purchased last year as a digital download.Â  I made it up using some of my treasured Tilda Windy Days fabrics.Â I sewed some of the pretty bias edging on the back of the placemat & then added in a box of tea & a vintage china cup/saucer from my own collection as I thought the colours all went so well together.Â  Claire informs me she will Not EverÂ be putting cups of tea on the mat ğŸ˜‰To package everything I wrapped all my items in pink tissue paper & then dove into my stash of brown paper bagsÂ  ...
