I decided to tizzy them up a bit as I found a piece of scrapbooking cardstock with lovely Valentines images on it.Â Â ğŸ’— L O V E ğŸ’—Whenever I want nicely shaped applique letters I always go to this free site.Â  I cut mine out from cardstockÂ then tied onto the bags with a length of stiff white tulle that I already had.Â  I really enjoy packaging & presenting things invitingly.Â On my recent trip to Mums I was able to catch up with my lovely friend & give her my swap gifts.Â  Although she had not finished mine at the time of my visit I still wanted her to open hers that day so I could enjoy sharing everything with her.Â  Â  It was such a pleasant couple of hours drinking tea, eating slice & enjoying each others company.Â  Here are all her gifts opened & sitting on her window seat above .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â Â .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  and here is my lovely friend sitting with all her new treasures.I am due to go back to Mums early April so I look forward to catching up with Claire again & opening all my swap gifts from her.Â  I will be sure to share them all with you.Thank You all SoÂ much if you've stayed all the way to the end.Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: Sometimes Blog Posts Just Won't Come ..............................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI have had these photos loaded for a few days now but have not been able to find blogging words to write down ... today is my 3rd attempt.I had to drop everything & drive down to my Mums again (3rd time this year) after she popped a Ligament in her knee.Â  I would like to say she is doing much better now but I can only say I think this is going to be a long slow process.Â  I also had Mum assessed for Resthome Care & she now has help coming in for five mornings a week - much to her disgust & annoyance. ğŸ˜‰Â For years I called Mt Taranaki a "she" but have been told it is a "he".Â  He was not wearing his usual white coat but was equally as spectacular looking & never fails to take my breath away when I come round a bend.Â  Quite by accident I found this cute little cafe in Inglewood called Lure Cafe.Â  I am so pleased I stopped my journey for a coffee & a caramel slice as it was just delightful.Â I was so busy photographing all the eclectic things inside I forgot to get an outside pic so this one is borrowed off their Facebook PageJellie the Pig in a paddock outside & a friendly Goat also.Delightful spaces to sit both inside & out.A gorgeous array of eclectic vintage treasures to be found in different rooms inside the Cafe.Along with my coffee & slice I made a purchase ... here is what I bought below ..........He (She ??) caught my eye & I could Not resist bringing him home with me.Â  The girl behind the Counter told me it was her own work which made it even more special to me.Â  I love to create but I also love to support fellow crafters by buying their work.And Yes dear friends, before you ask ... I did find some treasures at the op-shop ğŸ˜Š I love the Hospice Shop in Stratford - its clean & well laid out & very reasonable prices.Â Â This unusual metal urn was from the Hospice Shop in Hawera - $5 ... I plan to do something with it but just not quite sure what as yet.This book/letter rack was a $2.50 purchaseÂ back in * this post *Â at Christmas time - once again from the Stratford Hospice Shop.Â Â My friend Sally had gifted me these 2 beautiful books, one for my Birthday, one for Christmas.Â  I decided to revamp the book rack to display my books in so I gave it two coats of Chalk paint, Pale Duck Egg.Â  I had to sand the folk art flowers off the front first as their outline kept appearing through my paint.Some offcuts of Re-design transfers in keeping with the bee/butterfly theme, just completed the rack & the books look perfect sitting in it on display.Â I wondered why the tiny succulent cuttings I had planted in this old watering ram in my garden were not doing especially well.Â I think they have been somewhat flattened by a certain four-legged creature who weighs a tonne !!Sid is currently obsessed with all things Pokemon related.Â  Last week I looked up the names he told me on good-old-google & we found images & printed them off ... he spent happy hours cutting them all out & I learnt new names I had never even heard of !!! ğŸ˜‰Thank You So Very MuchÂ for stopping by today dear friends,I shall be back in a couple of days with a follow-up post,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Hearts ğŸ’—, Coffee Table Vignettes  ......  & Disobedient Cats ğŸ±
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersSome of you may remember the Tilda Swap I did with my friend ClaireÂ in * this post * early last year.Â  We both enjoyed it so much & we chatted about doing another Swap together.Â  Claire decided we should do a LOVE Swap for Valentine's Day this year.Â  I took my swap gifts down on my recent trip to Mum's but I can't post about what I made yet as they are still un-opened.Â Â Whilst browsing Pinterest for ideas this stunning but simple picture kept popping up on my feed.Â  I LoVed it so much ğŸ’—Source : PinterestJust prior to my trip to Mums I decided to do a new vignette on my lounge coffee table. I like to change this out with the seasons but had done nothing on it since clearing away my Christmas decor.Â  I decided to try & recreate the heart/basket picture.Â I knew I had this old chicken wire basket in my sleepout so I dug it out & gave it a wash.Â  These quilted pillow shams were an Op-shop purchase that I had initially planned to cut up but were in such perfect condition I didn't have the heart to.Â  I folded & stacked them in my wire basket.Using some oddments of fabrics & vintage laces I sewed & stuffed two hearts & added some mother-of-pearl button embellishments.Â  I really loved the effect of these sitting in the wire basket.My friend Joyce had gifted me this heavy cotton lace tablecloth for Christmas - Joyce works in the Church Op-shop so no doubt came across it in there. I loved it & once again, it was immaculate.Â  I arranged a vignette on my table just using up bits from around my Home & some thrifted finds ... candles, old books, vintage china - all my faves.Another thing I like to collect is Vintage Bibles, Prayer & Hymn BooksÂ  ... seen above on my book rack.Â  I mostly come across these in second hand bookstores & even have one written in Croatian.I felt so happy when my coffee table vignette was finished & the wire basket just set it off nicely - & I felt pleased that I had used treasures from around my Home.Â  Â  I sit beside this coffee table each night on the couch, & do my knitting or my stitchery work & watch TV.Â You know dear readers - I had thought that by covering the vintage lace tablecloth with Lots of display items there would NotÂ be room for any furry four-legged creatures to park their ample proportions on !!!Â It would appear I was Wrong !!!!Â Â Here is Madam Pip the other night watching the lovelyÂ Sherry Iris's Stitchy Podcast on YouTubeÂ  ......Â  Â & as if that wasn't enough, The Mr sent me this photo below while I was down at Mum's to tell me "everything is under control here"Â  !!! ğŸ˜–Seriously dear friends ... goodness knows how I managed to raise two sons into quite decent adults when I can't even get two cats to do as I want them toÂ  !!! ğŸ˜ŸI used the dried Rose Petals in my Potpourri'sWe are getting good light rain as I type this & I am so thankful.Â  This morning I picked all the roses that were about to drop their petals as this is a good time for drying them.Â  I spread them on cane trays in my Sleepout to dry.I also picked a bunch of mixed dahlias to enjoy inside.The Mr has gone to Auckland today on farm business so I made a banana cake this morning as I had banana's going brown.Â  I only ever ice half the cake as The Mr doesn't like icing & always picks it off.And I cooked myself my Most Favorite LunchÂ Ever - poached eggs fresh from the neighbors chooks, on toast with cherry tomatoes & basil straight from my garden.Â Â I saw this funny on Instagram & thought it was perfect ... I am off to clean up the Craftermath that is currently in my Sewing Room !!!Thanks so very much for your visits here today dear friends,With Much love & friendship to You All,Julie & the naughtyÂ furry Ones x0x0x

title: Away (Again)   ...............    & Back Again
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI see I have some new followers to my blog ...... A Very Warm WelcomeÂ to you All !!Â I have had to do another trip down to my Mum's this past week so I have missed catching up on your posts. But before I went away to Mum's Alec asked if he could come & stay again before the school year resumes.I took both my grandsons, Alec & Sid toÂ The Space CentreÂ which is just up the road from me & although I have driven past it a thousand times, I'd never been inside.Â  The boys loved it - especially Alec who is a bit older & very in to astronautical things.Alec wanted to craft again so out came all the sparkly bits & bobs from my craft drawers.Â  He wanted to makeÂ A Christmas Tree this time so I cut a shape out from felt & he was happy just to work out his placement & glue things on ... no sewing required ğŸ˜‰(I also have lots of apple cucumbers which I forgot to include in the photograph)I have an abundance of courgettes, cucumbers & green peppers in my veggie garden at present so I picked alot to take to Mums & give to other friends also.Â As I planned to call on my dear friend Carolyn en-route, I baked a Chocolate Fudge slice & a batch of Gingernut Bites - gave half to her & took the other half to Mum's.Remember the old aluminium pots I revampedÂ in my last Post ... well here is the smaller one which I wanted to gift to my friend Carolyn.Â  She loves YellowÂ so I painted it the same Pumice Chalk Paint as the larger one & then added a Sunflower ğŸŒ» Iron Orchid Transfer to it.I purchased a lovely sunny looking Calla lily that sat perfectly in the pot. I've left it up to Carolyn whether she plants it or uses the pot for something else.My brother had organised for Mums kitchen, dining & lounge ceilings to be plastered & painted while I was down there.Â  "You can take Mum out while the tradesmen are here" he told me.Â Â I thought this would be simple enough but what I hadn'tÂ  envisioned was that IÂ would be the one to empty the rooms, take Mum out, & then put everything back again once finished, whilst also cleaning Every Single Thing.Â  Â I felt like I had run a marathon when I finally got home again.On the 2nd day we had 4 hours to fill in so I took Mum up to the Garden of Remembrance at the Crematorium where my Dad's ashes are buried.Â  We took silk flowers & managed to find the plaque we had put there several years ago along with other silk flowers from previous visits.Â  Mum always feels better when she has visited DadÂ she says.On the way back I stopped in 2 Op-Shops in Stratford.Â  I found the treasures above at the Salvation Army Op-Shop.Â  The silk framed pictures were dirty & covered in fly spots but I was able to gentle wash them & dry in the sunshine.Â  At $2 for the pair I could notÂ leave them behind ... Yes one is very faded but I still love it & have hung them on my bedroom wall.At the Hospice I found the two trays above right - $6 & $4 respectively.Â  I hope to paint/revamp them both.Â Â My daughter in law's Mum Julie, is turning 60 & I wanted to make her something to gift.Â  I stitched another of the Books & Roses bookmarks thatÂ Jenny of elefantz designsÂ is so generously sharing with us this year.As I don't really know Julie's colors I made this one to match the book that I had purchased for her in the Boxing Day sales.Â Stitchery worked in Cottage Garden Threads "Running Postman"I used a scrap of Tilda floral from the Old Rose Collection & then I added a soft blue velvet ribbon to the top as I had no tassels left in my stash.Jenny has released a new bookmark pattern while I was away ...Â  go * Here * to access itÂ - it is beautiful & isÂ next-on-my-list-to-stitch ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜ŠThank You all so very much for your visits here today,I hope the week ahead is filled with many happy moments dear friends,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Op-Shop Treasures
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersThe weeks go by so quickly & here we are in the final week of January already!I want to teach my grandsons the value & the JOY of op-shopping & buying second hand.I took Sid along to St John's Op Shop last week as we had a couple of bags to drop off & - as luck would have it - they had a large collection of dinosaurs that had been donated.Sid & I chose all the above figurines & JeepÂ for the sum total of $35.00.(including Dragon book further below)Â When you push the orange button on the top of the Jeep the cage doors open & a dinosaur pops out & growls. This was priced at $4.50 ... I let Sid take this one home with him as well as 2 dinosaur figurines that he chose.Â  (the other figurines I kept here for both Sid & Alec to play with when they come)Sid's Mum pointed out to me that this crocodile was a Schleich brand.Â  A quick google search of this same toy & it showed a new price tag of $25.00 ... I paid $3.50 for this one.Â This beautiful Dragonology book was in nearly-new condition - I paid $5 for it & found it onÂ Book DepositoryÂ for $62.00 !!Â  I have put this book away to gift to one of my grandsons when they are a bit older.Â Â Whilst at the Op-Shop I found the aluminium pots above for $4 & $6 respectively.Â  I had an idea for both of them ... I will share the larger pot today but the smaller one has not yet gone to its recipient so I will share that in another post.I painted it with two coats of chalk paint in the colour Pumice - then applied the remnants of an Iron Orchid designs transfer to the base & the lid.Â  Then I gave it 2 coats of Annie Sloan clear wax.I purchased this beautiful pink Begonia on special at my localÂ Mitre 10 & it fit perfectly in the pot.Â  The friend I am giving it to just loves anything Pink ğŸ’—Â  I decided I am not going to plant it as she may choose to use the pot for something else.My friend Gail is having a birthday at the end of this month.Â  She is really tricky to buy for now as she more or less has everything she wants or needs.Â  I bought this book awhile ago for her & decided to make her one of the beautiful free bookmarks thatÂ Jenny of elefantz designsÂ is so generously sharing throughout this year.I stitched it on a scrap of pale blue linen (using Cottage Garden thread "Blue Wren") ...Â & instead of "2022" I stitched Gail's name.Â  I embellished it with some lace scraps & a piece of treasured Tilda Fabric from the Windy Days collection.The cotton dish/washcloth knitting continues - I like to knit these at nights when I am tired or perhaps when Sid is watching his Dinosaur programmes on YouTube & sitting still for half an hour ... I like to have something to pick up.Â Â * Here * is the free patternÂ I like to use - knitted on the diagonal - easy peasy.Yesterday I made myself a new Ironing Board Cover.Â  Long time readers of my blog will know this is something I like to do as each new year rolls around.Â  I had 60cms of this lovely Cath Kidston fabric purchased fromÂ MystyleÂ which fit perfectly.Â Â I always just take the old cover off, lay it on my new fabric & cut around it, then overlock the edges, sew a casing & thread a new piece of elastic through it.Â  It probably takes me half an hour tops.Â  I even gave my Iron a clean ğŸ˜‰Thank you as always for your visits here today dear friendsI first tried to do this blog post on Sunday Evening but you can see by the photo above, how much progress I made on that !!!Â  ğŸ˜Sending much love & friendship to You All,Love Julie & the furry nuisancesÂ ones x0x0x

title: A Church Made Of Trees
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersLast Sunday my dear friend Sue & I went to Church together - we went toÂ The Tree Church a stunning venue about half an hour from here.Â  Sue had visited once before but I had never been.Â  Â Oh dear friends - it wasÂ  AmazingÂ !!I took about 50 photos in total so I have tried to pick out the best just to give you some idea of this beautiful property.Â  Believe me dear readers - my photos do NotÂ do it justice.The approach to the church top left & inside - the altar.Taken from inside the church looking outwards ... you can see the Iron windows top right.Although the Tree Church acquired new owners about 18 months ago, it was the realisation of one man's dream - who had the vision to build a church frame from iron & then grow & train trees over the entire shape of it.Â The entire property covers 3 hectares & is planted out in the most amazing garden - I just loved all the structure from the different trees that were planted.Â  If youÂ click * here * it gives a bit more background about the history of the Tree Church & if you scroll to the bottom of the page there is a beautiful soothing Video to watch showing the Church & Gardens.I adored the trees in the avenue above left - their trunks looked & felt like paper bark.Sue said these clipped trees above left reminded her of Dr Seuss trees.There was an area of flower gardens planted in a cottage garden style as well as a large veggie garden area. It was all immaculate.Tall sunflowers that reached way up above our heads.Sue managed a photo of us both inside the Church - I am inclined to chop heads off when I try to take selfies ğŸ˜‰We spent a good couple of hours there & then we drove over to Cambridge & went toÂ The Podium Cafe where we enjoyed a delicious lunch while chatting & watching the boats & water ski's on Lake Karapiro.Â  It was such a wonderful days Outing ğŸ˜ŠThese are lightweight aluminium horseshoes worn by Race Horses that I cover.I managed to complete two Orders this past week ... the first was for my friend Jan, who asked me to make a white horseshoe & if possible, to put a gold "50" on it as it was to be presented at a 50th wedding anniversary.The 2nd Order was for 20 Mothball Sachets for my friend Marie who had an infestation of moths in her Merino Jumpers. Luckily I had all the dried herbs on hand to make these up & only had to purchase the whole cloves.As school is on holiday here 'til February, Alec came to stay a couple of days.Â  His first request was "can we craft".Â I cut out a large fabric heart shape & set him to work embellishing it.Â  Alec loves anything shiny & gold so he was in his element.Â  He quickly decided he did not wish to learn to sew the things on as yet so we relied on craft glue & the hot glue gun.Â We had a visit to the Park & then the Berry farm to pick raspberries & of course, a berry icecream each ğŸ˜ŠThe next day he enjoyed the play dough ... I had a couple of new colours & lots of shape cutters as I had been gifted some new cutters for Christmas.Â Â I have been trying to blog for at least 3 days now with no success - I thought I would show you this next photo so you might realise how very difficult it is to actually get computer time around here ğŸ˜‰Thank you as always dear friends, for your visits here today,Wishing you all a wonderful week ahead - be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Happy New Year Everyone
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersHappy Shiny New Year to you All ...Â  & Welcome to 2022 ğŸ’™I've felt so shattered since my return from Mum's - I've had to have Nana Naps each day & certainly slept through the New Years entrance.Â  Â The Mr pointed out to me yesterday that it was an incredibly busy lead up to Christmas & now that it is over with, sometimes you just have to rest & re-group.Each Christmas I usually include a Lego set for the toy content of my Grandsons Stockings. This year Alec's parents informed me that he no longer played with his Lego - but what he wasÂ VeryÂ IntoÂ was Gemstones.Luckily I was able to go online & buy Gemstones from a variety of sellers, but when they arrived they just looked like a bunch of coloured stones.Â  Â I found some voile bags & printed out labels for each set of rocks, then found this pale grey box & was able to make a label for this from some wooden cutouts I found in my craft drawer.I love this photo above left - you can see the joy on Alec's face when he opens his Gemstone box & in the next pic he is busy yelling "Sid - look at my Gemstones!!"Â ... however Sid has just opened his new Lego pack & could not care less about any old Gemstones ğŸ˜ŠÂ  ... Just precious memories.Â We had a lovely early Christmas celebration on Sunday 19th & I fed them all a traditional Roast Turkey Lunch.Youngest Grandson Sid with their dog DarcyÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â It's hard to believe this wee rascal turns 5 this coming year & will be off to school.Â Â Â The next day - MondayÂ  - my dear friend Sandy had invited 3 girlfriends to her home for a Christmas Morning Tea. It was so lovely to catch up again as I had not seen one of the girls (Pam) for well over a year.Â  Sandy is always a wonderful Hostess & she presented us with a delicious morning tea & we were still sat chatting & laughing well after lunchtime !From left to right,Â  Bev, Pam, Sandy & myself ğŸ˜ŠÂ  ....Â  Â the food was simply delicious !!Everything Sandy does is to exquisite taste & her home was so beautifully decorated for the festive season.Â Â I couldn't resist snapping a few photos.Later that same day The Mr & I travelled over to the City to pay a Christmas visit to Juno & her parentsÂ (they were travelling South for Christmas this year). We gave her the table & chair that I revampedÂ in * this post * along with other gifts ... & I took some home-baked treats so we could enjoy a Christmas supper together.Juno was quite taken with her table & chair & I was delighted when her Mummy told me one of her absolute favorite things is Rabbits.The next day was my Tuesday-with-Sid,Â  then on the Wednesday I got up very early & set off on the 4-hour drive down to Mum's.Â Â I always stop at Stratford for a takeaway coffee & can never resist a quick look in their local Hospice Shop.Â  I came away with the above items as the books were all $1 each, & I purchased the china because - of course - I needed more vintage china like I need a hole in my head !!ğŸ˜‰I love these photos above - Alec was quite taken with Mum & very affectionateThe Thursday was spent doing errands & tasks for Mum as well as a huge grocery shop.Â  On Friday I prepared a big finger-food luncheon as we had visitors - eldest son & his family were en-route to Palmerston North & also Mum's younger brother had travelled over to join us for Christmas.Mums younger brother Rol - top leftÂ  ......Â  Â Aaron, Sarah, Mum & Alec top right.The obligatory Family Photos.Christmas Day itself passed in a complete blur & I forgot to take any photos. But I cooked another Roast Turkey Lunch for Mum, my Uncle & my brother & his wife.Â Â VeryÂ early the next morning I left to return home again, trying to avoid the usual Boxing Day traffic.I received some lovely books for Christmas - the Joy of Gardening book I purchased for myself from The Mr.Â  He also gave me a leaf blower which I was most excited about as I love power tools (yes I am strange like that !!)Â The other books were gifts from my friend Sally.I returned home to lovely decorations posted from friends across the ditch (Australia).Â  The candle on the right was gifted from my Stepson & the fragrance is Christmas Lights - pomegranate & fig - just light & pleasant.Well dear friends - our weather here is scorching & we are in the midst of a heatwave.Â  Some rain is forecast tomorrow but I won't hold my breath.Â  I turn the air-con on in the afternoons & these two usually retreat to our bedroom which is nice & cool with the blinds down.Wishing you all the most wonderful New Year,Thank you as always - for your visits here today,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: A December Recap
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWell another Christmas is behind us & tomorrow evening we roll on in to a shiny New Year.I thought I would do a bit of a recap on some projects I completed in December but did not get to post about prior to Christmas. In no particular order here eitherÂ  ğŸ˜‰ . . . . .While searching the internet for a Primitive Santa pattern I stumbled across these beautiful patterns fromÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â Kentucky PrimitivesÂ & fell in love with this one -Â  "Mousie's Christmas Letter to Santa"The pattern comes as an instant download & included is the Letter that Mousie wrote to Santa, which you then have to coffee stain & generally "muddy up".Click on the photo so you can enlarge & read the LetterThe letter is so sweet - you can read it top right.Unfortunately my Mousie Brown turned out to be more of a "Ratty Rat" as I added too much black to my light brown paint.Â  Once dry, you sandpaper him & then rub with cinnamon so, as you can imagine - he smells great!!I gave him a jute string tail & a woollen checked scarf.Â  His pencil is made from a twig & the end sharpened, with a dab of black paint added.I got these large books for free from my local 2nd hand Bookstore in Kihikihi, so I painted & distressed them for Mousie to stand on ... a little primitive vignette.I packaged up & posted off a large order of my Citrus & Rose petal potpourri to the bottom of the South Island.I made two Lavender & Lace covered coat hangers for my friend Bev.I made a Lavender sleep pillow to gift to one of my daughter in laws, along with a jar of Sleep Balm purchased fromÂ The Herb FarmYou may recall the swap I mentionedÂ in * this post * where I made the 8 felt mice to send to my swap partners.Â  A gorgeous array of Christmas Ornaments & gifts began to trickle through my mailbox.Â  We were allowed to create, thrift or purchase a Christmas related ornament & the girls came up with such a wide variety of goodies.Â From the far north to the deep south, lovely packages came in & brightened my days. The girls each agreed that we all got far moreÂ out of this swap than we ever anticipated & it was so special to open each of the swap gifts & think about the giver, most (6) of whom I have never even met.This year I made Gingernut Bites, Fudge Cake & Mars Bar SliceI made my usual Christmas baked treats & packaged them up in cellophane & brown paper bags ready for gifting to friends.In early December I invited 3 girlfriends for a Christmas Morning Tea. I polished my Oak dining table & set it nicely with my vintage crochet table cloth & my finest bone china.Â  I went to answer the phone & when I returned I hadÂ  Â  Â "an extra guest" sitting at (onÂ !!)Â the table (!!!) ğŸ˜‘( Stitched using Cottage Garden Thread "Mistletoe" )I finished these two Stitcheries during Lockdown & finally made them up into small plump cushions using some Liberty fabrics.Â  The patterns are a Natalie Bird Design fromÂ this Christmas book * here *...... I can show them now that they have been gifted.I came across this Stitchery on calico that I had started many years ago.Â  I used to make these Oval Christmas Santa bags & sell in my Craft Cottage, but had never made one for myself.Â  This is a very old pattern by Wendy Briggs of Country Friends Designs whom I am sure is no longer creating.I finished stitching the Santa & then made him up into this cute Christmas bag ... I had planned to fill it with greenery & berries but this might have to wait until next Christmas now. ğŸ˜‰Well dear friends - this is my wish for you all as we wave Goodbye to another Year & we welcome with anticipation a New One.Thank You all so much for taking the time to visit with me here ... I appreciate each & every one of you. ğŸ’•Wishing you a wonderful celebratory weekend ... mine will be spent with a good book, a glass of vino & a couple of furry friends,With VeRy Much Love & Friendship To You All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: A (mini) Christmas Home Tour   ğŸ„
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAs promised, I have put together a little Christmas Home TourÂ of my rather small & humbleÂ Home.Â  I have decorated my dining room & lounge, & just tucked a couple of bits into my kitchen.Â Come along with me - grab yourselves a cuppa or a tipple. Hang on a minute & I'll pass you one through the screen ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜ŠğŸ·I have a Galley style kitchen that you walk into directly off the deck & then into my dining room.Â  A couple of shelves in my kitchen above - just small festive bits tucked into them.The bench to the right of my stove area.Beside my dining table I have a vintage Singer Sewing Table which I change the displays on throughout the year. This is my Christmas display (which I think I showed last post)Our dining room is L-shaped & has the fireplace in, as it was originally the lounge.Â  This small round table above holds my knitted ornaments tree & some other bits. I purchased the Poinsettia yesterday for $5.The table in the corner (above) holds some handmade items & then below is the fireplace hearth & mantle.Â (If you click on the pics you can enlarge them & see clearer)The mantle is not especially wide so I am limited to what I can display on it.A small display of bottlebrush trees on my china dresser.Â  (I am totally in love with bottlebrush trees lately!!)Now we walk through into my Lounge room ......A display on my vintage typewriter & thenÂ the Tilda Reindeer I made last year hanging above this.My American Oak Spindle Leg table with some handmade Santa's on - & the antique wooden trolley cart filled with teddies beside this.The old fireplace mantleÂ which I installed * here * - both in the day & at night.Vintage Metal highchair & handmade Mohair BearI like to create little vignettes, which I say are for the grandchildren but truthfully I think are for theÂ grown-up-childÂ that lives here (Yours truly !!) ğŸ˜‰I had planned to pack away the Tilda Princess-&-the-Pea cot which I made in * this post *.Â  However I decided to leave her out & give her some Christmas embellishing.I wrapped some empty boxes with pink paper & sewed her a simple Santa hat (pink of course)Â from a scrap of pink felt. ğŸ’—I hung my gorgeous pink stockings from my Gothic Mirror ğŸ’•This Tilda Father ChristmasÂ was made earlier this year & was my first attempt Ever at Needleturn applique.Â  I have hung him on my quilt ladder.Another little pink vignette using up bits I already had .....Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  The tree stands just behind my couch rather than in a corner so it is decorated all the way around.Under the tree is my vintage metal trolley filled with (empty) wrapped boxes & (some of) my vintage teddy collection.Beside the tree I have a squishy armchair & a round oak table - both Christmas decorated ğŸ„Beside my TV is another small table - this time a primitive vignette.Â  I will write about Mousie Brown in my next post - he is a new pattern.Â  The music bunting was made just yesterday from some scraps of vintage sheet music I found.The top of our vintage radiogram - I like to put little Santa hats on my teddies at Christmas.Â  Â  Â I haven't included my coffee table display (similar to last years)Â & a couple of other tables because I think you might all have a crink in your necks by now.Thank You So Very MuchÂ for staying with me through this long drawn out post.Â  Â Â This will be my last post before Christmas - we are having our family Christmas this Sunday & then I am heading down to Mum's mid week to spend Christmas with her.Â  Â  I would like to take this opportunity to Wish You AllÂ a peaceful & blessed Festive Season - may you all enjoy the spirit of Christmas.Â  I appreciate each & every single one of you that takes the time to visit me here & read my ramblings. The Mr assures me I am only talking to myself so I thank you for the chance to tell him he's mistaken ğŸ˜‰Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â With much love & friendship To You All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x ğŸ’—ğŸ„ğŸğŸ˜»

title: Christmas Festivities
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersIt feels like December came aroundÂ really fast!Last weekend I sat on the floor & wrapped 48 tiny parcels in red tissue paper ....Â  I was filling my grandsons advent stockings again, even though it only feels like yesterday I was filling them for last December.On Wednesday the 1st December I hand delivered them & both boys got to open their first one.Â Â I picked Alec up from school which he was very excited about.Â  Also he had forgotten it was December 1st so his advent calendar was a real surprise.Last December I made myself this Advent Angel just prior to Christmas & only got to enjoy her for 7 days beforeÂ "the big day" arrived.So I was delighted to pull her out this year & get to enjoy her for the full lead up. Each day I change the swing tag on her dress.Go toÂ this older PostÂ if you want to read the details about her.Early in December our small craft group usually go out to lunch as our little "break up" for the year.Â  This year we decided to go across to Tirau, about an hour away.Last year a couple of the ladies handed out bags of baked treats at our lunch so this year I decided to do something with the multitude of cotton dishcloths that I continually knitted during our Lockdowns, to help keep myself sane.Â Â I frequently buy soaps fromÂ this lovely little craft shopÂ out at Pirongia & store in my gift box.Â  I added a soap to each dishcloth & wrapped it up nicely in cellophane with a Christmas swing tag tied to it. I did up 7 packages & popped them in my vintage cane basket so the ladies could each choose their own.The Craft ladies were all just delighted with their little surprise gifts ğŸ’™Speaking of dishcloth cotton, I purchased these two new lovely colourways from Spotlight last week when I went across to visit Alec.Â  You can see from the photo that a certain ginger 4-legged furry creature took a liking to the bottom one while I turned my back for barely 2 minutes !! ğŸ˜–We had a lovely outing to Tirau for our lunch & I purchased a couple of Christmas gifts for hard-to-buy-for people.Â  I usually buy a couple of new Christmas decorations each year & these above were my purchases from Tirau as they had 25 % off all Christmas stock.Â I belong to a small private group on Instagram of 8 ladies & this year we all agreed to take part in a Christmas Ornament swap.Â  The ornament could be handmade, shop bought, or thrifted.Â  I decided to make the girls these felt mice in stockings, a free pattern off the internet (which I can no longer find)Â & I began stitching mine back in early November as I knew they were labour-intensive & fiddly.Once finished I thought they looked a bit tiny so I decided to add a box of my citrus potpourri to each parcel as I was sure the girls in the group would love this.Â  I purchased these Kraft favour boxes onlineÂ from * Here *Â & just love how attractive my potpourri looked all packaged up in them.Recently I called in to see my friend Gail at the Op Shop where she volunteers - she was just about to toss this broken section of Christmas Tree in the skip.Â  Being the "Steptoe" that I am, I asked her if I might please have it.Â  I chopped it up with The Mr's wire cutters & the greenery has come in so handy this year for both decorating AndÂ gift wrapping.Â Madam Butterfly (aka Pippi) was off colour for a few days last week -Â  She gets like this from time to time.Â  I came home from Tirau to find The Mr had tucked her up sound asleep - I am rather thinking she might put this on for all the fuss & attention she gets ğŸ˜‰Thank You all for your ever-welcome visits here today dear friends,I hope the coming week is good & kind to you,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: This Past Week I  .............................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersÂ Â It was another busy week here at Threadbear HQ ğŸ’—This past week IÂ received some wonderful surprise mail, all the way from the U.K.Â Sid was most taken with the card of the Owl, the Pussycat & the pea green boat !!Pam - a longtime reader of my blog, wanted to send me something to say Thank YouÂ for my blog & all the links & tutorials that I share with you all out here in blogland, so she stitched me this absolutely beautiful Needlebook & filled it with goodies before sending it across the oceans & the miles to me here at the bottom of the world.Â Â The front (left pic) & even the back (right pic) had a gorgeous design stitched on itPam's work is just exquisite & I know this will be treasured as well as Very Well Used.Thank You So Much Pam for your kindness & generosity. ğŸ’•This past week IÂ was able to meet up with my Craft Group ladies again - we are allowed to have small gatherings indoors now, so we all met up at Maureen's home last Monday.This is what the table looked like as we all worked on beaded Christmas trees that Gail & Maureen had stitched onto fabric for us ready to embellish.Â  All we had to bring along was a selection of charms, beads & any broken jewellery bits.Â  None of us finished our trees (there was lots of chatting & catching up)Â but I have clicked a few pics of our works-in-progress.I just loved the top left hand pic of the doiley tree Maureen had made & would love to make one similar.Joyce's one (top left) was almost finished - Sharlaine's is the green one.I think these two were Sally & Liz's ... I will show more pics when the girls (& myself)Â complete them. Some of us are going to frame ours & some will make into wallhangings.This past week I had a haircut which delighted me immensely ğŸ˜ŠÂ  Also I took all the vintage china off my dining room dresser & gently washed it all after a winter of fires & dust.Â Â I decided to takeÂ the beautiful birthday quiltÂ my dear friend Leeanne made me, offÂ my bed for the summer so I found a way to drape it over my dresser & thought it looked lovely with the china all around it.When I was happy with the arrangement of all my china I added just a couple of simple Christmas touches to the dresser.This past week I dug out this Christmas Pattern that I purchased (about 4 Christmas's ago) fromÂ Grandmothers GardenThe Pattern is called Christmas Bowl Fillers & comes complete with a pre-printed panel fromÂ Bonnie Sullivan of All Through The NightÂ designs.Â  You applique the preprinted designs with wool felt - I had fun sorting through my scraps of wool felt & Miss Pip very graciously approved my choices for me ğŸ˜‰Once the handwork was done I quickly sewed & stuffed them into tight little cushions & then I added some feathery wool to the outer edges to give it a fluffy Christmas look.Â  I also stitched some tiny charms to several of the cushions.I have had this tiered tray for ages but never ever used it so I really enjoyed doing a Christmas display in it using my new cushions/bowl fillers.These 6 wool felt decorations were handstitched by me way back in early JanuaryÂ in this post * here *Â - this was an Op Shop kitset purchased for $5.Â  It is lovely to be able to add them to my Christmas displays this year.You might remember on my last trip to Mum's in early October I purchased these 2 china tureens ($6 & $4) from the SPCA shop.Â  You can read about themÂ * here *Â Â They were both minus their lids but I had thought I would like to fill the larger one with my citrus potpourri & make up a candle in the smaller size one.Yesterday I did just that & I am so pleased with how they both turned out - the candle fragrance is Christmas Time, which I thought was perfect & the potpourri smells of delicious orange/clove scents.The Mr is away riding Moto X this weekend so I am hoping to finish all my Christmas decorating.Â  I am usually alwaysÂ a not-before-1st-December kind of girl but this year I am trying to be more organised & it has felt like it's bringing a little JoyÂ to things.Â  I have been thoroughly enjoying watching "Christmas House Tour" YouTube videos & I may do a little pictorial House Tour when I am finished so long as I don't bore you senseless ğŸ˜‰Wishing you all a wonderful rest of the weekend dear friends,Thank You - as always - for your visits here today,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Dinosaurs .......... & Some Christmas Touches  ğŸ„ğŸ’
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAlthough the past two days have been sunny, the week prior was wet & windy & wild.Â  Though I am always thankful for any rain at this time of year as it gives the garden such a good drink, the winds were just dreadful.A vase of spring roses picked before the winds bashed them ğŸ’•On the wettest days these two took up residence on my couch - I was quick enough to toss a cotton sheet over my good quilt & cushions.Â  As you can see one has the entire length of the couch & one gets to curl up in the little space left over ğŸ˜‰I had purchased this gorgeous Dinosaur fabric fromÂ my local Patchwork Shop just prior to Lockdown. I wanted to make each of my Grandsons a pillowcase for Christmas.Â  I used thisÂ simple tutorial * Here *Â  which I find fast & effective to make up.The top left hand photo shows the back of the T-Rex one. This was a cot panel that I cut down to pillowcase size.Â I made Sid a Triceratops Crown & we both coloured it in - he loved it & wore it for two days running before asking me to cut it down for his toy Tiger.Â  I bury dinosaurs in the sandpit & then he uncovers them using my paint brushes & tells me about the fossilsÂ he unearths.Â After he went home on Monday I decided to put my Christmas Tree up & add the lights.Â  I thought it would fill in several hours the following day while we decorated it together.Let me tell you friends ... that boy is a trooper.Â  He hadÂ far more stamina & staying powerÂ than his Granny did. I wanted to stop after about half an hour & have a cuppa but he kept on going until every single last decoration was on the tree & believe me ... there are alot !!And he didn't just put them all down at low height either - he climbed on the little stool & spread them around at all different levels.Â  He did a wonderful job & I was most impressed but most importantly - he loved it !!And I might add ... we did notÂ even get the felt tree skirt around the tree before Madam Pip came along, curled up on it & promptly went to sleep!!On my last trip to Mum's I purchased these wooden discs in her local Variety store - $2 for a bag of 10.Â  I had some Christmas paper serviettes left over from last year so I mod-podged some on to the wooden discs & made lovely tags to tie onto packages for Christmas.Â  This was such a fun & simple task that I thoroughly enjoyed.I must be honest & say that the next task was definitely Not funÂ & enjoyable.Â  Â  I have loved these shabby twig trees for a long time - they areÂ a free tutorial on Kerryanne's blog.Â Â  Â I just found it so incredibly fiddly & ended up having to spray starch/iron my fabric strips to stop them from all turning towards the back.Â  Â I had no cream coloured bells so I painted a rusty bell & I won't go in to detail about how time consuming that task was suffice to say I won't be making anymore of these. ğŸ˜‰I made a felt matchbox mouse to gift to a friend.Â  Â (This used to be a free downloadable pattern but I can no longer find the link to it.Â  If anyone should want to make one then email me & I can send you my pattern.)Â I have long admired these teeny tiny stockings that are all over Instagram & finally got around to making myself a set.Â  I stuffed mine with wadding & then added greenery & pip berries to the tops. These are just pegged on to my Christmas ribbon with tiny pegs from the $2 Shop.Â Â I made mine up using some primitive duller coloured fabrics but I would rather like to make myself a pink set too ğŸ’—Thank You so much for your ever-welcome visits here today dear friends,Wishing you all a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other.With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0x

title: Under My House ............
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersGosh here it is the 11th already ... over a week gone by so fast !When we extended the deck around 3/4's of our house we hung a large swinging door at one end so that we could access the cavity underneath at any time.Â Â It's a good place to store old garden pots, bamboo stakes & other garden-related paraphernalia.Â  I crawled under there last week as I wanted a pot for a maidenhair fern.Â  It's not pleasant under there - its dark & full of cobwebs but I did find some hiddenÂ junkÂ treasure.Â This chipped ceramic pot was the perfect size for my fern so I gave it 2 coats of Chalk Paint in the colour Grey Mist.Â  Before it dried I picked any black cat hairs out of it ğŸ˜‰I finished it off with this Re-design transfer & a couple of coats of clear wax.Â Â Now we have the birds, the bees & the butterflies ğŸ˜ŠOnce we finish with fires for the year I give the firebox a good clean out & fill with pinecones. I polish the hearth & surrounding bricks & I like to sit my plants along the hearth for the summer months.Also under the house I found these two rusty old watering cans.Â  I hauled them out as I had a plan for one of them.I painted it with some leftover black chalk paint that had nearly gone hard, but which I added water to.Â  Then I used up some of the Iron Orchid transfers that I had left over from whenÂ when I upcycled the vintage SawsI sprayed it with 2 coats of matt finish polyacrylic to protect it.I planned to sit it outside on the deck by my Mangle & the saws.Â I had thought about planting it with some black mondo grass however when I posted a photo & mentioned this on Instagram the majority of people said Leave it as it is.Â  What do you think dear blog readers ... plant or leave as is ??The kitchen smelt a delicious mix of Sweet Lime & Mandarin & also Christmas Tree fragranceWe had atrocious weather last week with strong winds & rain so I spent a pleasant morning in my kitchen making up some candles into vintage containers & using up the last of my Soy Wax.Â  I plan to give most of these as Christmas Gifts.I came across this box full of vintage Tala cookie cutters in the back of a cupboard.Â  I thought about donating them but then decided to make up some play dough for Sid to play with .Â  .Â  .Â  ..Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  which he very much enjoyed & the cookie cutters were a big hit !Thank You so very much for your visits & for stopping by here today dear friends,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: These Lockdown Days ......................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersThe days & weeks continue to go by so very fast - we are still in Lockdown Level 3 here so many of my days are still taken up with looking after Sid.Â I can hardly believe we turn the calendars over to November tomorrow !!I just Love this photo my son sent me of Sid with Darcy - just a boy & his dog, two scruffs togetherÂ  - happiness indeed ğŸ’™(Sid uses my kindling wood to make fences & enclosures)On Friday we went down to the Pond to feed the fish & while we were gone, another big black T-Rex got insideÂ the dinosaur enclosure!Â  Oh dear - we must've left the gate open ğŸ˜² !!Â While hunting in a drawer for a piece of flannelette I came across these vintage flour sacks.Â  I thought they would be ideal to make some outdoor cushions with as I needed some for my rustic garden seat down by the Pond. I made an inner & stuffed them quite loosely as I wanted them to feel squishy.Â They are perfect for the seat & it doesn't matter if they get left out in the odd rain shower.Â  The cherry blossom tree (Shimidsu Sakura) is in full bloom at the moment.While ratting around under my house looking for a planter pot I came across this vintage childs table & chair set.Â  I pulled them out & gave them a scrub - they were Very rusty.Â  I thought I would like to paint them up & maybe gift to my step grandaughter Juno for Christmas.The Mr made me sand them first & then spray them all over with an anti rust Primer.Â  I usually want to take the quickest, simplest method but he makes me do things properly as he is boringÂ fussyÂ particular like that ğŸ˜‰It is very much a matter of using up what's on hand in these current Lockdown times. The chair is painted in Dulux Lake Camp (testpot) & the table is left over paint from my fire surround - Dulux Ngataringa Bay.Â I was most excited as I had these gorgeous rabbit transfers that I planned to use on them - purchased fromÂ * Here *I was able to do a click-&-collect with my local Mitre 10 store & purchase some new rubber feet for each item which just finished them off perfectly. (I should add here that it took 3 goes to get the right size!!!)Rather than waxingÂ  I decided to spray both items with a matt finish polyacrylic which I had on hand - I think this will give a better protection should Juno happen to draw on the table.I'm really delighted with how these turned out & hope Juno gets lots of happy hours using them. ğŸ˜ŠThe Magazine is the Spring 2018 Issue - No 26This vintage Tilda charm pack was tucked into my birthday gift this year from my dearest friendÂ Leeanne.Â  My heart skipped several beats ğŸ’—!!Â  I had earmarked this pattern in the above issue of Simply Vintage Magazine to make the Spring Cushion.The pattern is byÂ Tweetledee Design CoÂ  ... I decided to make mine up into a table runner as I did not have anywhere for another cushion.I just adore the faded florals of these earlier Tilda ranges & am not so partial to some of their newer brighter ranges.Â  This charm pack was called "All that is Spring"Â The Needleturn applique always takes me out of my comfort zone but finally I was happy with my centre panel.I just did some simple straight line machine quilting across the pieced blocks.It fits perfectly tucked into my Spring display ... I picked a small vase of Seafoam roses yesterday before the rain bashed them all.Â  It's hard to believe only one more month of Spring time left.I saw this on Instagram last week & it made me smile ... all that Lockdown Baking & EatingÂ has resulted in "Covid Curves" so I could definately relate ğŸ˜‰Â  I hope it makes you smile too dear friends.Wishing you all a wonderful week ahead - be kind to yourselves & to each other,Thank You So much for stopping by here today,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: To Mum's & Back Again ................................  (Part Two)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI paid 50c for the small china butter dish & the Yankee Candle was $4 - brand new!Â Long time readers of my blog will know that I love to scour the Op Shops in Mum's small town.Â  This visit I literally had to run around them as I waited for Mum's prescription to be made up.Â  I found the items above at 3 shops, Hospice, St Mary's & the SPCA ... I've put the prices beside each item.I especially love the two tureens above that I found at the SPCA shop - minus lids but only $4 & $6 each. The china isÂ W.H. Grindley & Co & each piece is number stamped.Â  I would like to make a candle up in the smaller one with 2 wicks & maybe fill the larger one with potpourri.The beautiful vintage cushion cover that all my thrifted items are resting on was tossed to me by my friend Claire as I was leaving her Home.Â  Yesterday I made a calico inner for it & stuffed it tightly.Â  I really love the pattern & am wondering if it might be Sanderson Linen?I treated myself to this beautiful Candle while down at Mum's with some leftover birthday money.Â  I have been given the Oakmoss fragrance before & absolutely loved it ... & I can verify that I still do !! ğŸ’—The Mr informed me that it rained here nearly every day that I was gone & I can see the garden has come to life in the few days I was away.Â  The pram thatÂ I featured * here * is almost entirely surrounded by forget-me-nots & granny bonnets now.Â  The blossom trees are in full bloom . . . . .Â . . . . .Â  the clematis is in full bloom & my pots are flowering away merrilyÂ Beautiful vibrant Rhodohypoxis ...... I have 3 pots of thisI had sewn basil seedlings & these are now ready to be planted out & the 3 different varieties of tomatoes that I planted in plastic buckets have grown SoÂ much.As I mentioned in my last post we are currently back at Level 3 Lockdown so the Daycare Centre is closed for Sid.Â  I have had him extra days last week & again this week.Â  We played dinosaurs on the floor & then we noticed that a really big black T-Rex had decided to join our game ğŸ˜‰I took him in to town to the Park which was taped off & a big "Closed" Sign on it ... so we went to theÂ local Rose Gardens & Sid ran around there for an hourÂ On my 2nd night Home I was just about asleep when I heard this almighty crash that I thought was a bus driving into my lounge French Doors!!Â  Â Upon investigation I found my large oval mirror had fallen off the wall taking two glass fronted pictures with it & shattering myÂ beautiful glass Fairy Dome.Â  There were splinters of glass & mirror shards everywhere to clean up.Â  I was none too impressed ğŸ˜My second "accident" was when I noticed this small wooden table top was stained & swollen on one side. I had watered the plant that sat on it prior to going away & not noticed that the water had over-run the saucer causing the wood to swell.Â Fortunately I managed to get it smooth using the electric sander, repaint it & it is now back in place with a piece of Oilcloth underneath to prevent this happening again.Â I am hoping there's Not going to be a third thing !! ğŸ˜‰Well dear friends, that's about me all caught up.Yesterday I made a Fridge Drawer Stew as I had lots of veggies needing to be used up & I also made aÂ Scroggin SliceÂ ... so I think I might just go put the kettle on.Thank You - as always - for your visits here today,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0

title: To Mum's & Back Again   ..........  (Part 1)
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI had a good, but Very busy trip down to Mum's & returned home right as my region went into another Lockdown.Â Â On my second day at Mum's we travelled just over 2 hours away to meet up with two of her brothers.Â  We had lunch atÂ The Herb FarmÂ - a wonderful place just out ofÂ AshhurstÂ with a cafe as well as a shop selling their handmade herbal products.After lunch we sat in the gardens for awhile & I captured this lovely photo. Mums brother in the middle is nearly 80 & the one on the right hand side is 94. (Mum is 92) These are the only remaining siblings from "the first batch" ... Grandma had bunches of children in batches & she had 11 altogether.Â  The reason they came in batches was because she lost pregnancies in between & then the older batch had to help raise the younger ones.After lunch we drove toÂ the CemeteryÂ  to take flowers to the family graves that are there.Â  It took us 2 hours to get around 5 graves as they were scattered all across the cemetery. Mums sister on the far right died at 5 months old in 1936.Â  I love Cemetery's - when I was young I used to find them spooky but now I find them incredibly peaceful places.We visited my brother & had afternoon tea.Â  He has finished building his fence which I wrote aboutÂ in * this Post *I was lucky enough to visit my dear friend Claire for an hour. We had a quick cuppa & I took a few snaps around her beautiful Home of some of her latest creative endeavours.I always love Claire's displays & find it makes me feel very inspired.Â Â One of her spare bedrooms above.A sweet little spring display in her entrance way.The wool picture above left is a recent completion & hangs on her Sampler wall.New Coffee Table Vignette on the right.But the item below really caught my eyeÂ & though I tried very hard to sneak it into my bag, I was not successful ğŸ˜‰Â (I'm talking about the Dress not the Vodka !!!)Claire's craft group had taken part in a knitting challenge. Claire had knitted a bodice & then sewn a tulle skirt to attach to it & hung it from a miniature (chalkpainted)Â hanger. She had knitted the bodice using a long string of tiny fairy lights, so once you turned the wee switch - it lit up!!!My pic is not doing it justice - it was Stunning!!Before I left I had to finish a bunting Order for my friend Joy. Her request was for a gender neutral woodland themed nursery. The Mum-to-be loves foxes so this fabric was perfect.Â Â I added the hearts as the Mum-to-be has upholstered a vintage chair in forest green.Â  Miss Pippi very kindly multi-tasked by pressing my fabrics for me whilst doing her morning meditation at the same time !!When I delivered the bunting to Joy I had ordered 3 of her handmade wooden tags in a lavender theme. Joy had so kindly made me extras as well as some of her other beautiful tags & some new butterfly paper serviettes to use for decoupage.Blackie did his usual "feral trick" & disappeared while I was away which gave The Mr & I even more grey hair!! He has returned again & is currently tucked up on my (un-made)Â bed with Madam Pip as we are getting icy spring showers here today.Thank You all So Much for staying with me through today's lengthy post.I will be back in a few days with Part 2 as I still have a tiny bit more to share.With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: The Blink of an Eye .....................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersAnother busy week has gone by in the blink of an eye.This vintage Cane Dolls Pram was gifted to me over 5 years ago by my dear friend Leeanne.Â Â Â I usually plant it over winter with Pansies & then in summer it enjoys either Petunias or Busy Lizzies.Â Â After I removed the flowers last summer I noticed that the entire carriage underneath had collapsed - due to constant watering the wood had rotted.Â  I didn't plant it over winter but I really didn't want it to go to the "cane pram graveyard"Â just yet ... so I pulled it into shape as best as I could & then stacked lengths of wood to hold the undercarriage up.Â This worked well but looked hideous so I popped it in a spot in my garden where I knew the plants would grow around it & hide this ugly fixer upper.Â  I lined it with a black rubbish bag & then planted some Snapdragons in it ... true to form the flowers have grown & it now looks great tucked into the garden beside my deck where the forget-me-nots will sprawl out & surround it.Â  It has bought me many years of pleasure this ratty old cane pram.Â Last Saturday my eldest son turned 40! He wanted to celebrate with a finger food family dinner here at home.Â Â On birthdays I always ask my boys if there are "any special requests".Â  He asked for aÂ Honey Rice Bubble SliceÂ & a plate of Salmon Rolls.Â  It only seems just yesterday that I was making Honey Rice Bubble slice for them as youngsters.We had a very enjoyable evening & his wife Sarah made him a carrot cake which is his favourite.Â  I blew up some balloons but these were more for the little boys than the big boys.Aaron is my eldest son & is dad to Alec, my eldest grandson.Happy Birthday Aaron - you have grown into a wonderful man that I am So Very proud ofÂ  ...Â  & it feels like I blinked & forty years went by!!On Monday I hosted the craft ladies - we are able to have small gatherings indoors now & as there were only 7 of us we had a wonderful day together sharing ideas, inspiration & delicious food.Our last meeting was a few months ago now & we had all worked on felt pincushions in a variety of patterns.Â  I had taken along 3 of myÂ Hatched and Patched DesignsÂ pincushion patterns & some of the ladies made these - others made felt fruit pincushions.Â Â I decided to make theÂ Alice Angel PincushionÂ but as I have lots of pincushions - I made mine into a door hanger by filling her with dried lavender,Â  stitching a hanging loop & some rusty bells to the bottom.My one is shown up close on the left & the ladies creations on the right - poor photo sorryOn Monday I made up kitsets for us all to make the "Christmas Elf in a Pudding".Â  This is a pattern fromÂ Tis' the SeasonÂ gifted to me by my neighbour last year.Some of the ladies bought along their Lockdown projects for Show-&-Tell, & Gail had made this beautiful framed Tree.Â  She had sewn a tree shape to some embossed fabric, stuffed it lightly, stitched on some braiding & then embellished away with beautiful copper coloured charms before framing - it was truly stunning !!On my Tuesday-with-Sid it was a beautiful sunny spring day so we went to the Park for a couple of hours, then Sid had an Icecream & a packet of Smarties ... & Granny consumed an entire bag of Jet Plane lollies All By HerselfÂ Â ğŸ˜ !!If you look at the pic above right you can see that Blackie was not at all worried about Sid & had a nap on the couch while Sid watched Dinosaurs .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  ..Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  .Â  . whereas Madam Pip who prefers to act traumatisedÂ all day long, hid in a sewing room drawer that I had accidently left open.I am happy to report that after the seed planting effortsÂ in my last PostÂ it would appear thatÂ Houston We Have LiftoffÂ Â !!Â  ğŸ˜ŠÂ  I'm sure you can see from the photo above which ones IÂ planted & which ones a certain little boy buried down real deep !!Well dear friends - I had my final Covid Vaccination this morning & now I need to pack my bags as I am off to Mum's for my usual 3 monthly visit.Thank You for your visits here today - wishing you all a wonderful weekend - be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship To You All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Snippets from my Week
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersI was delighted yesterday, to collect my newly framed Sampler from my local boutique Framing Shop.I began stitching this back in June - it is a French General Chafarcani Panel pre-printed on Linen.Â  There were a set of 4 in the series - I only purchased 1 & now wish I had bought more.Â Really hard to photograph on this rainy dull dayJanet at the Framers helped me choose this frame - new in stock.Â  I liked that the "plain-ness" of it didn't detract from the stitchery itself & I also really liked the pale pink wash of the wood.I stitched this using Cottage Garden Thread in the colour "Running Postman".Â  (Whoever knew that Running Postmen had a colour ???!!!)Â ğŸ˜‰Very slowly my Sampler Wall is growing .........................My dear friend Carolyn was up visiting as her youngest son & his partner have just welcomed a new born baby son.I buy white bath towels when they are on sale & use these to back my BibsI wanted to put together a handmade baby parcel for Carolyn to give them so I went hunting through my stash of fleece & flannelette.Â  I made 3 bibs usingÂ * this * free pattern which my daughter in laws always told me were "the best bibs Ever"!Â  I made a thick fleece cuddle rug from some gorgeous polar bear fabric & added in a pair of knitted booties.Â The lockdown dishcloth knitting continues as I slowly use up all my oddments of cotton/bamboo.Â  I really like usingÂ * this * free patternÂ as I find it enjoyable to knit up as well as being a nice size for a dishcloth (not too large, not too small)My lovely friend Shirley asked me to run up 4 lavender sleep pillows for her. She provided the beautiful Japanese Woven fabrics cut in to 6 x 4 inch squares. Shirley is a wonderful sewer but her machine has thrown a massive wobbly & gone away for major repairs.Â To try & use up some more lemons & oranges, I made aÂ Citrus SliceÂ  & also made The Mr aÂ Weetbix Slice which is his favourite.As mask wearing is mandatory in our country now, I have had more requests for masks.Â  I don't especially enjoy making these as I find them very boring & uninspiring to make & lots of people request plain black which probably doesn't help.Â  The one on the far right (black with scissors) was for my hairdresser which I thought was perfect for her.Last Tuesday Sid & I planted some "dinosaur gourd seeds" which I hope grow as a certain little boy pushed the seeds in rather deep ğŸ˜‰We also planted some sunflower seeds as every year I seem to leave this too late & then wish I had.Â My dear friend Sandy left me a deliciously moist Banana & Chocolate Chip loaf in my letter box yesterday - it was such a treat with my coffee this morning.Â Wishing you all a wonderful weekend dear friendsÂ Thank You as always, for your visits here today,With much love & friendship To You All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: Three Upcycled Items  =  $7   Total
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersA couple of months ago I had to travel toÂ Putaruru, a small rural town about 45 minutes inland from where we live ... I had to collect a farming part for The Mr.Â There is an Op Shop in Putaruru called "Paws" (Pet Animal Welfare Shop).Â  It is dimly lit inside,Â  everything is just tossed on shelves,Â  there is very little in the way of displays -Â  but the prices are VeryÂ reasonableÂ - my kind of Op Shop !!Â  ğŸ˜Â This old steamer pot (for $2) was the first item I picked up & the lid (which doesn't fit the pot) was $1.Â  I had an idea in mind for these.I painted the pot & the lid usingÂ Newtons Chalk Paint in the colour Country Green.Â  Because we are in Lockdown it was very much a matter of using up what I had on hand as there were No shops open to buy supplies.Â  Once dry I decided to apply some transfers & as you can see I had good assistanceÂ in choosing which ones to use. ğŸ˜‰I tied a thin balsa wood swing tag to the handle once finished.Â Â I also sprayed the entire thing with 2 coats of clear acrylic varnish in a matt finish.The pot had to wait two more weeks before our Lockdown Levels changed & I was able to purchase some plants for it.Â  First I lined the inside with a black rubbish bag as even though it had holes in the bottom I didn't want the water pouring out every time I gave it a drink.I had visualised white petunias in it but all I was able to get were dark burgundy petunias, which I think will be equally as nice once they bloom.The 2nd item I purchased from Paws was this wooden box for $1.00It contained filing cards inside which were surprisingly still in quite good condition.Â  It had a chip out of the lid which I was able to fill with polyfiller.Â  Once again - using up what I had on hand, I painted this with Voodoo Molly Vintage chalk paint (Robins Egg) - two coats.Â  Then I stenciled this rabbit design to the top using a testpot of white acrylic that I found.Â  I ended up sanding it back quite a bit as I wasn't especially happy with my stenciling finish initially.I lined the inside with some cardstock paper & screwed a small file-label holder to the front ğŸ’™It looks perfect amongst some other pastel items on my corner table.The last item I purchased (for $3) was this heavy old metal stool. I could not resist it & could visualise it already revamped in my mind.I removed the seat part (with great difficulty)Â & then set about painting the legs with some Pumice Chalk Paint left over fromÂ the drop leaf table I painted HereFortunately,Â  amongst the myriad of things in my stash - I found a piece of thick foam rubber.Â  I had to get The Mr to help me upholster the seat as it needed an extra pair of hands. I had this Sanderson Oilcloth left over from other projects & I use it sparingly as I adore it.I absolutely LoVeÂ how this turned out. I painted right over the rubber feet of the stool as I knew I could not get to any Hardware Stores to buy more & I think it turned out just fine. It's actually really comfy to sit on too !Â I was so chuffed with my 3 upcycled items for the princely sum of $7.00Â  ğŸ’—Thanks so much for staying with me through this waffly post dear friends - I shall leave you with this picture of Blackie.I walked around my house & I countedÂ TenÂ different comfy sleeping placesÂ  - boxes with blankets in, cushions & folded up cuddly rugs, lined baskets ... just especially for the furry ones !!And where does he choose to sleep I ask youÂ  . . . . . . . . . . ???On top of The Mr's electronic keyboard !!!! ğŸ˜–Â  Â Â No further comment I thinkÂ  . . . . . . . . . .Wishing you all a Wonderful Weekend ahead,With much love & friendship to you All,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0x

title: A  (thrifted)  Spring Tablescape
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersWelcome to SpringÂ Â - my favourite Season of the Year ğŸ’—On the very first day of spring - right on cue - my Magnolia buds burst into bloom.Â  How wonderful !Yesterday, while weeding under some shrubs, I pulled these pots of bulbs out ... I had forgotten I had shoved them under there last year when they finished blooming.Pretty Pots of Tulips & a white Hyacinth which smells divine !!I was cleaning out my hallway cupboard & came across a plastic bag of doilies that my friend Gail had tossed my way. In the middle of the doilies I pulled out this cross stitch, all screwed up & forlorn looking.I decided to frame it myself & make up a little Spring Tablescape on my Vintage Singer Sewing Table, which still had its Autumn display on it.Â I have a box full of frames in various sizes & states of repair - left over from the days of running my Craft Cottage.Â Â I found this one which was a good size to fit the cross stitch.Â  I gave the frame 2 coats of paint & then decided to add the small scroll to the top.Â  I gave the cross stitch a gentle iron to get all the creases out & then framed it using some double sided tape.I was really pleased how it turned out & the frame fitted it perfectly.These sad looking little birdhouses were in another box of junkÂ treasures so I gave them the once over with my cream chalk paint too & then added a couple of Transfers & some dried moss.The lace doiley I displayed on my pedestal stand was thrifted as were the lace cloths I used on the table.I found some Tilda flowers that I had made a long time ago & displayed them in a thrifted glass bottle ... the flower plate was a thrift store find on my last trip down to Mum's.Â The wool blanket flowers were displayed in another thrifted glass milk bottle.(I foraged a couple of birds nests)I dug out the "Spring" Stitchery that I madeÂ in this Post Â last year.The China tureen is also a thrift store item & the other few bits were just gathered from around my house.Â Â Total Cost $ zero !!And to put the finishing touch to my display ...... I picked my very first vaseful of freesias to sit in a thrifted vase.On Wednesday I knew my friend Sandy was heading in to town so I left bags of Oranges, Lemons & some Worm tea in my letter box for her to collect on her way past.She Very kindly left me a delicious Banana Loaf in return & I have been enjoying it with my cups of tea.Mask Wearing has become mandatory in my Country now so I decided to make myself a couple of new ones yesterday, using up some scraps of pink floral fabrics. I also made The Mr a plain black one.I have 2 friends with birthdays soon & I want to post them each a Garden Voucher which I am able to buy using click & collect. I made two hanging heart pockets as I love using these to gift a Voucher inside.Â  These are made usingÂ *  this great tutorial  *Â from Craft With Fee.Â  And I reluctantly cut into my treasured Tilda fabrics ğŸ’•Miss Pippi - tucked away where she is NOT supposed to be !!!!! ğŸ˜–Thanks So Much for your visits here today dear friends,I hope you all have a wonderful weekend - remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x0

title: Lockdown Projects ...........................................
text: Greetings lovely friends & readersLockdown Life continues here at the bottom of the world with our Level 4 Lockdown having been extended until the end of the month.Â  Â  There is always plenty to do here at Threadbear HQ - though I must admit my energy levels (& enthusiasm) this time round are somewhat diminished.Â Â Â Yesterday I was weeding an area of my garden & could smell the heavenly scent of wild violets - so I picked the sweetest little bunch to enjoy inside ğŸ’•We have a surplus of lemons at the moment - our tree is laden & it's branches bending over.Â  I swap produce with my neighbour Jenny who gives me free range eggs in exchange for broccoli & worm tea.Â  Jenny left a dozen eggs in my letter box a couple of days ago so I decided to make a sticky Lemon Slice.I usedÂ * this * recipe hereÂ - a recipe from a Cafe, that I had torn out of an old newspaper.Â  When I make something citrusy I want to reallyÂ tasteÂ the citrus - not just a hint of it.Â  See the piece missing from the corner .......... I can most certainly attest that This Slice Was DELICIOUSÂ !!!!Â  ğŸ˜‰Filling some bottles of worm tea for Jenny prompted me to give my worm farm a good clean out. I like to hose down the lids & get rid of any bugs & things every few months. I managed to fill 7 more bottles of worm tea - with spring just around the corner it's time to start liquid feeding plants & potted things again.I came across a half pot of Resene "Hot Chilli" paint in my cupboard which was timely because my outdoor table & chairs were looking tatty after the winter.I decided to give them a good scrub & then a coat of paint to freshen them up.Our weather this week has been more settled & it was quite pleasant painting outside on my deck area.I am always impressed with how much one good coat can give them a new lease of life.Â  Â  Now if only the birds will stop using the chairs as perches ..........I scrubbed out my old kettle, which I painted & stencilled last year & planted a small white paper daisy in this.Last OctoberÂ on one of my trips to Mum'sÂ this drop-leaf tea wagon was waiting for me in her shed.Â  My sister-in-law had seen it being carted to the road side "free for the taking" & grabbed it for me, along with 2 wooden chairs for herself.I pulled it out of my sleepout on Thursday, gave it a good wash down & then prepared to paint it with chalk paint in the colour "Pumice".I started off out on the deck but found it easier to put it on my table upside down & get in all the nooks & crannies.Â  Yes I had my usual "Supervisor" who rather enjoys watching paint dry !! ğŸ˜‰Most of it took 3 coats before I was satisfied with my coverage - I had masking taped the castors as I didn't want any paint on these.I had this gorgeous Iron Orchid Transfer that I planned to cut into & affix to my tea wagon, to take the plain-ness off it.I had a vision in my mind of flowers cascading across the top & down one of the drop leaves of the table as if someone had thrown a bunch of flowers across it . . . . . .Â I kept having to walk away & then come back to it several times before I was happy with my finish - it was tempting to keep adding more but I tried to restrain myself.I'm really pleased with how it turned out & just have to give it all a coat of clear wax now to protect it.I just added a small flower & a leaf to one leg (below)Last night at the dinner table I was telling The Mr the story of how I came to get the tea wagon - he would have No IdeaÂ what I have stashed away in the sleepout nor where I acquired it from.This morning this little funny appeared in my Inbox - sent from The Mr.Â  (Yes I must confess I am rather like that at times !!!)Thank You all So Very Much for your visits here today dear friends,I hope you are staying safe & well no matter where you may live in the world,Remember to be kind to yourselves & to each other,With Much love & friendship to you all,Julie & the furry ones x0x0x

title: The Princess & The Pea   ......   â¤  Tilda Style  â¤
text: Greetings lovely friends & readers(warning - Photo heavy post - I've tried to condense it but there's still lots of pics - apologies in advance)Long-time readers of my blog may remember the Princess & the Pea Cot I did for my friend SallyÂ way back in 2017.Â  Â Â I loved it & found it rather hard to part with ... & always kept in the back of my mind, that one day, I would like to do one for myself.On my trip down to Mum's early last month I drove past a Vintage Store several times & couldn't help noticing a dolls cot out front on the footpath. I mentioned this to my friend Claire while we were Op-shopping just prior to my trip home - next thing I know she had whisked me off to the Vintage Shop & was able to secure the cot for me at aÂ Very ReasonableÂ price.Â  I wasÂ So excitedÂ ğŸ˜Š !!I must mention that as I was paying for the Cot, the lady very sweetly asked me "Are you going to be doing it all up nicely for a young girl?".Â  Â I smiled at her & replied "Yes I amÂ going to be doing it all up nicely but it's for a rather large Not-so-YoungÂ girl aged 61!" ğŸ˜‰As you can appreciate, after spending goodness-knows-how-long sitting out front of the shop - it was in rather a filthy state. I gave it a good scrub on my return home with sugar soap.The next time I visited my local Library with Sid, I foundÂ * this * bookÂ the same one Sally had given me to use for her Cot.Â  The Princess themed doll & bedding patterns begin on Page 104.Over the course of a wet, rainy week I painted my cot using Chalk Paint in the colour Vintage White. Painting all those dowels was not exactly my idea of fun - but I love how it all turned out.I glued two thin lengths of wood together, painted & screwed to the back - this was to hang my lace drapes from.Â  This cot has a front that actually drops down & the mechanism is still in good working order.First up I made a selection of mattresses.Â  I know in the original story the Queen piles 20 mattresses up on the bed but I had to make do with 6 as I didn't want a tower of mattresses toppling down on me.I especially loved the ticking stripe ones.Â  These fabrics are all from my Tilda stash - some vintage Tilda & some from more recent ranges.I was looking forward to making the bed quilt & cut into some gorgeous vintage Tilda that I had set aside for this.IÂ  attached some wide vintage cluny lace to the top, just to give it a bit more prettiness.I didn't have enough Tilda fabric for the back but I found a pretty embroidered supper cloth that I used to back it.Then I made a wee pillow - again using vintage Tilda.ğŸ’•ğŸ’—ğŸ’•ğŸ’—Next it was time to drape the cot .....Â  I was over in the city so I popped into Spotlight as they have a good selection of lace/net curtains, which just happened to be 40% off that day.I found a length of cream gathered lace in my stash which I sewed to the bottom - I visualised it just touching the floor.I was happy with my cot drapes but after walking past them for a day or 2 I felt they needed something moreÂ ... so I decided to make some folded fabric roses from oddments of cotton lace.Â  I foundÂ this Youtube VideoÂ really helpful as I couldn't for the life of me, remember how to make these.I also wound some ribbon & lace around knitting needles & painted these with a mixture of water & PVA glue.(which is what you use when you don't have any Stiffy Fabric Stiffener)ThisÂ was the effect I was after ...Â  tumbling down ribbon curlsNext it was time to make my Princess.Â  The fabrics I used for her nightie & stockings are not Tilda fabrics but were already in my stash & I didn't have any Tilda that was suitable.I love the sweet little crown charm which I tied around her neckI am so pleased I gave her messy bed hair, which is what you would expect after tossing & turning all night long while sleeping on the pea !!!Â  I made her a crown by photocopying some Tilda fabric onto Inkjet paper.
